HEADLINE: Exports Help Japan Show Robust Rate Of Growth

BYLINE: By TODD ZAUN

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, May 18 

 BODY:
The growth in the Japanese economy surpassed all expectations for the first quarter as a largely export-driven recovery broadened to include a pickup in consumer spending, government figures showed on Tuesday.
 Japan's gross domestic product rose at an annual rate of 5.6 percent, after vigorous growth in the fourth quarter of 2003, when the economy increased at a 6.4 percent annual pace, the fastest in 13 years. 
 But while last year's expansion was driven largely by exports to the United States and China, the most recent growth figures show that Japanese consumers are also contributing to the recovery, which is now nearly two years old. Economists had been predicting a first-quarter annual growth rate of 3.8 percent. 
 Better job prospects, rising corporate profits and a decline in bankruptcies are giving consumers confidence to spend more, economists say. Japan's unemployment rate fell to a three-year low of 4.7 percent in March; consumption, which accounts for about 60 percent of the economy, has been gradually rising. 
 Household spending has increased for five consecutive months, creeping up 0.2 percent in March from the month a year earlier, after a 5.2 percent jump in February. Economists are especially encouraged by figures showing consumers are spending not only on goods like cars and cellular phones, but on travel, dining and other services.
 ''This is a very good sign for the household sector,'' said Shuji Shirota, an economist at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, who contends that the increase in spending on travel and other nonessential services indicates consumers are genuinely becoming more optimistic. Over all, for the first quarter, household consumption grew at an annualized rate of 4.1 percent. 
 At the same time, government investment fell at an annual rate of 12.8 percent, a result of efforts by the administration of Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi to reduce huge deficits built up over the last decade as previous administrations tried to revive a moribund economy with heavy doses of public spending.
 The healthy United States economy and rapid growth in China continued to support Japanese exports in the first quarter and to encourage companies to invest. A wide range of Japanese companies, from automakers and steel producers to electronics and industrial equipment manufacturers are enjoying robust profit growth because of growing overseas sales. 
 While cheap Chinese manufacturers were once seen as a threat to Japanese industry, increasingly companies see opportunities to expand sales in the fast-growing Chinese market or to use China as a low-cost production base to supply customers around the world.
 ''Japan and China are so complementary,'' said the business consultant and author Kenichi Ohmae. ''A greater, stronger, more successful China helps Japanese industries sharpen their focus on what they're good at.'' 
 The government said Monday that Japan's current account surplus -- a broad measure of trade in goods, services, tourism and investment -- rose in March for the ninth consecutive month, expanding 13 percent from the month a year earlier to 1.83 trillion yen ($16 billion). Rising exports to Asia, especially to China, were the main reason for the increase.
 In the last decade, two fledgling export recoveries in Japan died as consumption at home failed to take hold. But with both a widening of exports and signs of a rebound in consumption at home there is increasing optimism that the current recovery has staying power.
 Government figures released Monday provided further evidence that Japan's long battle with deflation may be ending. Prices that companies pay for goods and services rose in April at the fastest pace in four years, according to the figures, that economists said might be a prelude to more stable consumer prices. 
 Despite signs of improving demand at home, Japan's dependence on exports means it remains vulnerable to any changes in economic conditions abroad, economists say.
 And a sustained rebound in consumer spending is far from a sure thing. Although spending has been ticking higher, there has so far been no corresponding increase in incomes. And economists warn that the spending recovery will fade unless wages begin to rise.
 Many economists also say, however, that with rising corporate profits and fewer unemployed workers to compete for new jobs, it is just a matter of time before companies begin to pay their employees more. 
 Mamoru Yamazaki, chief economist at Barclays Capital, expects companies to be more generous when they pay summer bonuses this year.

HEADLINE: When the Oil Disappears

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 In ''A Crude Shock'' (column, May 14), Paul Krugman describes how the market deals with scarce oil supplies and gives the economist's view of the relevance of statistics like oil consumption per dollar of real G.D.P.
 But faith in the market and statistics should not obscure the bottom line: this will be the last century of majority fossil fuel use because of the energy demands of an increasing population. 
 Now is the time to make historic investments in efficiency and renewable energy research and development. For the sake of today's children, we need citizenship, self-control, common sense and community spirit to sustain humanity in a world of finite resources.

ERNEST R. BEHRINGER
Ann Arbor, Mich., May 15, 2004

The writer is an associate professor of physics at Eastern Michigan University.

HEADLINE: World Briefing Americas: Dominican Republic: A New President

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
With a hard-fought election victory in hand, President-elect Leonel Fernandez, left, began preparing for the herculean challenge of pulling the country out of its worst economic crisis in decades. President Hipolito Mejia conceded defeat late Sunday even though the Electoral Board had only counted 3 percent of the votes. He said his own voter surveys had made it clear that he would lose. With 53 percent of the vote counted by yesterday afternoon, electoral officials said Mr. Fernandez, who was president from 1996 to 2000, was leading with 55 percent against Mr. Mejia's 35 percent. A third candidate had 9 percent. It was the first election in which Dominicans living abroad were able to vote, including 52,000 registered in the United States. Mr. Fernandez said his first move would be to meet with business owners. He said he would also start heavily courting foreign investors. He is set to assume the presidency on Aug. 16.

HEADLINE: Progress at Deutsche Telekom After Returning to Its Roots

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, May 17 

 BODY:
When Kai-Uwe Ricke steps before the shareholders of Deutsche Telekom at its annual meeting in a Cologne arena on Tuesday, he will probably be hailed as a savior -- and for good reason.
 Mr. Ricke took the helm of Deutsche Telekom in November 2002 at a time when the German telecommunications giant, the largest in Europe, was in turmoil. Its leadership was discredited, its global expansion in tatters, and it was sinking under an ocean of red ink. 
 Today, Deutsche Telekom is back above water, earning 1.3 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in 2003, after a 24.6 billion loss ($29.2 billion) in 2002. Mr. Ricke has whittled down its $64 billion in debt by almost a quarter, beating his own target and putting the company on a stable course.
 But toward what destination?
 ''We have the possibility to be the most profitable integrated telecommunications company in Europe,'' Mr. Ricke, 42, said in an interview at the company's headquarters in the former German capital, Bonn.
 Such a goal may suit Deutsche Telekom's battle-weary shareholders fine. But it seems remarkably modest for a company that was run by an empire-building chief executive, Ron Sommer, who once boasted of having a $100 billion war chest for deals around the world.
 ''Every time has the right C.E.O.,'' said Mr. Ricke, who was drafted a few months after Mr. Sommer was dismissed. ''We saw the hype. We saw the deep depression. Now we are back to normality.''
 Normality, for Mr. Ricke, means tending to Deutsche Telekom's core German fixed-line phone, mobile and Internet-access markets, as well as its thriving cellular franchise in the United States. It does not mean exporting the Telekom name into exotic new markets or services.
 In this regard, the company is like other German giants, from DaimlerChrysler to Bertelsmann, which have curtailed their global ambitions. As Germany's economy continues to sputter, its leading companies have, at least temporarily, lost their appetite for overseas expansion.
 ''If you are a visionary investor, you might think of it as boring,'' said Boris Boehm, a money manager at Nordinvest in Hamburg. ''But coming back to your roots is good for investors.''
 Mr. Ricke is not retreating to Germany. Deutsche Telekom, for example, did not sell off its American cellular operations, despite being goaded by analysts, who saw it as an easy way to raise cash.
 But Mr. Ricke, whose father ran Deutsche Telekom when it was transformed from a state utility into a commercial company, clearly does not care if he is not known as a globe-trotting mogul, as his predecessor was.
 A lanky, genial man whose close-cropped hair has turned grayer in the last 18 months, Mr. Ricke favors incremental, often painful, steps: cutting costs, through a deep reduction in the number of employees, selling off extraneous assets, and raising profits in basic services. 
 In recent weeks, newspapers here predicted that Mr. Ricke would overhaul the company's four major lines of business. Critics say the structure, known as the ''four pillars,'' is outmoded in an era of seamlessly integrated communications. Yet he seems unlikely to do so.
 Mr. Ricke said it was a matter of making the four pillars -- fixed-line telephone, cellular, Internet access and technology systems -- work more closely together. ''We are where we are because we are organized as we are,'' he said, noting the company's return to profitability and growth.
 Still, some analysts doubt that Deutsche Telekom will be able to maintain its momentum without acting more boldly. They note that the company reduced its investment in MTS, a Russian mobile-phone provider that has one of the world's fastest-growing cellular businesses. It has also been unable to gain a majority stake in a Polish mobile operator, PTC.
 ''These are countries where the growth is really strong,'' said Frank Rothauge, an analyst at Sal. Oppenheim in Frankfurt. ''It would be interesting for them to go for acquisitions there.''
 Mr. Ricke's decision to hold on to Deutsche Telekom's cellular operation in the United States looks wise. T-Mobile USA, as the unit is known, added 1.2 million customers in the first quarter of this year, nearly four times the number of T-Mobile's German operation, where subscriber growth and revenue per customer are as lackluster as the broader economy.
 With the American cellular market in the midst of consolidating, Mr. Ricke said he was not averse to selling T-Mobile USA, provided the price was right. Otherwise, he seems ready to compete for customers against newly enlarged rivals like Cingular, which now owns AT&T Wireless.
 ''I'm not in the U.S. to own a Rolls-Royce,'' Mr. Ricke said. ''I'm in the U.S. to get a reasonable rate of return.''
 The United States may act as a hedge against Germany in other ways. On Friday, the German Parliament passed a telecommunications law that opens the market to competition. That threatens Deutsche Telekom's local phone business, but more vitally, its Internet-access service. It now controls 90 percent of the market for high-speed digital subscriber lines.
 Mr. Ricke lobbied fiercely against a provision that would have required Deutsche Telekom to open its network and resell parts of it to competitors. Until 2008, rivals who want to use the network will have to buy a bundle of services from Deutsche Telekom, as they do now. 
 ''Certainly, we are losing market share,'' he said. ''But it should be in a way where I feel incentives to invest in the infrastructure.''
 Deutsche Telekom is not likely to face the full fury of competition as long as the German government owns 43 percent of its shares. But the government's position has come under question lately. With Berlin trying to plug a big hole in its budget, some analysts think it might sell down its stake.
 That prospect has weighed down Telekom's stock, which at just over 13 euros a share, is up only 20 percent since Mr. Sommer's ouster in July 2002. Shareholders may credit Mr. Ricke with keeping the company afloat, but he must still figure out how to make it take wing.

HEADLINE: Lowe's Earnings Are Up 8%; Kmart Rebounds From Loss

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The Lowe's Companies and the Kmart Holding Corporation both reported profits yesterday. 
 Lowe's reported an 8 percent increase in first-quarter profit, helped by sales of higher-price items like kitchen cabinets and its expansion to big cities. 
 But the company's stock fell about 2 percent, to $49.68, yesterday on concerns about higher energy prices and rising interest rates, analysts said. 
 ''What we don't know is what's going to be the effect on home-improvement spending in the next 12 months,'' Sarah Henry, an analyst with Sovereign Asset Management, said. 
 Lowe's, based in Mooresville, N.C., reported first-quarter net income of $455 million, or 57 cents a share, compared with $421 million, or 53 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts had expected 54 cents a share.
 Sales rose 22 percent, to $8.68 billion. Sales at stores open at least a year, an important retail measure, rose 9.9 percent, helped by higher lumber and building material prices. 
 Excluding a 16-cents-a-share impact from an accounting change, Lowe's said, earnings for the 2004 quarter would have been $581 million, or 73 cents a diluted share. 
 Kmart posted its second consecutive quarterly profit as it cut costs, driving its shares up nearly 10 percent even as sales tumbled after it closed hundreds of stores last year. 
 The discount retailer, which emerged from bankruptcy protection last May with a new management team, fewer stores and lower debt, has been focusing on building profits, even at the expense of sales.
 The company, based in Troy, Mich., said it earned $93 million, or 94 cents a share, in the first quarter ended April 28. For the period a year ago, Kmart lost $862 million while it was still in bankruptcy.
 Kmart said quarterly sales tumbled 25.3 percent, to $4.62 billion, reflecting the closing of 316 stores in the first quarter last year. The company shut about 600 of its 2,100 stores while reorganizing.
 Sales at stores open at least a year fell 12.9 percent. Kmart attributed the decline to special promotions that increased sales last year and to reduced advertising this year.
 Kmart shares rose $4.32, to $48.62.

HEADLINE: Bush and Kerry Mark Desegregation Where Suit Began

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY and RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: TOPEKA, Kan., May 17 

 BODY:
President Bush and Senator John Kerry descended on this Kansas city on Monday to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Supreme Court ruling that ended school segregation, with Mr. Kerry warning against persistent racial and economic disparities and Mr. Bush saying the nation ''has yet to reach the high calling of its own ideals.''
 The remarks by the president and Mr. Kerry, his likely Democratic opponent, came in two separate if perhaps unequal events to commemorate the anniversary of the case, Brown v. Board of Education, which sprang from this city 50 years ago. 
 With all the flourishes of a presidential visit, Mr. Bush marked the opening of the Brown v. Board of Education National Historic Site at the former Monroe Elementary School, one of four all-black schools in Topeka that were at the center of the 1954 Supreme Court ruling. Air Force One flew directly over the school as it headed toward Forbes Field Airport, providing a roaring herald of the president's arrival and a dramatic picture for the local television stations covering the event live.
 ''On this day, in this place, we remember with gratitude the good souls who saw a great wrong, and stood their ground, and won their case,'' Mr. Bush said to a mostly white audience in an unusually brief speech of 12 minutes, which is about one-third the length of his standard stump speech. ''And we celebrate a milestone in the history of our glorious nation.''
 Mr. Bush warned that the ''habits of racism in America have not all been broken'' and urged that laws ''against racial discrimination must be vigorously enforced in education and housing and hiring and public accommodations.''
 Across town, Mr. Kerry attended a ceremony organized by Gov. Kathleen Sebelius, a Democrat, on the steps of the Capitol, in which Ms. Sebelius signed a proclamation marking the anniversary. To applause from an audience that appeared to be heavy with Democrats, Mr. Kerry painted a harsher portrait, that of a nation still torn by disparities in race and class.
 ''As far as we've come, we still have not met the promise of Brown,'' Mr. Kerry said on a cool, gray spring day. ''We have not met the promise of Brown when one-third of all African-American children are living in poverty. We have not met the promise of Brown when only 50 percent of African-American men in New York City have a job. We have not met the promise of Brown when nearly 20 million black and Hispanic Americans don't have basic health insurance.''
 As an indication of the extent to which the 2004 presidential race provided the backdrop for the day's ceremonies, Mr. Kerry received his loudest applause when he assailed the Bush administration for failing to finance its signature education law known as No Child Left Behind, the same law Mr. Bush later cited in talking about ways the government was working to end educational disparities.
 ''You cannot promise no child left behind and then pursue policies that leave millions of children behind every single day,'' Mr. Kerry said. ''Because that promise is a promissory note to all of America's families that must be paid in full.''
 The anniversary here coincided with a moment that gay rights advocates hail as another civil rights milestone: the first day that Massachusetts, Mr. Kerry's home state, began issuing marriage licenses to same-sex couples. But in a sign of uncertainty about how the debate over gay marriage might play in the campaign, Mr. Kerry and Mr. Bush made no mention of the events in Massachusetts in their speeches here.
 Mr. Bush, however, issued a statement urging Congress and states to pass a constitutional amendment ''defining and protecting marriage as a union of a man and a woman as husband and wife.''
 The commemoration brought the two candidates into unusually close contact, albeit in a Republican state that almost surely will not be in play this year. Accordingly, their visits were brief; Mr. Kerry flew off for Oregon, to campaign with Howard Dean, the former Vermont governor, in one of the truly contested states this fall, while Mr. Bush flew to Atlanta, where he was expected to raise $3.2 million for the Republican Party at a fund-raiser at the home of Bob Nardelli, the chief executive of Home Depot.
 The appearance in this city of a president and his likely Democratic opponent created an undercurrent of competition between the events. Rarely have Mr. Bush and Mr. Kerry been in the same state at the same time.
 When Mr. Kerry arrived at the airport to leave Topeka, he was instructed to quickly move his chartered jet off the runway before Air Force One approached and forced a shutdown of airspace. Mr. Kerry bristled when an aide, David Moorehouse, instructed him to hurry and sit down.
 ''Well, we have to taxi first, David,'' he responded.
 And at Mr. Kerry's event, an announcer asked members of the public to refrain from heading for their cars to give civil rights dignitaries time to make it to the other part of town to see Mr. Bush. Cheryl Brown Henderson, a daughter of the plaintiff in the original decision, Oliver Brown, delivered the opening remarks at the first ceremony, but slipped off the side of stage before Mr. Kerry began speaking. Ms. Henderson showed up at the Bush event.
 Among the prominent civil rights leaders who made their way to both events were the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, who did not speak at either event, and Representative Elijah E. Cummings of Maryland, a Democrat who is chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus, and who delivered a similar statement at the rallies.
 ''I am concerned about Osama bin Laden,'' Mr. Cummings said at the Kerry rally. ''I am concerned about the terrorists. But ladies and gentlemen, the greatest threat to our national security is our failure to educate our children.''
 Across town, Mr. Bush called for a continuing battle to end racial equality, and pointed to his No Child Left Behind law as the way to accomplish that.
 ''Many African Americans with no inheritance but their character need access to capital and the chance to own and build for the future,'' he said. ''And while our schools are no longer segregated by law, they are still not equal in opportunity and excellence. Justice requires more than a place in a school. Justice requires that every school teach every child in America.''


CORRECTION-DATE: May 20, 2004

 CORRECTION:
 An article on Monday about the 50th anniversary of the Supreme Court ruling that ended school segregation misstated a word in a paraphrase from President Bush, who attended a ceremony in Topeka, Kan. He called for a continuing battle to end racial inequality -- not equality.
An article on Monday about the 50th anniversary of the Supreme Court ruling that ended school segregation misstated a word in a paraphrase from President Bush, who attended a ceremony in Topeka, Kan. He called for a continuing battle to end racial inequality -- not equality.

INTERNATIONAL A3-14

Leader of Iraqi Council Killed by Suicide Bomber
A suicide bomber killed the president of the Iraqi Governing Council and at least six other people at a checkpoint into the main headquarters for the American occupation forces in Iraq. Two American soldiers and five Iraqi civilians were wounded in the attack, the military said. A1

American commanders said they had discovered an Iraqi artillery shell containing sarin, one of the deadly nerve agents that Saddam Hussein said he had destroyed before the war began last year. A10

The American officer who was in charge of interrogations at Abu Ghraib prison told a senior Army investigator that intelligence officers sometimes instructed military police to force Iraqi detainees to strip naked and shackle them before they were questioned. A1

Interrogators from military intelligence told guards at Abu Ghraib to deprive detainees of sleep or food and would strip detainees and make them sleep naked in their cells, but their orders stopped well short of the graphic abuse seen in the photos, according to testimony from guards and investigators. A14

The Armed Services Committee said it would summon three senior military commanders to testify about the abuse of Iraqi prisoners. A14

India Stock Market Crashes
Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born leader of the Indian National Congress party, will formally stake a claim to be India's next prime minister, party officials said, after the country's stock market recorded its biggest single-day fall amid concerns over the new government's approach to economic reforms. A1

Gambia Rats Sniff Land Mines
The Gambian giant pouched rat may be as good a mine detector as man or nature has yet devised. They are abundant, cheap and easily transported. At three pounds, they are too light to detonate mines accidentally. They can sift the bouquet of land-mine aromas far better than any machine. A1

Hundreds of gays and lesbians lined city halls from Boston to the Berkshires as Massachusetts became the first state in the nation to allow same-sex couples to marry. A1

HEADLINE: Calls to Ease Gasoline Prices By Taking Oil From Reserve

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 17 

 BODY:
Congressional Democrats stepped up pressure Monday on the Bush administration to ease gasoline prices by releasing oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, but administration officials plan to keep adding to the reserve until some time next year.
 On Tuesday, a group of Democrats led by Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York will demand that the government release as much as 60 million barrels from the reserve over the next two months.
 A much larger group of lawmakers has called on the administration to stop adding to the reserve until prices settle down. In March, even before the most recent price increases, the Senate narrowly approved an amendment to budget legislation that would temporarily halt additions to the reserve. 
 Political pressure on the administration is almost certain to increase. The Energy Information Administration reported on Monday that last week the average price for regular gasoline climbed above $2 a gallon for the first time. Crude oil prices hovered above $41 a barrel, near the record reached last week.
 But administration officials remain opposed to any change in policy, saying the Strategic Petroleum Reserve was never intended to be used to move oil prices. Administration officials said on Monday that selling reserves would have a minuscule effect on gasoline prices and that the government stockpiles were intended to cope with true emergencies rather than simply high prices.
 The Department of Energy has been building up its oil reserves since shortly after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001. The reserve has climbed from 592 million barrels in November 2001 to about 659 million barrels today. The administration goal is to reach 700 million barrels by sometime next year.
 The United States consumes about 20 million barrels of oil a day, about 12 million of them imported. 
 Industry analysts say tapping into the strategic reserve would have little influence on world supplies, but it could have a significant short-term effect.
 Douglas McIntyre, a senior oil market analyst at the Energy Information Administration, a nonpartisan statistical arm of the Department of Energy, said a ''rule of thumb'' was that an increase in supply of one million barrels a day translated into a decline in oil prices of $3 to $5 a barrel. That in turn would lead to a drop in gasoline prices of 7 to 12 cents a gallon.
 But Mr. McIntyre said the market reaction could vary greatly, both up and down from the standard estimates, depending on the amount of speculative activity in the markets and the overall conditions.
 Senate Democrats are far from one mind on the issue. Senator John F. Kerry of Massachusetts, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, has called for a temporary halt to filling the reserve, but he has not called for actually selling any of the stockpile.
 ''John Kerry believes this is a serious situation which is why he has called for a temporary halt to filling the S.P.R. and truly standing up to OPEC,'' said Phil Singer, a spokesman for Mr. Kerry. ''When is George Bush going to come up with a plan that helps these Americans cope with a gas crisis that is occurring on his watch? America is waiting.'' 
 In 2000, the Clinton administration tried to push down oil prices by lending out 30 million barrels of oil from the end of September to the end of December of that year. The results were mixed. According to Mr. McIntyre, crude oil prices dropped from about $37 a barrel to $30 in the first few days of the program. But prices bounced back to $36 shortly afterward, and then began to decline again as the nation experienced a much warmer winter than had been expected. By the end of December 2000, oil was down to about $32 a barrel.
 Oil companies are adamantly opposed to any use of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. 
 John C. Felmy, chief economist with the American Petroleum Institute, the industry trade association, said oil freed from the strategic reserve would be tiny in comparison with global supply and demand.
 ''You've got extraordinarily strong demand for petroleum, and very limited ability to expand output,'' Mr. Felmy said. 
 Thomas Bentz, a senior energy analyst at BNP Paribas Commodity Futures, said global inventories of crude oil were not particularly low. Oil prices have been pushed higher by anxiety over possible disruptions in Iraq and other exporting countries, as well as by extremely high demand for gasoline.
 American refineries are running at about 96 percent capacity, but stockpiles of gasoline are about 5.2 million barrels lower than a year ago and 8.2 million barrels below the average of the last five years.
 ''The market has built a fear premium into the price,'' Mr. Bentz said. Releasing oil from the strategic reserve might well push crude oil prices down initially, he said, but the effect might well prove temporary and it might have little immediate effect on gasoline prices.

HEADLINE: Shares Plunge 11% in India on Jitters Over Election

BYLINE: By SARITHA RAI

DATELINE: BANGALORE, India, May 17 

 BODY:
India's stock prices skidded more than 11 percent on Monday, thrown into turmoil by the confusion over the future of the country's economy under Sonia Gandhi's Congress Party and its left-leaning allies.
 In Mumbai, India's bellwether Sensex stock index, tumbled almost 17 percent, but trimmed the losses to settle at 4,505 points, its lowest close since October, and its biggest drop in 12 years. As prices crashed, trading was halted twice. 
 Since the surprising rejection of the government of Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee in elections ended last week, the ultimate shape of a ruling coalition led by the Congress Party has been unclear. 
 As the new government will need the support of India's Communist parties, the shape of its economic policy was even less clear. Some analysts said that in the current policy vacuum, the market could drop another 10 percent.
 ''It all depends on whether there is a clear economic policy spelled out by the government and endorsed by the left in the next few days,'' Sanjay Prakash, chief executive of HSBC Asset Management (India), said. Mr. Prakash manages $42 million in domestic equity funds, in addition to advising the London-based $1.9 billion HGIF India equity fund, the world's largest equity fund dedicated to India. 
 The disparate talk by the Communist parties on economic policy was the main cause for the collapse in equity prices, as investors faced up to the possibility of an unstable government and a possible U-turn in India's economic modernization.
 The market's steep fall came as markets around the world also tumbled, alarmed by expectations of higher interest rates in the United States, rising oil prices and China's efforts to cool its racing economy.
 Adrian Lim, investment manager of Asian equities at Aberdeen Asset Management Asia in Singapore, said the markets were generally nervous about the level of the new government's commitment to economic liberalization. Monday's tailspin, he said, was attributable to the socialist views expressed by allies of the Congress-led coalition, and the fast unwinding of trades financed on margin. The company manages $10 billion in the Asia-Pacific region.
 The general feeling was that the Communist parties would slow, if not reverse, the country's 13-year-old liberalization process, which had gained momentum under the Vajpayee government and had drawn the interest of foreign investors.
 ''In a market mostly driven by sentiment rather than fundamentals, we relate to the economic policies of the Congress, but not to that of the Communists,'' Mr. Prakash of HSBC Asset Management, said. The possibility of political instability loomed as the Communist parties, dominated by the Communist Party of India and Communist Party of India (Marxist), said on Monday that they would not be part of the government. 
 Instead, they said, they would support the Congress government from the outside. This would allow the parties significant influence in government, with very little accountability. They could also withdraw their support at any moment, creating a political crisis.
 Communist parties won 62 seats in the recent federal elections and have become indispensable to the Congress Party. Congress and its allies, which together won 217 seats, need the support of the Communist parties to reach a majority in the 545-member Parliament.
 The lack of cohesion even among the Communist parties bewildered market players. Some spoke of nationalization, increases in subsidies, a halt in the sale of profitable state-owned oil companies, and greater job security for government workers. 
 When trading was halted a second time, angry brokers and investors held an impromptu protest on Dalal Street, the local equivalent of Wall Street, in Mumbai, shouting ''Down with Sonia Gandhi.''
 Seeking to reassure the markets, Manmohan Singh -- a Congress Party leader, former finance minister and the chief architect of India's liberalization program -- said, ''The new government's economic policy will be pro-growth, pro-investment, pro-savings and pro-employment.'' 
 The program of the Congress and the left-leaning parties, he added, would be committed to budget discipline, curbing wasteful spending, and emphasizing agriculture and pensions.
 He added that privatization of government-owned companies would continue, provided that it was in the national interest.
 S.K. Das, chief investment officer of LIC Mutual Fund, which manages some $1.1 billion in the financial markets, said that the possible end to privatization of government-owned companies had alarmed investors unduly. ''We will not panic. We see this as a buying opportunity,'' he said. LIC Mutual Fund is a unit of India's largest insurer, the government-owned Life Insurance Corporation.
 But experts said that the upheaval in the Indian markets was temporary.
 ''Today's correction is unwarranted and a knee-jerk reaction, especially in light of the strong fundamentals on both the economic and earnings front,'' said Sivasubramanian K.N., senior vice president and portfolio manager, equities, at Franklin Templeton (India), the country's largest private fund firm. 
 Mr. Sivasubramanian said that the fundamentals of the economy remained strong and that the change in government was unlikely to derail that. He said the coming months would offer a clearer picture of the new government's policies and its ability to manage a coalition. 
 Others were not so optimistic about the short-term outlook. ''The uncertainty will continue to drive market volatility in the next few months until there is more visibility about the government's economic priorities,'' said Mr. Lim of Aberdeen Asset Management.
 ''The anticipated budget announcement would add clarity and could crystallize the government's commitment to continued market reform,'' he added.

HEADLINE: MEMO PAD

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY

 BODY:

OVERALL PASSENGER TRAFFIC RISES -- United States airlines carried 43.5 million domestic passengers in February, an increase of 9.3 percent over February 2003, according to the Department of Transportation's Bureau of Transportation Statistics. Available seat miles, which measure capacity, were up 12.4 percent in February over the year-earlier month, the agency said. Delta Air Lines carried the most domestic passengers in February, and its main hub, Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport in Atlanta, remained the nation's busiest airport, with 2.8 million passenger boardings.

SNAG ON A380 DELIVERIES -- Virgin Atlantic, which had been one of the initial customers for the Airbus super-jumbo A380 jet in 2006, put off deliveries for more than a year of the six planes it had ordered. Airbus has said it has more than 125 orders for the A380. Virgin, a unit of the Virgin Group said it delayed deliveries because not enough world airports -- including Los Angeles International -- had begun making renovations necessary to accommodate the huge double-deck plane, which will carry from 550 to more than 850 passengers, depending on how it is configured. Los Angeles is considered a vital link because the A380 will be used on many trans-Pacific flights.

BUSINESS TRAVEL SPENDING JUMPS -- Universal Air Travel Plan, the global payment network for corporate air travel, said that the volume of spending handled by its charge cards exceeded $7 billion in 2003, a 10 percent increase over 2002. Growth rates accelerated significantly starting in October 2003 and continuing into this year, with March spending exceeding all forecasts, the company said. Universal Air Travel processes direct payments to airlines from companies buying airline tickets on its charge cards. The Air Transport Association, a trade group for domestic airlines, says that domestic revenue passenger miles grew 11.9 percent in April, compared with April 2002.

SPARTAN BUT CHEAP -- EasyHotel, a London-based economy hotel group, said it would open a hotel in central London later this year offering nightly rates as low as $9 (though the average room rate will be about $52). The hotel, at 14 Lexham Gardens, will have rooms resembling economy cabins on cruise ships. Rooms will be about 90 square feet and furnished with a double bed and a toilet, shower and sink. Telephones or televisions will not be available. Rates will vary, with the cheapest rates going to those who book earliest in off-peak times. Clean sheets will be provided, but guests need to bring their own towels. EasyHotel (www.easyhotel.com) is owned by easyGroup, the parent of the low-cost airline easyJet, which said it planned to expand the budget hotel concept to other world cities. JOE SHARKEY

HEADLINE: Lucent Fined $25 Million By S.E.C. In Fraud Case

BYLINE: By KEN BELSON

 BODY:
The Securities and Exchange Commission accused Lucent Technologies and nine former and current employees yesterday of fraudulently reporting nearly $1.2 billion in revenue. The agency also accused a former executive of WinStar Communications of engaging in a fraud scheme in which Lucent recorded $125 million in software sales to WinStar. 
 The accusations, made in a civil lawsuit filed in Federal District Court in New Jersey, come after a three-year government inquiry into Lucent's inflation of its sales figures dating back to the 2000 fiscal year. 
 Lucent, the nation's largest maker of telecommunications equipment, and three of the nine employees have agreed to settle with the government without admitting or denying wrongdoing. Lucent will not have to make any additional adjustments to its earnings statements, but it will pay a $25 million fine for not cooperating with the investigation, the largest penalty ever levied against a corporation for failure to cooperate. 
 The accusation against Lucent comes after smaller fines were levied against the Bank of America and Xerox and is emblematic of the S.E.C.'s growing frustration with evasive and obstructive behavior by companies under investigation.
 ''Stiff sanctions and exposure of their conduct will serve as a reminder to companies that only genuine cooperation serves the best interest of investors,'' Paul Berger, the S.E.C.'s associate director of enforcement, said in a statement.
 Shares of Lucent declined 18 cents, or 5.5 percent, to close at $3.10 yesterday. The announcements helped drag the Nasdaq composite index down 1.45 percent to 1,876. 
 Yesterday's move against Lucent added another jolt to the embattled telecommunications industry, whose fortunes have plummeted since the technology bubble burst several years ago. Industry analysts said some of Lucent's accounting problems stemmed from pressure to show stable sales and close deals even as the boom in spending on telecommunications equipment collapsed. 
 Companies are still paying the price for their aggressive accounting. Last month, the S.E.C. opened formal investigations of accounting irregularities against Lucent's biggest rival, Nortel Networks. The company, which is based near Toronto, has since fired several top executives and cut the 2003 profits it originally reported in half.
 Nortel is also grappling with a host of class-action lawsuits brought by investors. And on May 14, a federal grand jury in Dallas, where Nortel has major operations, subpoenaed financial and other records from the company as part of a new criminal investigation.
 The growing troubles at Nortel and the conclusion of this government case against Lucent comes amid a modest turnaround this year in the industry's financial outlook. The accounting problems, however, are starting to distract investors, who have dumped shares in Nortel and its rivals. 
 ''It's a serious blow to credibility to have this ugly monster rear its head when the industry smolders,'' said Susan Kalla, a telecommunications analyst at Friedman, Billings, Ramsey in New York. ''The timing couldn't be worse.''
 The case against Lucent dates back to November 2000, when the company alerted financial regulators about revenues it improperly recorded. S.E.C. regulators ultimately found that $511 million in revenue and $91 million in pretax income were prematurely recorded in the 2000 fiscal year, which ended Sept. 30 that year. Another $637 million and $379 million in pretax income should not have been recognized at all.
 Lucent subsequently restated $679 million in sales, an act that prompted 54 class-action lawsuits by investors, who said they were intentionally misled by the company. 
 In December, Lucent settled those cases by agreeing to pay $517 million in cash and shares as compensation for shareholders, bond holders and other investors.
 In addition to improperly booking sales, Lucent employees on at least 10 occasions made illegal agreements with customers, including WinStar, which filed for bankruptcy protection in April 2001. 
 The three executives who settled with the government had worked on the WinStar account. William Plunkett, vice president for Lucent's Emerging Service Provider, will pay $110,000; Deborah Harris, who worked with Mr. Plunkett, will pay $100,000; and Vanessa Petrini, who reported to Ms. Harris, will pay a $60,000 fine and an additional $132,992 related to profits and interest on illegally booked sales.
 A Lucent spokeswoman said three of the nine executives named by the government are still working for the company, but declined to name them, leaving open the question of whether some defendants are still making accounting and management decisions at Lucent.
 The case against David Ackerman, the former WinStar executive, has not been settled.
 The settlements with Mr. Plunkett, Ms. Harris and Ms. Petrini, though, could foreshadow a coming criminal investigation. Prosecutors often try to reach agreements with midlevel employees and offer them immunity in future cases against more important executives, legal experts say.
 ''If there is a criminal case, they'll need some people to testify,'' said Bradford C. Lewis, a partner at Fenwick & West in Mountain View, Calif., who worked for seven years as an assistant United States attorney in the Eastern District of California. ''It's a typical strategy.''

HEADLINE: A Filmed Taste of Lives Changed Since the Brown Case in 1954

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
On the evening before his documentary ''With All Deliberate Speed'' opened in theaters last week, the director Peter Gilbert had the singular career pleasure of showing it at the Library of Congress before an audience that included Justice Anthony M. Kennedy of the Supreme Court and Cecilia Marshall, the widow of Justice Thurgood Marshall.
 And while Mr. Gilbert's take on the varied meanings of the Brown v. Board of Education desegregation case is one of several current documentaries on the topic, it is the only one playing in theaters nationwide.
 For Mr. Gilbert (who was the cinematographer and a producer for the acclaimed 1994 documentary ''Hoop Dreams,'' about a chase for basketball stardom), the only thing missing in Washington were his children, Leo and Fay. They were home in Chicago, taking school tests. But as Mr. Gilbert, who is white, said in a recent interview, their absence was tempered by the realization that both attend a public magnet school that has managed a strict racial balance, a legacy of the Brown decision handed down by the Supreme Court on May 17, 1954. 
 This 50th anniversary year of that decision has had the expected rush of books, articles, conversations and films about the issues explicit and implicit in Brown: race, education, class. Marshall argued the case before the court on which he later sat as the first black Supreme Court justice, starting in 1967.
 Mr. Gilbert, 46, whose many documentary credits include, ''Vietnam: Long Time Coming'' and ''Southern Tour,'' about race relations in Jackson, Miss., said he had a couple of goals when he began the film last September. He wanted to capture the lives of the mostly unknown plaintiffs in the five cases from around the country that were combined to become Brown v. Board of Education (from the case in Topeka, Kan.) when they reached the Supreme Court. He also wanted to get at the current reality of Brown's legacy.
 So (to the dislike of some critics) ''Deliberate Speed'' weaves back and forth between older people telling their stories and young people talking about their schools today. The focus is on two of the Brown cases: one in Farmville, Va., in Prince Edward County, which started with a student boycott led by 16-year-old Barbara Johns, and one in Summerton, S.C., in Clarendon County, which began with a father's request for a ''colored'' school bus so his children would not have to walk more than seven miles to school.
 Between the interviews and the archival scenes are the actors Joe Morton, Alicia Keys, Mekhi Phifer, Larenz Tate and Terry Kinney in dramatic readings. The audience in Mr. Gilbert's head was always young people.
 ''While I'm glad the film is in theaters, I look forward to it having another life when groups of schoolchildren are able to see it,'' said Mr. Gilbert, who is the film's producer and cinematographer as well as the director. He spoke in the offices of CameraPlanet, the Manhattan company that distributed his film theatrically. ''My hope is that it sparks some conversations about race.''
 The film, which takes its title from the high court's declaration in Brown that desegregation be carried out ''with all deliberate speed,'' opened on Friday in New York, Washington, Boston, Los Angeles and Chicago.
 At least two other major documentaries about the decision also use schoolchildren and contemporary stories to explore topics like busing, self-segregation, academic tracking, testing and the impact of economics.
 Stanley Nelson's ''Beyond Brown: Pursuing the Promise,'' which had its premiere on PBS last week and will be repeated this month, is a sweeping look at those issues since 1954. Mr. Nelson is an award-winning filmmaker whose 2003 documentary on the 1955 murder of Emmett Till played a role in the government's reopening of the case last week.
 ''Beyond Brown,'' includes the stories of two young black women, one from a struggling school who failed a standardized test and one who benefits academically and socially from being bused.
 And ''I Sit Where I Want: The Legacy of Brown v. Board of Education'' had its debut on Monday on the N, an MTV offshoot that bills itself as a nighttime cable network for tweens and teens. It will be repeated tomorrow. The hourlong film follows students at a racially mixed magnet school in Buffalo as they try to get their fellow students to do more racial mingling in the lunchroom and as biracial pairs spent time in each other's homes.
 That film was produced and directed by Whitney B. Dow, 42, who is white, and Marco Williams, 47, who is black. In 1998 they created Two Tone Productions, a New York-based company that makes documentaries about racial issues. Their feature-length film, ''Two Towns of Jasper,'' which examined the 1998 racially motivated murder of James Byrd Jr. in Jasper, Tex., won several awards. Mr. Byrd was chained to the back of a pickup truck and dragged down rural roads for nearly three miles until his head and right shoulder came off.
 Given a mandate by the N to do something about the Brown anniversary, the filmmakers said they decided on a project jointly with the students. Mr. Dow led the discussions with white students, Mr. Williams with the black ones. Beyond airing their grievances and observations, they had a goal of lunchroom desegregation.
 ''One of the things that caught me off-guard was how aware they were of the self-segregation, with how comfortable they were with it,'' Mr. Dow said of the ''I sit'' film. ''I guess I was expecting more politically correct blather.'' Rather, he said, when he asked the white students to explore some advantages of whiteness, they talked about how low-income whites are disadvantaged compared with blacks who benefit from affirmative action.
 Mr. Gilbert said he completed his film with feelings of both hope and anger. ''One of the most incredible things I learned from the film was here were an oppressed people who believed in the constitution more than the people in power did,'' he said.
 The deliberate slowness and political timidity of the Supreme Court in dismantling desegregation allowed a racist backlash to fester, he said, making ''all deliberate speed'' a mockery.
 He also wondered, he said, if he could have been as courageous as the people he met, who resisted laws and customs at a great price. His camera caught Howard Smith in Prince Edward Country, Va., sobbing as he told how he and his sister were shipped off to white foster parents in Baltimore because school officials shut down the entire county school system for five years rather than desegregate. Other families endured everything from cross burnings to death threats. 
 Mr. Gilbert said he was captivated by the idea that people found a cause for which they were willing to die.
 ''I ask kids today, 'What are you willing to die for?' '' Mr. Gilbert said. ''Not one kid has had an answer. From the upper middle class all the way down. White, black, everything.''

 CORRECTION:
A film review of ''With All Deliberate Speed'' on May 14 and an article in The Arts on May 19 about its director, Peter Gilbert, misstated the source of the title. The words were from the Supreme Court's order on carrying out its desegregation ruling in the Brown v. Board of Education case, not from the ruling itself. A recent e-mail message from a reader pointed out the error.

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Fall, but Building Permits Rise

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 18 

 BODY:
Starts of new housing decreased in April, but permits to build homes exceeded expectations as builders anticipated steady demand underpinned by mortgage rates still relatively low.
 A report from the Commerce Department showed on Tuesday that home builders broke ground at a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 1.969 million units last month, down 2.1 percent from an upward-revised 2.011 million in March. 
Analysts had expected housing starts at a pace of 1.99 million units. 
 ''They are a little lower than expected,'' said Richard Egelton, deputy chief economist at the Bank of Montreal, ''but they are still at pretty stratospheric levels.''
 Building permits, a sign of builder confidence, climbed to 1.999 million units in April, compared with an upward-revised pace of 1.975 million the month before. Analysts had expected permits to remain steady at some 1.95 million units. 
 The bank UBS, in an economic report, said, ''A recent rush to buy homes, telegraphed by yesterday's solid reading on the home builders survey and recent strong mortgage applications, suggests starts will stay robust near term, partly as buyers rush to avoid yet higher mortgage rates ahead.'' 
 The National Association of Home Builders said its housing index, a gauge of builder sentiment on sales and buyer traffic, registered 69 for May, unchanged from April. An index reading above 50 means that more builders see sales conditions as good than as poor. 
 Mortgage rates, which dipped near 40-year lows at the start of 2004, have risen in recent weeks as the economic rebound continues and the Federal Reserve offers stronger hints of increases to come in the benchmark short-term interest rate.

HEADLINE: Big Project Moves Forward on One-Acre Site

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
State and city officials are putting together more than $370 million in tax-exempt financing for a project in Lower Manhattan that is remarkable for the mix of uses on a single acre: an apartment tower, a business school, a dormitory, an art gallery, a hospital, a parking garage and a good-size store.
 The one-million-square-foot building, designed by Frank Gehry for Forest City Ratner Companies, would include 330,000 square feet of space for Pace University, whose main building is across Spruce Street, and a 25,000-square-foot ambulatory care unit for NYU Downtown Hospital, which stands next door on Beekman Street.
 The developers are hoping to get up to $243 million in tax-exempt Liberty Bond financing for the commercial part of the project, up to $130 million in Liberty Bond financing for the residential tower and about $10 million in tax savings for Pace, which will lease its space with an option to buy it after eight years.
 The state Liberty Development Corporation is expected today to formally declare its intent to issue the bonds for the commercial portion of the project. 
 Cobbling together such a complex financing package for such diverse users has involved tough negotiations.
 ''We clearly used the carrot and the stick in order to get this done,'' Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff said yesterday in a telephone interview.
 ''It's a very complicated deal,'' Mr. Doctoroff said, ''but it seemed to us to make such sense to have Pace and Forest City Ratner and NYU Downtown Hospital as partners. Everybody compromised.''
 A key stumbling block was a kind of paradox involving Pace and NYU Downtown. On one hand, to ensure its economic health, the hospital needed to get a good price for the parking lot on which the new tower is to be built. (One bond application form put the acquisition cost at $42 million.) But the higher the development cost, the harder it became for Pace, a nonprofit institution, to afford to be a part of the project.
 ''While the developer was open to discussions with Pace about its tenancy, it also has an alternative, high-value development strategy involving a fully residential building,'' according to a memorandum from Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, to the directors of the Liberty Development Corporation.
 ''After protracted negotiations,'' the memo continued, ''both sides had essentially walked away from the table and the developer was prepared to proceed with a residential deal. It was only significant pressure from the city that got the sides talking again.''
 What justified the effort, said Andrew M. Alper, the president of the City Economic Development Corporation, was that ''you have, in one project, an awful lot of elements that all add to the recovery of Lower Manhattan.'' That includes 600 students in the Pace dormitory, who will ''provide traffic for retailers downtown and enliven the streets.''
 Officials said the project would provide the equivalent of 1,546 full-time jobs in construction and development. They emphasized that no final actions had been taken yet on any of the applications. A similar point was made by David A. Caputo, the president of Pace, who said the deal awaited the approval of the university board.
 In addition to the dormitory, Pace would use its space to house the Lubin School of Business, other classrooms, an art gallery, the admissions office and dining areas.
 ''We see this as a major reaffirmation of our investment and commitment to Lower Manhattan and also to the business and corporate community,'' Dr. Caputo said. ''It gives a sense of an urban campus.''
 Forest City Ratner, which is the development partner of The New York Times Company in its new headquarters on Eighth Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets, has kept quiet about its downtown project during the negotiations and preliminary design work.
 James P. Stuckey, the executive vice president of Forest City Ratner, said yesterday that it is still too early even to say how tall the structure will be, since much depends on the layout of the apartment tower (estimated at 45 stories all by itself), the dormitory, the business school, the hospital unit and the plaza at the base of the building.
 The expected action by the Liberty Development Corporation today would allow the developer to begin spending money that would eventually be reimbursable from the bond financing.
 Given the involvement of Mr. Gehry, who is working for Forest City Ratner on the proposed Brooklyn arena for the Nets basketball team, Mr. Stuckey said, ''We have a lot of confidence that this building will become a postcard for Lower Manhattan.''
 He added, ''We love to do complicated projects.''

HEADLINE: Old Reflexes Hurting 2 Asian Economic Giants

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: HONG KONG, May 18 

 BODY:
The more signs China and India have given in recent weeks that they may be drifting back toward a bigger government role in the economy, the more investors have punished their stock markets. 
 Though one is a democracy and the other a one-party dictatorship, India and China have followed similar economic policy arcs over the last half-century: decades of pervasive state intervention, with mostly dismal results, and then a shift in recent years toward deregulation and free markets, with spectacular results. 
 But investors have seen unhappy reminders of old habits in both countries lately. Leftists have gained greater influence in India's national elections, threatening to slow the sale of state-owned companies. China is trying to slow its fast-growing economy with more and more severe administrative dictates. 
 ''The biggest risk in China is the latent command-economy mentality,'' said Li Hui, head of China research for Credit Lyonnais Securities Asia. 
 To be sure, stock prices around the world have been falling in recent weeks, in response to rising oil prices, worries about Iraq and the prospect of higher interest rates in the United States. But the setbacks have been especially severe in India and China, which had two of the world's best-performing stock markets last year.
 The stock market in Mumbai, formerly Bombay, which nearly doubled in value last year, fell 6 percent on Friday and 11 percent on Monday after the opposition Congress Party defeated the ruling coalition at the polls and seemed to need the support of the Communist Party to form a new government.
 But on Tuesday, the benchmark Indian market index -- anticipating a decision to yield the leadership by Sonia Gandhi, head of the Congress Party and a politician seen as willing to cut deals with leftists on economic issues -- rebounded 8.3 percent. Investors were cheered by the possibility that Manmohan Singh, a former finance minister who helped start India's shift toward less government control of the economy in 1991, could be the Congress Party's choice instead. [World Business, Page W1.]
 For Chinese stocks, the damage has been more extensive and has lasted longer. Even after rising 3.9 percent on Tuesday, the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index, made up of big state-controlled mainland companies whose shares trade in Hong Kong, was still down by more than one-quarter from its high early in April. The index more than doubled in 2003, with practically all the gains posted late in the year, as China was being hailed for its apparent transformation into an increasingly free-market powerhouse reaping huge benefits from globalization.
 To brake what many economists describe as overheating in broad sections of the economy, including real estate, steel and autos, Prime Minister Wen Jiabao promised on May 6 that the government would take forceful action. That action has turned out to be re-regulation. 
 Officials have ordered limits on bank loans to a long list of industries, from textiles to printing. They have restricted the conversion of farmland to other uses, and have even had local officials detained for pursuing industrial projects that did not get advance approval from the central government.
 But Beijing has not used the policy tools that would be more familiar in market economies, like allowing the currency to appreciate or raising interest rates.
 Many economists say that an interest rate increase could still come any day. But new figures from the National Bureau of Statistics on Tuesday suggested that the impetus for a rate increase was fading. Investment in apartment buildings, factories and other fixed assets in April was 34.7 percent higher than a year earlier, the bureau said -- an extremely rapid growth rate, yet lower than the torrid March increase of 43.5 percent.
 ''Today's data are the first sign that an overheated economy is cooling,'' Tim Condon, an economist in the Hong Kong offices of ING, wrote in a report late Tuesday. 
 Still, industrial output, bank lending and foreign investment and lending continue to barrel ahead, according to figures released late last week, while inflation rose in April to 3.8 percent -- the highest year-over-year increase for a month in seven years.
 Li Yang, a member of the Chinese central bank's monetary policy committee, warned on Monday, ''If consumer prices become uncontrollable -- that is, rising above the bearable limit of 5 percent -- China may have to raise interest rates.''
 Economists tend to worry more about China's economy these days than India's, notwithstanding the election results. Accelerating Indian economic growth over the last few years has come partly from good harvests, but also from improved productivity and greater consumer demand by the upper middle class.
 By contrast, China's economy, while benefiting from foreign investment and rising exports, has relied more on heavy investment in new factories and apartment buildings. This construction has been financed mainly by loans from state-owned banks, which have an extremely poor track record foretelling viable projects from white elephants.
 Borrowers are not making timely payments on nearly half the banks' outstanding loans, often shielded by political connections and China's very weak debt-collection laws.
 The slide in Chinese stock prices is forcing delays in the initial public offerings of a series of Chinese companies. Some of the country's biggest and most reputable enterprises sold shares last year, raising about $19 billion in equity capital, led by the China Life Insurance Company's $3.5 billion offering. 
 But by and large, Chinese companies still rely overwhelmingly on bank loans -- much more so than even in Germany, where banks are much more important in corporate finance than in the United States.
 The financial disclosure and corporate governance requirements that go with being listed on stock exchanges have forced some discipline on those Chinese companies that have gone public. The recent decline in share prices is likely to set back that process, which Fred Hu, a managing director at Goldman Sachs, said China badly needed.
 ''The biggest problem,'' Mr. Hu said, ''would be to hold back the structural reforms.''

HEADLINE: Tenant Outcry Pre-empts a Hearing on Rents in Nassau

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

DATELINE: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, N.Y., May 17 

 BODY:
If New York City's rent regulations seem problematic, consider Nassau County's system.
 Nassau's Rent Guidelines Board met here on Monday night for what was supposed to be this year's first hearing on rent rates, but it never happened.
 Instead, tenants and their two board representatives staged a walkout and threatened a boycott of future proceedings, accusing the system of favoring landlords.
 Among their complaints is that one of the designated public board members, who is supposed to be a neutral buffer between the landlord and tenant representatives, is a partner in the most prominent New York City law firm representing landlords. 
 Tenants also object that the board refuses to hold hearings in Hempstead, even though that village has half of Nassau's estimated 13,000 to 16,000 rent-regulated apartments. And they object that the board started hearings without releasing the annual report on landlord income and expenses, a basic document for calculating rents.
 ''We won't participate in a farce,'' said Michael McKee, associate director of Tenants and Neighbors, a statewide group.
 The board's chairwoman, Catherine Kirk, called the walkout unfortunate and said it had deprived the board of testimony. Another member, John A. Mastromarino, called the exodus ''pretty grotesque.''
 The hearing effectively ended when the board's two tenant members proposed postponing it until the landlord income and expense report is filed, but they were outvoted. They stood up and left, joined by about 20 tenants in the audience.
 Two speakers who stayed were Hempstead's deputy mayor and a village councilman, who expressed concern that some board members had indicated a fear of meeting in Hempstead, which is mostly black and Hispanic. Mrs. Kirk, who is white, denied that contention and said that hearings would be held there ''in another year, I am sure.''
 This year's remaining hearings, on May 26 and June 8, will be in the Nassau County Legislature's chamber in Garden City, which has no rent-regulated apartments. Mrs. Kirk said that location ''is very close to Hempstead, and it isn't a hardship to get there.''
 Mr. McKee said: ''What's really going on is that they want to discourage turnout by tenants. A lot of people in Hempstead are poor, they don't have cars, and many are working two jobs to make ends meet, so it's really unfair.''
 After the Hempstead officials sat down, the rent board adjourned the session without any discussion of rents.
 In the lobby, tenants aired their complaints. The rent boards in New York City and Westchester County provide the landlord data before their hearings, said Mr. McKee, adding, ''It's pathetic but typical that the process in Nassau is backwards.''
 Tenants objected to Robert D. Goldstein, who has served as a public board member since 1998. He is a partner at Borah Goldstein Altschuler Schwartz & Nahins, New York City's biggest landlord law firm, a role that critics say poses a conflict of interest.
 Last year Mr. Goldstein never heard the testimony on Nassau's rents because he missed all four hearings, tenant groups say. But he showed up in time to vote with the landlord members for increases of 5 percent for one-year leases and 8 percent for two years.
 Those increases far exceeded inflation and came despite growing landlord profits, with an average net operating income over expenses of about 34 percent, critics said.
 Mr. Goldstein, the only one of the nine board members who was absent on Monday, defended his record in a telephone interview. He has always acted as ''someone trying to represent the interest of the public,'' he said. His law firm has ''virtually no practice in Nassau County, certainly none I'm involved in,'' he said.
 Three decades ago, as a tenant leader from Great Neck, Mr. Goldstein said, he served as a tenant member on the board for two years. And three years ago, he said, he sponsored a measure to help elderly tenants, angering landlords, who sued and overturned it.
 Tenant groups have long agitated for Mr. Goldstein's removal, and a replacement is finally in the works. But the County Legislature and the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal have been delayed in approving the new member, so Mr. Goldstein is lingering in office
 ''That a prominent landlord attorney should be a public member is an outrage,'' said the president of the Long Beach Tenants Coalition, Robert A. Rychlowski. ''It's a travesty that it has gone on as long as it has.''

HEADLINE: Errors Cited at Adelphia Trial

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
A former vice president of the Adelphia Communications Corporation, James R. Brown, testified yesterday that the indictment of the company's founder, John J. Rigas, and two of his sons contained errors about fraud charges against the men.
 The 102-page indictment contends that Adelphia falsely claimed 5,300,517 basic cable subscribers on May 15, 2000. After reviewing documents, Mr. Brown said the actual number was 5,003,517, a number misstated in both the original indictment in September 2002, and an amended one filed nine months later. 
 ''Would you agree that the superseding indictment overstates the number of subscribers by approximately 297,000?'' Andrew J. Levander, a lawyer for Michael J. Rigas, asked Mr. Brown during his 10th day of testimony in Federal District Court in New York. Mr. Brown confirmed the errors in the 133rd paragraph of a 214-paragraph indictment.
 Mr. Levander asked about the differences during cross-examination to try to raise doubt about the government's case.
 Mr. Brown is testifying against John Rigas; two of his sons, Michael and Timothy; and a fourth man, Michael C. Mulcahey. All four are charged with bank fraud, securities fraud and conspiracy in connection with the collapse of Adelphia.
 Mr. Brown, who pleaded guilty to fraud and conspiracy charges, is cooperating with prosecutors as part of a plea bargain. 
 The Rigases' indictment also misstated when Adelphia falsely claimed subscribers in Venezuela, Mr. Brown testified. The indictment contends that the inflation first occurred in the first quarter of 2000. Mr. Brown said the correct date was the third quarter.
 During cross-examination last week by Paul R. Grand, a lawyer for Timothy J. Rigas, Mr. Brown said prosecutors made another mistake in a transcript of a tape recording of a May 16, 2000, conference call with analysts. Mr. Brown said that Timothy Rigas, the former chief financial officer, falsely said the company upgraded about 60 percent of its cable lines to send and receive data.
 Mr. Grand played a tape of the call, and Mr. Brown said that he, not Timothy Rigas, made the false claim.
 ''That's what the tape indicates,'' Mr. Brown said last week. ''I was relying on the transcript before.''

HEADLINE: Suburban Sprawl? Study Says Trend Became History in 90's

BYLINE: By LAURA MANSNERUS

 BODY:
A half-century of suburbanization paused in the late 1990's, even as public concern about suburban sprawl grew, according to a report on economic and demographic trends in 31 counties in and around New York City.
 The area's suburban ring continued to gain residents and jobs, but its core urban areas gained in those areas too, at nearly identical rates, reversing a pattern that began in 1945, the study found. It was written by two researchers at Rutgers, James W. Hughes and Joseph J. Seneca, and will be released today. 
 ''I think there really is a fundamental shift going on,'' Dr. Hughes, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, said in an interview, ''and the patterns of the last 50 years really are history.''
 The data match the public mood of recent years, he added: ''After 50 years of suburban growth, the psychology was, 'We don't want any more.''' 
 Development throughout the region accelerated in the 1990's, a decade in which the population increased by 1.8 million. In the preceding 21 years, it had grown by just 306,000.
 But Dr. Hughes and Dr. Seneca, a professor at the Bloustein school, found that much of that development was in the ''urban core,'' the five boroughs of New York City, and Hudson, Essex and Union Counties in New Jersey. A critical measure of that shift, Dr. Hughes said, is the distribution of new housing. The core counties' share of new building permits had declined to 15.7 percent in 1994; it grew to 39 percent in 2002. The core area matched the other 23 counties in population growth starting in 1990, Dr. Hughes said, and employment growth in the core caught up in the late 1990's, for the first time since World War II.
 Dr. Hughes, a demographer, and Professor Seneca, an economist, attributed the trends in part to traffic constraints in the suburbs and a shortage of land for development, especially as open-space preservation programs expanded. 
 They also found that housing demand was shifting away from single-family suburban development, and would continue to do so. 
 ''We get empty-nesters who were rattling around in their McMansions,'' Dr. Hughes said, while ''children of the baby boomers are the second great-growth sector. Both of these groups are not single-family-home-centric.''
 A third group, immigrants, favored urban housing, he said, which had fed higher-than-expected growth in the urban areas of northeastern New Jersey during the 1990's.

PERSON: Henry J. Everett

HEADLINE: Henry J. Everett, 78, Investor; Led Philanthropic Foundation

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Henry J. Everett, a New York investment manager, supporter of many Jewish, educational and cultural institutions and namesake of the acclaimed Everett Children's Adventure Garden in the Bronx, died on Saturday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 78 and lived on the Upper East Side.
 The cause was cancer, his family said. 
 Mr. Everett was the founder and longtime president of Lexington Associates, an investment partnership. For as many years, he also was in a philanthropic partnership with his wife, Edith. Their foundation, established in 1957, annually makes scores of donations ranging from seed money to million-dollar grants.
 The Everett Children's Adventure Garden, a 12-acre preserve, opened at the New York Botanical Garden in 1998, meandering past a marshy pond across a bridge into the city's oldest surviving forest. It cost $9 million to build and was hailed by the National Science Foundation as the most ambitious children's education project of its kind.
 Mr. Everett also established a Public Service Internship Program that in 15 years has placed about 2,000 college students in public service agencies that provide them with a summer's worth of job experience.
 Mr. Everett was a supporter of the national Teach for America corps and sat on the board of Hillel, the Foundation for Jewish Campus Life. He was an officer or board member of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, the American Jewish Committee and the UJA-Federation of New York.
 Mr. Everett and his wife founded the Everett Comprehensive School in Hatzor, Israel, and continued to back the economic development of that town. He also benefited social and educational projects for Israel's minority Druse population.
 He was on the President's Council of National Public Radio, and he and his wife were also ardent supporters of the antismoking movement.
 Henry Everett was born to immigrant parents in the Bronx and raised in Brooklyn. He began studying economics at Columbia but served with the Army combat engineers in the Philippines before graduating Phi Beta Kappa in 1947.
 Two years later, he received a master's degree in finance at the Columbia School of Business and went to work for Abraham & Straus department stores. Doing market research he began to invest in securities and to advise friends about the ways of Wall Street.
 With the help of Edith, who got her broker's license, he was able to turn securities management into a profitable venture. He quit Abraham & Straus and in the early 1970's formed Lexington Associates. He retired as president in the mid-1990's, but remained active in business until 2002.
 Besides the former Edith Brenner, his wife of 54 years, he is survived by a son, David F., of Larchmont, N.Y.; a daughter, Carolyn, of Manhattan; a sister, Roslyn Mandelbaum, of Delray Beach, Fla.; and three grandchildren.
