HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:

A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums, children under 12 and members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

''ARCADIA AND METROPOLIS: MASTERWORKS OF GERMAN EXPRESSIONISM FROM THE NATIONALGALERIE BERLIN,'' Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200, through June 7. In 1937 the Nazis seized a large collection of Expressionist works from the Kronprinzen Palace in Berlin, Germany's first museum of contemporary art. But this branch of Nationalgalerie Berlin has made great strides in restoring what was the heart of its collection. This show of 40 works by Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Karl Schmidt-Rottluff, Emil Nolde, Max Beckmann, George Grosz, Otto Dix, Hannah Hoch, Paula Modersohn-Becker and others touches on the history of German modern art -- Expressionism, Dadaism, Neue Sachlichkeit -- from around 1910 through the post-World War I period. Its title is drawn from the early preference of the Expressionists for rural places versus their later attraction to the city. Satirical thrusts at the failures of the Weimar Republic by Hoch, Dix and Grosz are also standouts. Hours: Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7 for students and 65+ (Grace Glueck).

* ''THE ART DECO BOOKBINDINGS OF PIERRE LEGRAIN AND ROSE ADLER,'' New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street, (212) 869-8089, through June 12. The achievement of two French bookbinders is showcased in this sumptuous exhibition of 45 hand-bound rare editions and manuscripts of major French writers from Stendhal to Breton, commissioned by the couturier, collector and philanthropist Jacques Doucet. Only a few have been exhibited before. Their extraordinary exteriors are usually treated as a single flat surface and decorated with bold geometric designs, accented with crocodile, lizard, snakeskin, metal and gemstone. Legrain and Adler are credited with modernizing bookbinding and the show leaves little doubt that they did. Hours: Tuesdays and Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 7:30 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free (Roberta Smith).

* ''BYZANTIUM: FAITH AND POWER (1261-1557),'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710, through July 4. This vast and humblingly beautiful show about the waning centuries of the Byzantine empire reminds us that political decay does does not necessarily mean artistic decline. Full of amazing exotica -- manuscripts, miniature mosaics, textiles, drawings, paintings -- the exhibition ends with a room of great Northern Renaissance art indebted to icons that proves Byzantium's continued reach. People who are not Eastern Orthodox believers can enjoy the earthly pleasures of aesthetic spectacle linked with historical enlightenment. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 65+, $7 (Michael Kimmelman).

* ''AN ENDURING VISION: 17th- TO 20TH-CENTURY JAPANESE PAINTING FROM THE GITTER-YELEN COLLECTION,'' Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155, through June 20. Six schools of Japanese art that flourished during the Edo period (1615-1868) and on into the 20th century -- Nanga, Zenga, Rinpa, Maruyama-Shijo, Ukiyo-e and the Eccentrics -- are celebrated with about 75 examples from an outstanding private collection. With screens, hanging scrolls, albums and fans depicting flora and fauna, the forces of nature, abstract mountainscapes, genre scenes and calligraphy, done by some of the era's best artists, the show provides a rich acquaintance with four centuries of Japanese art. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; students and 65+, $3 (Glueck).

* ''FASHIONING FICTION IN PHOTOGRAPHY SINCE 1990,'' Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 33rd Road and Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9600, through June 28. With its first exhibition of fashion photography, the Modern dips a toe into a very large body of water, and dithers. The works by 13 artists and fashion photographers, including Cindy Sherman, Nan Goldin, Phillip-Lorca diCorcia and Cedric Buchet, focuses on the recent uses of narrative in both magazine features and advertising. How recent this development is could be debated, but mainly the Modern seems determined to make everything look like appropriation art. This seems unnecessary in a museum known for showing all kinds of everyday design objects. The show sticks too closely to the mainstream fashion press, which keeps it too superficial, too polite and in some ways misleading. Largely missing are the field's raunchy underbelly and cheap thrills: the intimations of heroin chic, grunge, homoeroticism and teenage sex that can make perusing a fashion magazine feel like a vaguely subversive act. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays to 7:45 p.m. Admission: $12; $8.50 for students and 65+ (Smith).

* ''GUSTAV KLUTSIS AND VALENTINA KULAGINA: PHOTOGRAPHY AND MONTAGE AFTER CONSTRUCTIVISM'' AND ''WAR IN IRAQ: THE COORDINATES OF CONFLICT, PHOTOGRAPHS BY VII,'' International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000, through May 30. Provocatively buttressed by two smaller shows, these imposing exhibitions dovetail into a chillingly informative examination of the roles of photography in art, history and science. The political, the personal and the formal alternate energetically in the first exhibition in this country devoted to Klutsis and Kulagina, who were married, and is primarily the tale of an artist whose striking photomontage posters helped establish the graphic look of the young Soviet Union, until Stalin had him assassinated. ''War in Iraq'' makes manifest the kinds of events that swirled around but rarely registered within the work of Klutsis or Kulagina. Starting with the ruins at ground zero, 53 images by nine intrepid photojournalists associated with the agency VII record the havoc that war, violence, dictatorial regimes and fanatical faith have wrought in our own time. Hours and admission: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 62+, $7 (Smith).

''THE 179TH ANNUAL,'' National Academy of Design Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880, through June 20. This year's nonmember invitational version of its annual exhibition continues a praiseworthy trend toward greater openness to the new. It includes known nonconservatives like Tara Donovan, Polly Apfelbaum, Barnaby Furnas, Jessica Stockholder, Mel Kendrick, Ida Applebroog, Whitfield Lovell and Joel Shapiro. Also notable are Pier Consagra's zany, faux-Rococo ink drawing of a sleeping bumpkin; Laurie Fendrich's glossy, richly colored update of Constructivist painting; Robert Taplin's double sculptural portrait of a seated woman -- clothed and unclothed -- finely made of painted concrete; and Barbara Takenaga's cosmic abstract painting made from countless little dots. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; students and 65+, $5 (Ken Johnson).

''THE PIERRE AND MARIA-GAETANA MATISSE COLLECTION,'' Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710), through June 26, 2005 in three installments. This heterogeneous array of paintings, sculptures and works on paper was once owned by the Manhattan-based art dealer Pierre Matisse (1900-1989) and his wife, Maria-Gaetana (1943-2001). Most of the material came to the Met after Mrs. Matisse's death. It includes sexy paintings by Balthus, Magritte and Wifredo Lam, batty ones by Jean Dubuffet, and a feminist icon in a self-portrait by Leonora Carrington. A selection of the rich, calm, pleasurable art of Henri Matisse, Pierre's father, takes pride of place. Hours and admission: See above (Holland Cotter).

* ''WHERE GODS AND MORTALS MEET: CONTINUITY AND RENEWAL IN URHOBO ART,'' Museum for African Art, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700, through Aug. 16. This engrossing show documents aspects of a so-called traditional African art as it existed in the recent past, and as it survives in a 21st-century world. Africa in this case means a society called the Urhobo of the Niger Delta, and the art ranges from spectacular larger than life-size figures of ancestor spirits to carvings of grotesque beasts with gaping, saber-toothed mouths, images meant to both encourage and control male aggression. Although some sculptures are now rarely produced in their original forms, they are in the paintings and prints of Bruce Onobrakpeya, a contemporary Delta-born artist of international stature, in whose art Urhobo traditions live on. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 to 5 p.m. Admission: $6; students and 65+, $3 (Cotter)

* WHITNEY BIENNIAL, Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676, through May 30. Easily the best biennial in a long time. The spirit is upbeat and ingratiating -- almost polite -- on the surface at least, with a utopian streak and a youth-heavy emphasis on gloss and craft. There's plenty of painting and drawing, ratifying the much-hyped trend, and multigenerational work, stressing ecstatic engagement and meticulousness. But the real story is the stress on the handmade in general, on materiality in whatever medium -- a change from the politics-heavy, slacker installations of recent years. The cross-generational dialogue is an interesting subtext. Among the younger set utopia does not mean 1960's-style radicalism; it implies something unattainable, except perhaps in a hand-me-down form, and therefore smaller and inherently poignant. Look for a few standout works from artists both younger and older, including Yayoi Kusama, Alec Soth, Catherine Opie, Julie Mehretu, Jim Hodges, Eve Sussman, Raymond Pettibon, Slater Bradley, Robert Mangold and Stan Brakhage, who died last year. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; students and 62+, $9.50 (Kimmelman).

* ''FRED WILSON, OBJECTS AND INSTALLATIONS: 1979-2000,'' Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500, through July 4. Mr. Wilson, who represented the United States at the 2003 Venice Biennale, made his reputation with conceptually pointed, technically polished and visually engaging installations and objects that focused on excavating American racial history and illustrating the exclusionary power of cultural institutions shaped by social, economic and ideological domination. Elements of his subversive museum projects appear in this traveling show, along with sculptures and a fine, short new film. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; students and 62+, $3; children under 12, $1 (Cotter).

Galleries: Uptown

* ''GARDEN IN DELFT: WILLEM DE KOONING LANDSCAPES 1928-1988,'' Mitchell-Innes & Nash, 1018 Madison Avenue, near 78th Street, (212) 744-7400, through June 26. For the centennial of Willem de Kooning's birth, this exhibition of 14 canvases represents a jubilant skip through his long career, with emphasis on his relationship to landscape. Never mind that the suggestion of abstracted still lifes sometimes seems equally strong, especially in two unfamiliar canvases from the late 1930's. A third painting, titled ''Still Life'' and dated circa 1929, may well be the earliest de Kooning painting most of us have ever seen. Its crisp shapes and deep primary colors suggest the influence of Joseph Stella and look forward to David Hockney. A second de Kooning tribute, at the Richard Gray Gallery upstairs through May 29, features four paintings from the 1940's and 50's that lean toward, or land in, the realm of figuration (Smith).

* JEFF KOONS, ''Highlights of 25 Years,'' C&M Arts, 45 East 78th Street, (212) 861-0020, through June 5. This excellent 27-piece survey touches on all phases of Mr. Koons's career, including greatest hits like the basketballs mysteriously hovering in aquarium tanks; the Mylar ''Rabbit'' balloon cast in shiny stainless steel; and the sexy blonde embracing the Pink Panther in glazed ceramic. The climax of the show is the 10-foot-tall ''Balloon Dog.'' Made of stainless steel and coated in coppery translucent orange, it is a breathtaking symbol of the inflationary euphoria and anxiety of our times (Johnson).

MARKUS LUPERTZ, ''About the Three Graces,'' Michael Werner, 4 East 77th Street, (212) 988-1623, through May 28. Mr. Lupertz, usually mentioned along with Georg Baselitz, Sigmar Polke and Anselm Kiefer as a German Neo-Expressionist star of the 1980's, here presents four massive heads cast in bronze. Tinted in primary colors, these boulderlike representations of the Three Graces, Hera, Venus and Athene, plus one of Paris, look as if they were gouged out of the earth and pummeled into shape by an impatient giant (Johnson)

FRANK STELLA, ''Exotic Birds,'' Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 76th Street, (212) 744-2313, through June 5. Looking at Mr. Stella's three big, splashily painted reliefs from a 1976 series, it is easy to forget how shockingly flamboyant they seemed in their day. Now, with their curvy, tilting forms cut from honeycomb-core aluminum panels, and neatly puzzled together within wide slanting frames, they seem prettily demure compared to what has happened since in painting as well as in sculpture (Johnson).

''WEEGEE'S STORY,'' Ubu, 416 East 59th Street, (212) 753-4444, through July 23. Wielding his 4x5 Speed Graphic with a master's touch, the New York tabloid photographer Weegee probably shot more murders and fires during his heyday, the 1930's and 40's, than anyone in the business. But his passion for the city also drew him to its many other photo opportunities: the strivers and the homeless, festivities and freaks, politicians and celebrities, posh avenues and mean streets. This show of 220 Weegee vintage photographs, culled from a collection assembled over a 30-year period by the Berlin dealer Hendrik Berinson, reveals his remarkable range (Glueck).

Galleries: 57th Street

* DAISY YOUNGBLOOD, McKee, 745 Fifth Avenue, (212) 688-5951, through May 29. Ms. Youngblood, who is in her late 50's and lives in Costa Rica, won a MacArthur award last year for her exquisitely sensitive, usually small ceramic sculptures of animals and human spiritual gurus. Here are 18 works dating from 1975 to 2003 in which the interest is mainly in the magical tension between the raw clay and the lifelike, psychologically evocative forms and gestures of animal and human bodies (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

LOUISE BELCOURT, ''Wriggling Philosophical Life,'' Jeff Bailey, 511 West 25th Street, (212) 989-0156, through May 29. Ms. Belcourt paints lovable, extremely simplified, sharply contoured pictures of what look like sunlit monumentalized sofa cushions under powder blue skies. Actually they are images of garden hedges in a small northern Quebec town where she grew up. With their attractively glossy, brush-textured surfaces they adroitly juggle the influences of Color Field painting, Pop and Surrealism (Johnson).

HANS BENDA, ''Kissing the Ground,'' M. Y. Art Prospects, 547 West 27th Street, (212) 268-7132, through May 29. Women and landscapes get equal time in this German artist's small, meticulously painted oils, and sometimes they share one composition. The young women, mainly Asian and very today, are unabashedly erotic; the landscapes not at all. In one fetching scene an innocent-looking young thing leans casually against the stone balustrade of a serious architectural balcony, wearing a loosely laced black corset and nothing else. Behind her is a North German Renaissance view of a blue sky with wisps of cloud and a stand of green foliage. As a play on Old Master painting it's amusing, but it's the quality of his painting more than his subject matter that makes Mr. Benda's work viable (Glueck).

* WILLEM DE KOONING, ''A Centennial Celebration,'' Gagosian, 555 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 941-1111, through June 19. This beautifully installed 40-work survey begins with several previously unexhibited late ''ribbon'' paintings with their wafting, tangling strands of color that intimate both landscapes and still lifes but are, above all, abstract. The presentation seems to argue that de Kooning, like his younger colleague Philip Guston, would still have ample art historical stature had he made no other paintings than these, produced during the decade before he descended into Alzheimer's disease. But the show then backtracks through most of the artist's development, making the counter argument by demonstrating the many divergent and crisscrossing paths he took to reach his final distillation (Smith).

DONALD JUDD, ''Single Stacks 1964-69,'' Van de Weghe, 521 West 23rd Street, (212) 929-6633, through May 28. The wall-mounted boxes featured here look like units from Judd's vertical ladderlike works. Different ones are made of shiny copper, stainless steel or galvanized steel; some have plexiglass panels casting colored light on the walls below. The installation is elegant and funereal: the sculptures are like containers for the ashes of Modernism. Or they might be Pandora's boxes, from which the demonic energies of pluralism would soon emerge (Johnson).

* CLAES OLDENBURG AND COOSJE VAN BRUGGEN, ''Images a la Carte,'' Paula Cooper, 534 West 21st Street, (212) 255-1105, through July 2. Made mostly on blue-lined notebook pages the size of index cards, using pencil, ink and watercolor, these wonderfully lively and keenly observed drawings depict shrimp cocktails, crabcakes, salads, sandwiches, a banana split, tarts, cheese cakes and other elaborate restaurant fare, interspersed with simpler items like a lemon slice, an apple core and a piece of cornbread. Mr. Oldenburg drew them; his longtime partner, Ms. van Bruggen, contributed ideas (Johnson).

* WILLIAM SCOTT, Denise Bibro, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 647-7030, through June 5. Pots, dishes, fruits, vases and other domestic shapes form the basis for much of this Scottish-born painter's imagery, magically reduced to lyrical, luminous ghosts of themselves. Scott, a figure of some importance in postwar British art, was well known in New York, too. This small but engrossing show progresses from 1954 to 1977, and in his spare, sensual paintings shape, space and color play beautifully together (Glueck).

Galleries: SoHo

''DOGS + CATS,'' American Primitive, 594 Broadway, near Houston Street, (212) 966-1530, through June 12. This lively exhibition includes more than 60 feline or canine representations in two or three dimensions. Some are by self-taught artists. A big colorful painting by Jean Metcalf has cats and dogs in it but features a formal parade of rats carrying wounded birds on stretchers. Many are by unknown craftsmen, like the smoothly carved wooden head of a boxer with brown glass eyes and the functional dog-shaped bench in the form of a wooden slab with branches that have been turned into legs (Johnson).

JOHN KESSLER, ''Global Village Idiot,'' Deitch Projects, 76 Grand Street, (212) 343-7300, through June 5. Mr. Kessler's Rube Goldberg-style contraptions incorporating computers, video equipment, photographs, electric lights and motors reflect on terrorism, airplane safety, fashion, pornography and media saturation. Their ingenious workings are absorbing to study, but unlike the beautifully made mechanized sculptures for which he became known in the 1980's and 90's, these have a raw, unfinished look, as if they had been built in the secret basement workshop of an angry and paranoid electrical engineer (Johnson).

LEONARD KOSCIANSKI, OK Harris, 383 West Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 431-3600, through May 29. For two decades Mr. Koscianski has been painting dreamy, slightly cartoonish, Magic Realist pictures of dogs, boars, hawks and other wild animals in violent Darwinian action. This show finds him in top form. It also includes glowing images of butterflies and tropical flowers that radiate a lush erotic heat (Johnson).

MARTIN PARR, ''Think of England,'' Janet Borden, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 431-0166, through May 28. You may have to be English to get very excited about this influential, controversial and popular English photographer of everyday life. He has a satiric novelist's eye for sociologically telling details, but what is most compelling in the large prints here is the shrill color, which imparts a repulsive artificiality to his images of formally garbed people at the races or tackily outfitted people at garden parties (Johnson).

LAMAR PETERSON, ''Milk and Cookies,'' Deitch Projects, 26 Wooster Street, (212) 343-7300, through June 5. The basic ingredients of Mr. Peterson's paintings seem friendly enough: tropical vacation spots, cute pets, quality family time. So does the tasty, candy-colored cartoon-realist style he has couched them in. But something -- maybe everything -- is wrong in this inorganically Disneyesque world, populated exclusively by African-Americans and robots. The racial dimension stands out at first, but the stereotypes he deals with are those of middle-class culture at large, one glutted on fantasies of perfection and excess (Cotter).

HOWARDENA PINDELL, ''Works on Paper 1968-2004,'' Sragow, 73 Spring Street, (212) 219-1793, through June 5. Ms. Pindell belongs to an understudied generation of African-American artists who were working with abstract painting and sculpture in the 1960's and 70's. The earliest drawings in this jewel-like show are composed of sequences of words and numbers arranged in patterns on graph paper, and suggest roots in postminimalism. Later she made collages of small circles, hand-punched from sheets of blank or printed paper. In her recent three-dimensional prints, the dots are suspended in clusters on grids made of threads, and the early words and numbers become the names and coordinates of constellations (Cotter).

GERHARD RICHTER, ''Two Sculptures for a Room by Palermo,'' Peter Freeman, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 966-5154, through June 26. Here is one of the very few sculptures made by Mr. Richter, the immensely influential German painter, during his career. It consists of two plaster heads cast from life, slathered in gray paint and mounted on pedestals. One head is Mr. Richter's; the other, his fellow German painter Blinky Palermo. Facing each other with closed eyes, in a gallery that is empty but for a small study version in a shadow box on the wall, the faux classical sculptures create an ambience of dry existential ennui (Johnson).

T. L. SOLIEN, ''Hollow,'' Luise Ross, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 343-2161, through June 5. If you were around in the early 80's you may remember Mr. Solien's intriguingly quirky paintings from the 1983 Whitney Biennial. His last show in New York was 14 years ago, so it is good to see that he is still making beguiling paintings while living in Wisconsin. Mixing abstraction, appropriated cartoons, and illustrations and images of homey, old-time interiors, the paintings create a haunting narrative blend of the domestic and the hallucinatory (Johnson).

Other Galleries

''CONCRETE REALITIES,'' ''The Art of Carmen Herrera, Fanny Sanin and Mira Schendel,'' Latin Collector, 153 Hudson Street, TriBeCa, (212) 334-7813, through May 29. This crisp show picks up a thread of geometric abstraction in 20th-century Latin America art, and follows it in the work of three women who have made significant constributions to its history. Ms. Herrera, born in Cuba, is represented by big, bold, wittily shaped forms. Ms. Sanin's paintings of intersecting planes in warm colors suggest architecture and textile designs. Ms. Schendel's work actually looks like woven fabric, the geometry slightly off-kilter, the edges uneven and soft. It offers yet another reason to consider geometric abstraction one the great experimental inventions of modern art (Cotter).

''THE DEVONSHIRE INHERITANCE: FIVE CENTURIES OF COLLECTING AT CHATSWORTH,'' Bard Graduate Center, 18 West 86th Street, (212) 501-3000, through June 20. The stately English country home Chatsworth has been occupied since its construction in 1552 by the Cavendish family, headed by a long succession of dukes and duchesses of Devonshire. They have enriched it with notable collections of fine and decorative arts, an awesome library of books and manuscripts, scientific instruments, silver, furniture and needlework. A glimpse of these treasures is provided by this show, which has works by Rembrandt, Raphael, Titian, Durer and Lucian Freud; books and drawings by Andrea Palladio; a spectacular jewelry ensemble worn at the coronation of Czar Alexander II and much else to light up the eyes of the most jaded connoisseur. The next step is a visit to Chatsworth itself, still a private home for the Cavendishes but very much open to the public (Glueck).

''TACTICAL ACTION,'' Gigantic Artspace, 59 Franklin Street, TriBeCa, (212) 226-6762, through June 10. This lively but crowded and unfocused exhibition is designed to promote leftish dissidence. Highlights include scenes of the war in Iraq, drawn on location by Steve Mumford; clever anticorporate lenticular photographs by David Byrne and Danielle Spencer; David Krippendorff's noirish video about the eroticism of hate; Michele Pred's American flag sculpture, made from pen knives confiscated at airports; and a mock prison visitors' booth, with a soundtrack about teenage gang violence, by Dread Scott (Johnson).

Last Chance

MIN KIM, ATM Gallery, 170 Avenue B, near 10th Street, East Village, (212) 375-0349, through Sunday. Ms. Kim's finely made paint-and-ink work amounts to a a kind of child's vision of Eden. A nude, doe-eyed prepubescent girl meets a boy, almost her twin, in a garden dominated by a glitter-producing tree; their story of Paradise Found comes to an ambiguous conclusion in a Chinese-style landscape overhung with tangle of snaking black lines. Ms. Kim's application of cartoon-style sweetness to an adult-style morality tale is common in new art and can easily be arch or sappy. She makes it work by presenting innocence more or less straight: threatened from without, unblemished from within (Cotter).

* ''OCEAN FLOWERS: IMPRESSIONS FROM NATURE,'' Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2166, through tomorrow. Dense with ethereal images and silhouettes of seaweed, this unusual exhibition shows how the needs of Victorian botanists, book publishers and inspired amateurs pushed traditional drawing and printmaking into the realm of photography without so much as touching a lens. The driving force was the need to get the wonders of nature down on paper, one way or another. Those ways run riot here and provide a startlingly revised view of the mongrel hands-on origins of the age of mechanical reproduction (Smith).

HEADLINE: Extra $150 Million Is Found to Pay for Housing for the Poor

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN

 BODY:
The nation's top housing official told Congress yesterday that the federal government had unearthed an extra $150 million to help housing agencies absorb cuts to the government's main housing program for poor Americans.
 Alphonso Jackson, secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, told the House Financial Services Committee that the money would be divided among 525 agencies, or about one-fifth of those that participate in what is popularly known as the Section 8 voucher program. But it was not immediately clear from either HUD or some of the agencies that stood to be the most affected, especially in New York City, how the money would be divided and whether the $150 million would cover the projected shortfall. 
 The announcement represents an olive branch on HUD's part in the face of mounting pressure after a regulatory change one month ago that Bush administration officials had said would help to control spiraling housing costs, but critics said would gut Section 8.
 In the past, the federal government paid the full cost of the 1.9 million rent vouchers given to poor tenants nationwide to help them pay for housing. But in the last three years, the Section 8 budget nationwide has surged 27 percent. So on April 22, HUD told housing agencies that, for the current fiscal year, it would pay the cost of a voucher only as of last August, plus an inflation adjustment.
 That calculation, according to housing agencies, threatened to penalize places like New York, where the cost of providing vouchers has climbed faster than inflation. New York officials estimated that the change could lead to a shortfall of at least $55.5 million, and perhaps force them to freeze the number of vouchers, demand more money from tenants or even evict tenants because of inadequate financing.
 Over all, housing agencies stood to lose at least $270 million under the regulatory change, said John Bohm, director of legislative programs for the National Association of Housing and Redevelopment Officials.
 But in testimony yesterday, Mr. Jackson said HUD would use $150 million that was left over from its 2003 budget. 
 ''These steps should alleviate the funding challenges some public housing authorities were anticipating when HUD recently adopted Congressionally mandated formula changes to Section 8 funding,'' he said. ''We will continue to work hand-in-hand with the public housing authorities to apply the funding cap in the fairest manner possible.''
 Still, initial reaction was cautious, or even dubious, something that was not surprising given the frequent clashes between housing groups and the Bush administration.
 Howard Marder, a spokesman for the New York City Housing Authority, said that while the city did not have any information yet as to whether New York's share would compensate for its shortfall, ''we're pleased the secretary realized that there is a problem.''
 But Barbara Sard, director of housing policy for the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal Washington research group, said the additional funds, while welcome, constituted money that was already due hundreds of agencies that were simply waiting to be reimbursed.
 And Kay Gibbs, the Democratic spokeswoman for the House Financial Services Committee, suggested that HUD's announcement might have been a matter of too little, too late, since some agencies had either begun to reduce payments to landlords, or in at least one case, to evict tenants.
 ''A number of housing authorities have already taken action that can't be undone,'' Ms. Gibbs said. ''Irreparable harm has been done, and has shaken the confidence of this program.''

HEADLINE: OPEC Offers Little Hope On Fuel Prices

BYLINE: By HEATHER TIMMONS

DATELINE: LONDON, May 20 

 BODY:
The president of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said Thursday that there was little the group could do to lower fuel prices anytime soon, because OPEC's oil production quotas were not the main problem. His remarks contradicted statements last week by Saudi Arabia, the cartel's leading producer, calling for increases in the quotas to ease price pressures. 
 Purnomo Yusgiantoro, who is both the cartel's president and the energy minister of Indonesia, said that the recent sharp rise in retail prices for gasoline and other fuels was ''due to factors beyond OPEC's scope.'' In a meeting with reporters Thursday morning, Mr. Purnomo said that speculation, geopolitics and structural problems in the United States gasoline market were to blame for the run-up in pump prices in America. 
 Even so, he said, representatives of OPEC members will meet informally this weekend at an oil industry conference in Amsterdam to consider Saudi Arabia's proposals for raising production quotas by 1.5 million barrels a day.
 Analysts said such a step would be largely symbolic, since almost all the cartel's members were already exceeding their quotas and pumping as much oil as they could.
 ''The price today is a high price, and we want it to be lower,'' Mr. Purnomo said in an interview Thursday afternoon at the Indonesian Embassy in London. But it would be very difficult for OPEC to overcome high prices by itself, he said, because simply pumping more crude would not address shortages of refinery capacity and other ''downstream'' bottlenecks and problems. 
 Fuel prices are becoming a more significant political issue in the United States, with pressure mounting on the Bush administration to act, by tapping the strategic petroleum reserve or by getting OPEC to produce more oil. Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham, who was also in London on Thursday, told reporters that he planned to discuss ways of cooling prices with OPEC members at the Amsterdam meeting, but declined to give specifics.
 On Thursday, seven state attorneys general sent a letter to President Bush, asking him to urge Attorney General John Ashcroft to join them in investigating whether oil and gas companies and OPEC are colluding to drive up prices. 
 ''We're asking the federal government to prove that it won't be a prisoner of energy interests in this country or worldwide,'' said Richard Blumenthal, the Connecticut attorney general, during a conference call with reporters. 
 Investigations into possible antitrust violations have often been conducted in the past when oil prices rose, but they have generally found little if any evidence of wrongdoing. ''Just because we have not found it does not mean it's not happening,'' said Bill Lockyer, the California attorney general, during the call. 
 The 11 members of OPEC produce about one-third of the world's oil supply. Iraq is a member, but it has not been included in quota agreements since it invaded Kuwait in 1990. Policy makers who had hoped that production in Iraq would revive and help bring down world prices have so far been disappointed. Though sanctions on Iraq were lifted after the United States-led invasion in March, persistent sabotage has held down the amount of oil the country has been able to ship.
 At the root of the global problem, Mr. Purnomo said, is global demand for oil that is far outrunning forecasts. ''Everyone got it wrong,'' he said, adding that OPEC was awaiting the results of a study about the effects of oil prices ranging up to $34 a barrel over the long term, rather than the range of $22 to $28 a barrel the cartel had assumed before. The benchmark grade of light, sweet crude for June delivery closed at $40.92 a barrel in New York, down 58 cents from Wednesday's close. 
 Oil experts said Mr. Purnomo's assessment of the causes of high oil prices and OPEC's ability to affect them were a mixture of political posturing and fact. 
 ''He's half right,'' said Fareed Mohamedi, chief economist for PFC Energy, a Washington-based consulting firm. Strong demand for crude oil and gasoline have helped drive prices up, Mr. Mohamedi said, but ''it's also the issue that OPEC and especially Saudi Arabia have not fully opened up the taps.'' 
 Other experts said that only Saudi Arabia still had enough idle production capacity to affect global oil prices and that an increase in quotas for the rest of OPEC was meaningless. Already, the group as a whole is producing about 2 million barrels a day more than its 23.5 million barrel quota; raising the quota would only put a different label on what is already going on, they said.
 ''This is more of a public relations exercise'' than a serious plan to lower prices, said Leo Drollas, deputy director and chief economist at the Center for Energy Studies, a London-based research firm. 
 In response to the criticism, Mr. Purnomo said that the Saudi plan was just a proposal and that the members of the cartel had not approved it. Other ideas may also be considered, he said, without giving details. 
 In addition to an overall shortage of refining capacity in the United States, where refineries are running at more than 95 percent of their maximum, Mr. Purnomo said that variations in auto emissions standards from state to state also drove fuel prices higher. ''You can't easily move excess capacity from state to state,'' he said. 
 The state attorneys general agreed on Thursday that adopting a single national standard could alleviate some supply problems. Analysts said that would also make it less difficult for refineries overseas to supply the American market.
 No matter what OPEC decides to do, there is little or no chance of relief in June, Mr. Purnomo said, because the tankers used to carry crude oil to market are already booked for the month and no more are available. ''I cannot change production in June,'' he said. 
 Mr. Purnomo also met with Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, as Britain calls its finance minister. Afterward, Mr. Purnomo described the meeting as an exchange of ideas that did not include pressure on OPEC. But Mr. Brown issued a statement saying that ''it is crucial for the stability and prosperity of the world economy that OPEC act now to achieve a more sustainable oil price.''

HEADLINE: But a Push Is On to Interest Donors in Unsung Spots

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER

 BODY:
Even during tough economic times, getting private money to keep up the public's most famous parks has never been terribly hard. Groups like the Central Park Conservancy have a long history of bringing in philanthropic dollars, concerts and film programs in places like Bryant Park have thrived, and scores of nonprofit groups have raised money or rolled up their sleeves to plant flowers in the city's more affluent neighborhoods. 
 But over the last two years, the Parks Department has tried to spread that private-sector help across the entire city, particularly to parks that serve poor residents. 
 The Parks Department, with the help of City Hall, has been pushing donors toward some of the city's most needy patches of green, and when donors insist on putting their money toward flagship parks, focusing city dollars toward the less celebrated parks. 
 Last year, for example, the Bloomberg administration joined with the City Parks Foundation to concentrate on 16 parks in Astoria, Long Island City, Harlem, Highbridge and Red Hook for immediate improvements. A plan to offer naming rights to companies willing to give money to support parks has been spreading slowly across the city. 
 In January, the financier Carl C. Icahn donated $10 million to help complete a track and field stadium at Randalls Island Park, the largest gift ever from a donor to a city park outside Central Park. And on the other end of the spectrum, the Target Corporation donated $35,000 to keep the fountains outside City Hall and the city's borough halls decorated with foliage during the winter, in exchange for small signs noting its sponsorship.
 ''The Parks Department was always supportive,'' said David Rivel, the executive director of the City Parks Foundation, a nonprofit group that supports neighborhood parks. ''But the thing that is different about this administration is that we were able to have a strategic conversation about focusing efforts in low-income neighborhood parks.''
 The city offered the foundation $20 million in capital money for the 16 small parks, while the foundation brought in $5 million, a partnership Mr. Rivel called ''unprecedented.'' 
 The focus is driven in part by City Hall, where Patricia E. Harris, the deputy mayor for administration, has been directing donors toward the mayor's favorite beneficiaries: ''The mayor's priorities include parks, education and the arts,'' Ms. Harris said, ''and those are great areas to fund-raise for because so many New Yorkers are interested in funding them.'' 
 Ms. Harris has longstanding relationships with philanthropic groups, stemming from her days in the Art Commission under Mayor Edward I. Koch, and her years at Bloomberg L.P. managing its giving program. Often, potential donors call looking for something to do, and Ms. Harris or Adrian Benepe, the city's parks commissioner, are ready with suggestions. 
 For instance, when the columnist Liz Smith raised $200,000 from readers during the budget crisis, the city allocated half for the Fund for Public Schools, and half to the Parks Department to train college and high school students to build nature trails and collect ecological data.
 The Parks Department has also tried to get communities to rally around smaller parks and raise money for them. For example, a volunteer committee (which includes Dr. Ruth Westheimer) was recently established to raise $5 million for Fort Tryon Park and the Heather Garden in Washington Heights. 
 ''A lot of people want to do things in Central Park, but there are only a few opportunities,'' Mr. Benepe said. ''So when people are not sure what they are going to do, we send them to projects that otherwise would not have had donors.'' 
 One such example was Randalls Island. Mr. Icahn, who has donated millions of dollars to causes here in his hometown city, was looking for a new project to finance. He was introduced to Mr. Benepe last summer, who presented him with a list of parks projects that included Randalls Island, where the storied but dilapidated Downing Stadium was being replaced. 
 On a chilly spring afternoon, Mr. Benepe took Mr. Icahn to see where seating for 10,000 spectators, a 400-meter running track, and a regulation-size soccer field were under construction. After taking a brief peek, Mr. Icahn took his cellphone and repaired to a giant I-beam for 45 minutes, where he closed a business deal. 
 Mr. Benepe was in a slight panic, wondering if Mr. Icahn was going to fall in love. He did, and now Mr. Icahn, whose gift completed the roof and light towers on the project, will see his name towering over the stadium, visible from the F.D.R. Drive. 
 The Randalls Island project, which has been developing for several years, is expected to provide world-class track and field facilities for local communities and schools, especially in the adjacent Harlem and Bronx neighborhoods. The $40 million project is also financed by $20 million in public funds and another $10 million in private donations, and will be open next spring.
 Other areas around Randalls Island for which the Parks Department would love to find donors -- who would also get to see their names in lights -- include a stadium for Gallic football, a water park at the island's northern tip and a tennis center to replace the aging stadium. 
 Some nonprofit groups that specialize in rejuvenating parks in less affluent areas say the city still has a long way to go. ''The challenge is greatest in underserved parks,'' said Joseph Pupello, president of the New York Restoration Project. 
 But Mr. Benepe said that enticing more donors to give to small parks and offering corporate naming rights was part of an overall strategy to increase private money, volunteerism and general revenues from outside the city budget for his parks.
 Exhibit A: among the city's 1,700 parks or playgrounds, 50 percent have been adopted by volunteers, up from 40 percent a year ago, he said. And nine nonprofit groups have together raised $60 million for parks restoration, which Mr. Benepe says he believes is a $10 million increase over two years ago.
 The department is also trying to raise more money through concessions and rentals of parks. It recently closed a deal to get more than $180 million in combined rent and capital improvements at seven city-owned golf courses over the next 20 years. In the first year of the contract, the city will receive nearly double the rent it did in 2002; an increase to $4.6 million from $2.5 million. 
 ''We have developed a more sophisticated approach to charitable fund-raising and new forms of partnerships,'' Mr. Benepe said. ''The level of involvement from both private citizens and corporations and nonprofit groups is the way of doing business now. The days of the Parks Department strictly being a municipal enterprise without working with the community and having people assisting are gone and will never return.''

HEADLINE: House Approves $447 Billion in Spending for Military

BYLINE: By CARL HULSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20 

 BODY:
The House on Thursday overwhelmingly approved a $447 billion military package that includes the extra $25 billion sought by the Bush administration to pay for operations in Iraq and Afghanistan through early next year.
 Authors of the measure, which passed by a bipartisan margin of 391 to 34, said it was specifically geared toward the needs of those fighting in Iraq and Afghanistan, providing $1 billion for new vehicle armor, replenishing stockpiles of arms and ammunition and giving military personnel a pay raise and other benefits.
 ''This is the year of the troops,'' said Representative Duncan Hunter, Republican of California and chairman of the Armed Services Committee.
 The House defied a veto threat from the administration by keeping a two-year delay on a round of military base closings set for next year, easily defeating an effort to require the closings to move forward in 2005. Mr. Hunter and other senior Republicans said they did not expect the Pentagon's spending plan for the year beginning Oct. 1 to be rejected over the base closing provision. 
 Senators were moving much more slowly with their own $422 billion measure and abandoned hope of finishing before leaving on their Memorial Day break. Both the House and Senate were considering the proposals against the backdrop of the prison scandal in Iraq and continuing unrest and uncertainty there.
 ''We are in a war,'' said Representative Ike Skelton of Missouri, the senior Democrat on the Armed Services Committee. ''Neither the country nor this Congress was united in initiating the conflict, but we stand now as one with the soldiers, sailors, airmen and marines fighting it.''
 House Democrats complained throughout two days of debate that they were prevented from offering important amendments, but in the end most of them supported the legislation. Some Democrats said the $400 million for body armor and other ''force protection'' provisions showed that the troops dispatched to Iraq were ill-equipped in the first place. ''There is no excuse for us to send our soldiers into harm's way without this most basic protection,'' said Representative Louise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York.
 Among the personnel benefits in the measure are a 3.5 percent pay increase, a raise in hazardous duty and family separation pay, improved survivor benefits and elimination of a limit on the construction of military housing. The measure also allows for adding 30,000 troops in the Army over the next three years and 9,000 in the Marine Corps.
 Democrats again failed to strip the measure of money for researching a new nuclear weapon capable of penetrating underground bunkers. But Representative Ellen O. Tauscher, Democrat of California, noted that the 214-to-204 vote was closer than a similar effort last year, which she read as a sign of growing skepticism about new nuclear devices. Opponents of the nuclear program say it could spur proliferation.
 The most significant fight was over the plan to proceed next year with the base closings, an important matter for lawmakers trying to protect facilities in their districts. Opponents of delaying the base closings said that the military needed to get moving on shutting under-used facilities and that the economic impact on communities was exaggerated.
 But supporters of the two-year delay said the makeup of the armed forces was undergoing significant changes given the conflict in Iraq and that it would be impractical to proceed next year before a study of overseas installations was finished.
 ''Too many balls are in the air,'' said Representative Joel Hefley, Republican of Colorado and chairman of the subcommittee on military readiness. Mr. Hefley prevailed, 259 to 162, against the push to keep the closings on track. That decision sets up an eventual showdown with the Senate, which this week narrowly defeated an effort to delay the closings.
 The House also gave its support to tearing down the Abu Ghraib prison, the scene of the abuse of Iraq detainees, and replacing it with a new facility. But lawmakers defeated a Democratic push for a special Congressional inquiry into the abuse as Democrats complained that the House was failing in oversight of the war.
 The debate in the Senate got off track this week when the Armed Services Committee spent much of Wednesday on its third hearing into the prison abuse cases. Lawmakers will take the bill up again in about 10 days. The Senate consideration promises to be more contentious than the House, though the outcome is likely to be the same, with a wide approval for the measure.
 Both parties are near agreement on incorporating the $25 billion in war money in the Senate measure. But Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, is trying to add a requirement that President Bush deliver a report on his strategy for stabilizing Iraq. Democrats also intend to challenge the spending on new nuclear weapons and money for missile defense while proposing a troop increase beyond that adopted by the House.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Founder of Strong Funds Settles Trading Inquiry
Richard S. Strong, who helped fuel the growth of mutual funds over the last three decades, has agreed to pay $60 million and be banned from the financial industry for life to settle an investigation over rapid trades he made at the expense of fund investors.
 Mr. Strong, 62, the founder of Strong Capital Management, is the most prominent figure to be ensnared in a sweeping investigation of improper trading in mutual funds begun last September by Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general. Mr. Spitzer and other regulators have sued some of the nation's largest money managers, forcing several to pay steep penalties and reduce the fees charged to investors. [Page A1.]

Richard Strong might take heart at some recent examples of Wall Street figures who also received bans, including Michael R. Milken, the former junk bond king, and Frederick H. Joseph, Mr. Milken's boss. [C2.]

Bids Received for Media Holdings
About a half-dozen bidders, including the Barclay brothers of Britain, submitted offers of about $1 billion for The Daily Telegraph of London, the crown jewel of Conrad M. Black's publishing empire, Hollinger International, executives involved in the auction said. [C2.]

Grasso Suit Expected Next Week
Regulators are expected to file a civil suit against Richard A. Grasso next week that could also include former directors who played a role in deciding the pay of the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange. [C5.]

An Advertising Battle of the Beers
The battle between Budweiser and Miller beers over the carbohydrate content of beers is heating up. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C6.]

Air Canada Reaches Union Pact
Air Canada cleared a crucial obstacle in its restructuring by reaching an agreement with the last of seven unions on wage concessions and other cost reductions. [C5.]

Tellabs to Buy Advanced Fibre
Tellabs plans to buy Advanced Fibre Communications for about $1.9 billion in cash and stock to add high-speed Internet access equipment to its products, gaining higher profits and the prospect for strong growth, analysts and company executives said. Shares of Advanced Fibre rose $2.13, while shares of Tellabs fell $1.24, or 13 percent, to $7.95. [C5.]

Oracle and Microsoft Join Forces
Two longtime rivals, Oracle and Microsoft, announced a partnership intended to help Oracle's databases work better with Microsoft's Windows operating system. [C2.]

Italy Backs Alitalia Plan
Alitalia, Italy's flagship airline, secured government support to sell new stock and for a bridge loan that would provide cash to pull the company back from the edge of bankruptcy. [World Business, Section W.]

Estee Lauder Joins With P. Diddy
Estee Lauder is expected to announce today that it will produce a men's fragrance in collaboration with Sean Combs, the hip-hop entrepreneur known as P. Diddy. [C11.]

Pringles Adding Trivia Quiz to Chips
Procter & Gamble plans to print trivia questions and answers on its Pringles chips, using ink made of blue or red food coloring. [C2.]

Wall St. Concerned About Oil Prices
Stocks were nearly flat. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.07 point, to 9,937.64, and the Nasdaq composite index declined 1.58 points, to 1,896.59. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 0.51 point, to 1,089.19. [C5.]

The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators rose 0.1 percent in April; slightly lower than the 0.2 percent rise forecast by analysts. In other news, the Labor Department reported that initial claims for unemployment benefits rose 12,000, to 345,000. [C5.]

HEADLINE: Mutiny by 4 Republicans Over Bush's Tax Cutting Forces Delay on the Budget Vote

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 20 

 BODY:
Unable to a squelch a six-week mutiny over President Bush's tax-cutting agenda, Senate Republican leaders on Thursday conceded that they could not muster enough votes to pass a $2.4 trillion budget plan and abruptly postponed a vote until at least next month.
 ''It's premature to bring it to a vote tonight,'' said Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the Senate majority leader, after spending much of the day trying to persuade a handful of centrist Republicans to abandon their insistence that any new tax cuts be paid for with either spending cuts or tax increases.
 The decision, coming on the same day that Mr. Bush made a high-profile plea for approval of the budget on a last-minute trip to Capitol Hill, was a major setback for the president, and reflected growing unease about his goal of permanently extending the tax cuts of 2001 and 2003. It was also a sign of bitter rifts between House and Senate Republicans and between House leaders and Senate moderates, some of whom openly traded insults earlier this week. 
 Democrats wasted little time in using the moment to denounce Mr. Bush's economic agenda.
 ''Welcome to the big leagues,'' said Representative Rahm Emmanuel, Democrat of Illinois, a former White House aide in the Clinton Administration. ''This is not only an example of their being unable to govern, it's an example of the failure of their economic policies.''
 Congressional analysts have estimated that the cost of making the tax cuts permanent could total nearly $2 trillion over the next 10 years. The budget impasse, which began in March, was over whether to impose a ''pay as you go'' rule that would require Congress to offset the cost of new tax cuts.
 Mr. Bush and House Republicans adamantly opposed any such restrictions, as they would have made it almost impossible to make last year's tax cuts permanent.
 But in the Senate, a handful of centrist Republicans teamed up with Democrats in March and succeeded in attaching the pay-as-you-go rule to the budget resolution by a two-vote majority. House and Senate leaders agreed on a compromise that would have essentially postponed the major decisions until next year, but all four of the Republican dissenters rejected the deal as unacceptable.
 Although Mr. Frist said he still hoped to pass a budget resolution when Congress returns in early June from its Memorial Day recess, Republicans and Democrats said the impasse will not be easy to resolve.
 ''I would have been surprised if the budget had passed today,'' said Senator Charles Grassley, Republican of Iowa, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. ''I knew if there were holdouts they weren't going to change at the last minute. ''
 The battle on Thursday was over a central difference between budget resolutions passed earlier this year by the House and Senate.
 Four Senate moderates -- John McCain of Arizona, Olympia J. Snowe and Susan Collins, both of Maine, and Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island -- had insisted on attaching a provision that would have applied pay-as-you-go-rules for the next five years.
 The House budget resolution called only for a pay-as-you-go rule that would apply to new spending programs outside of defense and domestic security. The Bush administration staunchly supported the House approach, determined to permanently extend the tax cuts of 2001 and 2003 rather than let them expire over the next several years.
 Senate Republicans needed two more votes to reverse the earlier budget vote in March, but none of the four moderates were willing to give much ground.
 ''It sounds like an obscure technical issue, but it is extremely important,'' said Robert Bixby, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a nonprofit research group that campaigns for lower budget deficits. ''It is becoming a major rift within the Republican Party.''
 Mr. McCain let it be known this month that he would go along with imposing pay-as-you-go rules for three years instead of five, but House Republicans said they would only accept the restriction for one year.
 In what seemed like a last-ditch effort at agreement, Mr. Frist and other Senate leaders agreed with House leaders on a one-year plan that would allow Congress to extend for one year three major tax cuts that are set to expire at the end of the year.
 But as the pressure to reach a deal increased, Mr. McCain scathingly attacked the ''fat cats'' who were not willing to make sacrifices while fighting a war. That prompted an angry retort earlier this week from the Republican House speaker, J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, who said Mr. McCain, a decorated war veteran and former prisoner of war, ought to appreciate the sacrifices being made by soldiers in Iraq.
 Mr. McCain fired back on Thursday. ''I fondly remember a time when real Republicans stood for fiscal responsibility,'' he said. ''Apparently, those days are long gone for some of those in our party.''
 By Thursday morning, Republican leaders had all but abandoned hope of persuading any of their four rebellious colleagues and tried in vain to find one or two conservative Democrats who might change their views.
 Mr. Bush came to Capitol Hill, in part to talk about Iraq but also to appeal for support on the budget.
 ''I urge the Senate to follow the House's lead and pass this budget so that we can continue making progress on our shared agenda of building a safer, stronger, and better America,'' Mr. Bush said in a statement after meeting with House and Senate Republicans.
 The failure of Senate Republicans to pass a budget resolution does not mean that any of last year's tax cuts will necessarily expire.
 Both House and Senate budget plans would have left room to extend those tax cuts without finding ways to pay for them, at least for the next few years.

HEADLINE: The Russian Contender For King of the Oil Patch

BYLINE: By ERIN E. ARVEDLUND

DATELINE: MOSCOW, May 20 

 BODY:
By rights, Russia should have a world-class energy company. It has 6 percent of the world's oil reserves and pumps 10 percent of daily global production, rivaling Saudi Arabia. And its economy has rebounded as oil-consuming nations east and west turn increasingly to Russia for energy supplies. 
 The decade of sharp-elbowed deal making that shaped the Russian industry yielded two leading contenders for the global energy big leagues. One, Yukos, was a clear favorite in the capital markets: run by a charismatic, financially astute young chairman, eager to do business the Western way, emphasizing transparency and technical skill, and open to deals with giants like Exxon Mobil. 
 But Yukos fell from grace last year, after its chairman, Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, locked political horns with the Kremlin and found himself arrested and jailed on fraud and embezzlement charges, while the company fights a $3 billion assessment for back taxes. 
 The other contender, Lukoil, has no such troubles. Its president, Vagit Y. Alekperov, gets along very well with President Vladimir V. Putin, who even took time out from a state visit to the United States last September to cut the ribbon at a new Lukoil gas station on the West Side of Manhattan. 
 But the very things that make Lukoil work in Russia are holding it back in the rest of the world, analysts and industry experts say: Lukoil remains a very Russian company, with all that has come to imply, from its complex structure and opaque finances to its inefficiency and dependence on the good will of the Kremlin.
 The company's ambitions are plain: Mr. Alekperov has been saying since 1996 that the company aims to be the biggest producer in the world, and that the ''seven sisters'' of the oil industry ''now have a brother.'' 
 Lukoil's reserves, which by some measures are second in the world only to Exxon Mobil's, give weight to its claim; so does its major retail presence in Europe and in the United States, with the purchase of 1,300 Getty gas stations in 2001 and 800 more from ConocoPhillips this year. 
 Mr. Alekperov said in an interview that Lukoil was looking for refineries to lease in the United States so that American drivers ''will have us as one of the major producers of gasoline.''
 Whatever else it may be, Lukoil is immense. In April it reported that it had 20.06 billion barrels of proven oil and gas reserves at the beginning of the year, a 4 percent increase from a year earlier. Lukoil reports its reserves under rules of the Society of Petroleum Engineers and those rules are somewhat more permissive than the Securities and Exchange Commission rules that govern American companies; even so, its resources put it in a class with international majors like ChevronTexaco, PetroChina, BP, Royal Dutch/Shell and Total.
 For years, though, Lukoil lagged rivals like Yukos and Sibneft at the wellhead and in the stock market. Putting modern methods and technology to work in its Soviet-era oil fields much faster than Lukoil did, Yukos caught up to it in daily production in the late 1990's, and averaged 1.61 million barrels a day in 2003, ahead of Lukoil's 1.58 million. 
 Last fall, Yukos and Sibneft agreed to merge in a deal that would have eclipsed Lukoil, but the billionaire investor who controls Sibneft, Roman A. Abramovich, called it off after prosecutors arrested Mr. Khodorkovsky at gunpoint last October. Yukos and Sibneft are still trying to disentangle themselves as Mr. Khodorkovsky awaits trial. 
 Mr. Alekperov, the career oil man who built Lukoil, could hardly be more different from Mr. Khodorkovsky, a banker 13 years his junior, in background and politics. Born in Azerbaijan in 1950, one of five children raised by a single mother, and trained as an engineer, Mr. Alekperov worked his way up through the Soviet oil industry to be deputy minister of energy in 1990 and 1991, as the Communist era was lurching toward its end. When the Soviet Union collapsed, Mr. Alekperov was in a position to cherry-pick the best oil and gas assets as they were privatized. 
 Both men want more export pipelines built in Russia to ease bottlenecks, but where Mr. Khodorkovsky has advocated private projects to compete with Transneft, the state pipeline monopoly, Mr. Alekperov has avoided challenging Transneft.
 Where Mr. Khodorkovsky financed opposition parties and advertised his own presidential ambitions, Mr. Alekperov stayed close to Mr. Putin and his ruling party, United Russia. 
 Where Mr. Khodorkovsky argued publicly that Russia should drop its opposition to the United States-led invasion and occupation of Iraq, Mr. Alekperov stayed quiet in public, choosing instead to have Lukoil cooperate with the American authorities behind the scenes, training employees in the new Iraqi oil ministry and supplying northern provinces with fuel. 
 Lukoil's hope in Iraq is to win back its lucrative West Qurna oil concession, which Saddam Hussein annulled just before the invasion last March. ''Our contract is solid,'' Mr. Alekperov said, adding that much depends on the handover of sovereignty to Iraqis planned for June 30. 
 At the same time, Lukoil is solidifying its beachhead in the United States, gradually converting its Getty stations to display the red-and-white Lukoil logo. And at home, it is moving into production of natural gas, another sector where prices are quite high and Russia has huge deposits, mostly controlled by Gazprom, the state gas-distribution monopoly. 
 ''We have pretty good reserves in the Yamal region'' in Russia's far north, Mr. Alekperov said. ''And we have an arrangement with Gazprom to sell them gas.'' 
 Yukos and its managers, meanwhile, have had to spend time responding to attacks from the tax ministry, local prosecutors, and other officials questioning its oil production licenses. 
 Though publicly traded as a single entity, Lukoil is structured more like a decentralized web of fiefs, and some investors say it is often unclear how profits flow to the center of the group or whether its published accounts fully capture what is going on. 
 ''Some of the units within Lukoil, like Permneft, are, in management terms, very autonomous,'' said Ian Hague, co-manager of Firebird, a hedge fund specializing in Russian investments. ''The amount of oil they're producing, as compared to net income, seems to show that large sums -- hundreds of millions of dollars -- are going places not clear to investors.'' 
 Mr. Hague noted that Lukoil's sales, general and administrative costs appear to be much higher than those of rivals like Sibneft and Yukos. Renaissance Capital, a brokerage house in Moscow, calculates the difference at $2.10 for each barrel it produces. 
 ''Investors don't like things that are difficult to explain,'' Mr. Hague said. ''If Lukoil is running an expensive ship, meaning more of their money goes to administrative costs than others, investors view that as a problem.''
 According to an analysis by UBS Brunswick, Lukoil earned about $5.36 for each barrel of oil it pumped in 2002; Yukos made about $5.53. Those figures are almost certainly much higher today, thanks to export prices that have risen by more than 30 percent since then. The Russian industry could export much more if the ports and pipelines existed to handle the greater volume; as it is, much of its oil remains stranded in the glutted domestic market, where it can be bought for less than $8 a barrel. 
 Stocks of American majors like Exxon Mobil and ChevronTexaco are now trading at price-to-earnings multiples in the mid-teens, based on estimated earnings over the next year. But Lukoil's multiple is just 7.9, in the middle of the Russian oil pack. 
 William Browder, who manages Hermitage, a hedge fund specializing in Russia that holds Lukoil shares, said that the company's stock is undervalued because of investor-unfriendly business practices and profits that are weaker than they should be. 
 With more than 600 affiliated companies and 160 subsidiaries, Mr. Browder said, ''the structure of Lukoil makes investors' access to future cash flows very uncertain.'' 
 Lukoil is making little progress on a two-year-old promise to sell poorly performing or noncore units like banking and construction companies. But a bigger worry about Lukoil, investors and analysts say, is the way it handles exports: selling oil at below-market prices to offshore affiliates who resell it to customers at full price. 
 Mr. Browder said that profits from this arrangement, known as transfer pricing and common in the Russian oil industry, are not finding their way back to Lukoil's bottom line. He estimated that Lukoil had forgone about $1 billion in earnings from 2000 to 2003 because of transfer pricing; if not for that, he said, the company's stock would now be worth $40 a share instead of $27. A Lukoil spokesman said he could not comment on Mr. Browder's assessment. 
 Two years ago, Mr. Alekperov promised that the offshore affiliates would be merged into a wholly owned Lukoil subsidiary called Litasco, but so far only 29 percent of Lukoil's exports are passing through Litasco.
 ''Lukoil investors should insist on termination of transfer pricing practices and full consolidation'' of Lukoil's exports, Mr. Browder said. A Lukoil spokesman said the company was not done with its restructuring yet.
 The Russian government has decided to sell its remaining 7.6 percent stake in Lukoil, perhaps by the end of the year, Mr. Alekperov said. For a while, investors hoped that the shares would go in a block to a Western oil major, perhaps ConocoPhillips, which is working with Lukoil in developing the Timan Pechora field. ConocoPhillips is also talking to Lukoil about refining some of its crude oil in Scotland for sale in North America. But the Kremlin is now cool to the idea of foreign companies taking large stakes in Russian oil producers, making such a sale unlikely. 
 ''In this world, nothing is impossible,'' he said. ''But we're oriented as an independent company. We have international oil rights, and we're a global company.''

HEADLINE: Bankruptcies Continue to Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 21 

 BODY:
Personal bankruptcies rose 2.8 percent in the 12 months ended March 31, continuing the upward trend of recent years but marking a more moderate increase than in earlier months, data released Friday showed. 
 New personal bankruptcy filings rose to 1,618,062 in that period from 1,573,720 in the 12 months ended March 31, 2003, according to the data from the Administrative Office of the United States Courts.
 The upward trend has continued despite signs of recovery in the economy as effects linger from the consumer spending binge of the 1990's, and the historically low interest rates that encouraged borrowing and built up heavy household debt. The rate of bankruptcies generally lags behind direction changes in other economic indicators.
