HEADLINE: Rating on California Bonds Is Raised by One Agency

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 21 

 BODY:
A Wall Street rating company upgraded California's dismal credit rating for the first time in nearly four years Friday, reflecting a modest economic rebound and, under Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, the prospect of an end to years of political stagnation in Sacramento.
 The company, Moody's Investors Service, bumped the state's rating up one notch, to A3, still the lowest of any state's and one grade below New York's. Among the chief reasons for the move, the agency cited improved job creation and higher-than-expected receipts from the personal income tax .
 Tim Blake, chief California analyst for Moody's, also said that the state's political climate had improved markedly under Governor Schwarzenegger and that the worst of the state's fiscal crisis appeared to have passed, at least for now. 
 ''California is now back to the rating that it had when Schwarzenegger came into office,'' Mr. Blake said, noting that the agency downgraded the state's rating in December. ''The outlook is positive for the first time in several years.''
 Mr. Schwarzenegger, using his favorite adjective, proclaimed the Moody's announcement ''fantastic news.''
 ''Their financial analysts have had a chance to carefully review our revised budget and our economic outlook, and they've concluded that it warrants an improvement in California's standing in the nation's financial markets,'' the governor said in a statement. ''I appreciate their strong vote of confidence in the new direction that we're taking California.''
 Mr. Schwarzenegger has made improving the state's business and investment climate his highest priority, and the rating change is a significant step toward that goal. He has used a potent combination of celebrity, cajolery and naked threats to intimidate lawmakers and interest groups into going along with his policies.
 He pushed through a ballot initiative in March that authorized borrowing $15 billion to address an acute cash crisis and to patch a longer-term hole in the state's $103 billion annual budget. Voters approved the measure overwhelmingly, along with a companion bill to outlaw such borrowing in the future.
 Over the last several weeks, the governor has also negotiated budget deals with crucial constituent groups -- K-12 schools, state colleges and universities, local governments -- that trade short-term spending cuts for longer-term increases.
 Further, he has prodded the Legislature to enact a revision to the state's costly and inefficient workers' compensation program and is demanding that lawmakers pass a budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 by the statutory deadline of June 15; the Legislature has missed the deadline in 17 of the last 25 years.
 The governor used the credit rating announcement on Friday to remind the Legislature of its duty to pass a budget by mid-June. Moody's is ''staking this vote of confidence on our ability to approve this budget,'' he said of his budget proposal, and added, ''We should now return the favor by doing the right thing, and that is for the Legislature to get this balanced and responsible budget passed on time.''
 The two other chief credit rating agencies, Standard & Poor's and Fitch, have left California's bond ratings unchanged, at BBB, just two grades above junk status. Standard & Poor's said last week, however, that it was viewing economic and budgetary conditions in California favorably and would review the low rating after the state enacts its budget for the coming fiscal year.
 The Moody's announcement on Friday affects nearly $44 billion in outstanding debt issued by California and should over time lower the state's borrowing costs. It said that California had added an average of 100,000 jobs a month this year and that its personal income growth was outpacing the national average.
 The company said California still faced huge budgetary challenges, noting that even if Mr. Schwarzenegger's budget passed more or less unchanged, he would face a shortfall of $6 billion to $8 billion next year and for several years thereafter.
 ''The budget's structural imbalance situation represents a significant ongoing fiscal challenge for California, and is a primary reason for the still quite low bond rating relative to other states,'' Moody's said. However, it said, the new borrowing and the deals with schools and local governments have given the state financial breathing room for at least the next 18 months to address those long-range problems.
 Timothy A. Hodson, director of the Center for California Studies, at California State University, Sacramento, said that the upgrade was in part a reflection of national economic trends over which no governor has any control. But he also said the financial markets were beginning to reward Mr. Schwarzenegger's muscular brand of political leadership.
 ''You'd have to be the proverbial blind man,'' Dr. Hodson said, ''not to recognize that Arnold Schwarzenegger has brought an impressive level of enthusiasm and proactive governance to California, and that has resonated among Californians and obviously has resonated on Wall Street.''
 Dr. Hodson said Mr. Schwarzenegger appeared to be following a strategy of dealing with acute problems immediately and putting off addressing the state's longer-range budget problems until next year. That strategy works, he noted, when the economy is growing, but can create more severe problems if another recession hits.
 ''Of course he understands there's a bill coming due in two or three years because of these deals,'' Dr. Hodson said. ''But his view is, 'I'll take care of the alligators now and worry about draining the swamp next year.'''

HEADLINE: In India's Spotlight, He Was Both Director and Audience

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 21 

 BODY:
As members of his Hindu nationalist party mounted vehement attacks on Sonia Gandhi's Italian origins earlier this week, and as his cabinet pledged to boycott her expected inauguration as India's new leader, the departing prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, said not a public word. 
 Did his silence signify disapproval of his party's flouting of democratic protocol? Or approval? It was unclear, but the result was that the campaign against Mrs. Gandhi proceeded unchecked. 
 On Tuesday, Mrs. Gandhi, whose Indian National Congress had dealt Mr. Vajpayee's Bharatiya Janata Party a surprise election defeat last week, said she would not take over as prime minister, in part because her foreign roots threatened to become so divisive. Instead, a former finance minister in her party, Manmohan Singh, will be sworn in this weekend. 
 That Mr. Vajpayee's final gesture in office should be one of convenient passivity speaks much to the legacy of his rule.
 In the six years that he led the country, some of the fundamental traits that had defined India for decades shifted. On some of those shifts, Mr. Vajpayee, a 79-year-old poet whose political career spans a half-century, clearly set the course. On others, he opted for an inaction that proved its own form of course-setting.
 That combination may put him in the history books as one of India's more formative leaders, but also one of its more inscrutable.
 During his administration, India became a declared nuclear power and emerged as an economic power as well, firmly embracing globalization and the market. Nonalignment gave way to a new closeness to the United States, and Mr. Vajpayee made fresh peace moves toward China and Pakistan.
 He pushed grand infrastructure projects, like a national highway system, but largely neglected social programs like education and health. His government demonstrated that a coalition government could be as stable as the Congress party monolith that governed India for most of its history.
 But his Hindu nationalist party also used the state machinery to undermine India's secular identity, which guarantees equal rights both to the country's Hindu majority and to Christians, Muslims and other minority groups. 
 The Congress party assuming power for the first time since 1996 will find ''the India that they left is not the India they have inherited,'' said Ashley J. Tellis, senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington. ''It is very different in many ways -- some for the better and some for the worse.''
 If, as some have argued, Mr. Vajpayee was a visionary, of what sort? Was he like Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first prime minister, who actively defined many of the ideas challenged in the past six years? Or more like Ronald Reagan, who set a broad ideological course but largely left the details to others? 
 Many of the initiatives Mr. Vajpayee is given credit for, whether in foreign or economic policy, began under previous Congress governments. But Mr. Vajpayee in some cases effectively used his party's orientation to advance those policies, and in others used his political talents to overcome the resistance of the Hindu nationalists in or allied to his party. 
 Within days after taking office in May 1998, he ordered a series of nuclear tests that changed India's relation to the world. 
 Matching tests soon followed from its neighbor and enemy Pakistan, causing some critics to say India had lost its conventional military advantage to nuclear parity.
 But C. Raja Mohan, a professor of South Asian studies at Jawaharlal Nehru University in New Delhi, argued that the tests allowed India to shake off its ''inferiority complex'' and deal with China and the United States in a different way. 
 ''There was a sense of confidence with which he could engage the whole world,'' he said. 
 Last June, Mr. Vajpayee visited China and set in motion a new process to resolve the two countries' border dispute. This January, he did the same with Pakistan, in his third and most fruitful effort to make peace with India's neighbor. 
 Mr. Mohan said the party's worldview -- ''anti-Communist in a Western sense'' and unencumbered by the anti-imperialism that so shaped the Congress party -- made it easier for it to forge a new relationship with the West. 
 ''These guys were not burdened by the need to rhetorically argue with the United States,'' he said.
 And after the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks, the two countries found more common ground in fighting Islamic extremism.
 As for the economy, Shekhar Gupta, editor in chief of The Indian Express, said Mr. Vajpayee was not enamored of socialism, as many of his predecessors had been. He brought ''less an intellectual understanding of economic reform than an instinctive appreciation for enterprise,'' Mr. Gupta said. 
 Mr. Gupta said he wished Mr. Vajpayee had sometimes pushed harder, both against his party's hard-liners and for economic reforms, some of which were delayed or halted because of political opposition. 
 Where Mr. Vajpayee went wrong, Mr. Gupta said, was in not standing his ground. Despite projecting himself as a moderate, he largely bowed to his party's Hindu nationalist agenda. 
 This was evident in his handling of the Gujarat riots in 2002, when rioters avenged the burning to death of 59 Hindus in a train carriage by killing at least 1,000 Muslims. While aides described Mr. Vajpayee as personally opposed to retaining the Gujarat chief minister who let the riots continue unchecked, he gave in to his party's pressures and allowed the chief minister to stay in office. When the Gujarat State government failed to prosecute Hindus for the riots, it was the Supreme Court -- not Mr. Vajpayee's government -- that intervened.
 Mr. Vajpayee also entrusted the education portfolio to a Hindu nationalist, Murli Manohar Joshi, who over six years set about rewriting textbooks and packing academic bodies with fellow ideologues whose aim was to uncritically glorify the ancient Hindus at the expense of other groups in India. 
 Yet on issues of more basic education, there is little to show. ''I think they did very little certainly for rural areas,'' Jean Dreze, an economist, said. ''Social sectors really weren't their focus.''
 One of Mr. Vajpayee's chief aides, Sudheendra Kulkarni, argued that it was unfair to expect the B.J.P. government to do in a half-dozen years what Congress could not do in almost a half-century. ''We really had a very short time,'' Mr. Kulkarni said. 
 But for Indian politics, new to coalitions, those six years were a long time, and may stand among Mr. Vajpayee's great achievements. ''He demonstrated you could have stable coalition governments that could complete full terms in office,'' Mr. Tellis said. ''This was very important for the maturation of India as a democracy.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Atal Bihari Vajpayee, shown here on May 14 at his residence in New Delhi, has been something of a closed book, both during his term as prime minister and throughout the election that ended it. (Photo by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Weakening the Rules for Judges

 BODY:
The special commission weighing revisions to the American Bar Association's code of judicial conduct seems to have missed the lesson of Justice Antonin Scalia's notorious duck-hunting trip with Vice President Dick Cheney: Americans don't appreciate it when judges behave in ways that undermine the judicial system's fairness and integrity.
 The bar panel's newly unveiled proposals for revamping the Model Code of Judicial Conduct would actually weaken the core provision that requires judges to avoid not just actual impropriety in all their activities, but also the appearance of impropriety. Although the new version retains the appearance standard, it waters it down by saying that violations will not ''ordinarily'' lead to professional discipline unless there are charges of other rule violations. Intentionally or not, as Senator Patrick Leahy of Vermont aptly noted last week in a letter to the bar association's president, Dennis Archer, that transforms a crucial ethical mandate into ''an ancillary add-on'' and significantly diminishes its moral force and deterrence value. 
 The proposed change was apparently driven largely by an overblown concern about the ''vagueness'' of the appearance-of-impropriety standard. Judges interpret similar terms every day, and there now exists a substantial body of case law and ethics opinions construing the type of behavior that gives rise to an appearance of impropriety. The proper way to address any undue murkiness, in any event, is for the commission to provide further guidance, not to dilute expectations.
 In another disappointment, the commission's proposal failed to tighten the rules on disqualification to match the stronger and more clear-cut requirements for the federal judiciary. A federal judge is barred from sitting in a case involving a company in which the judge has any economic interest. A provision of the bar's current code, retained in the new proposal, requires disqualification only when a judge deems that the economic interest is more than ''de minimis,'' and ''could be substantially affected.'' 
 Even more baffling, the commission has deleted the current instruction to judges to resolve any ambiguity in the Code of Conduct in a way that advances public trust in the judiciary's ''integrity, independence and impartiality.'' Practically and symbolically, that deletion is a real mistake.
 Mark Harrison, the Arizona lawyer who leads the commission, stresses that the draft is tentative and partial. Plainly, other critical issues still loom -- not least of which is the festering scandal of the well-attended, expense-paid judicial seminars that are held at nice resorts and underwritten by private interests bent on influencing judicial decisions. The commission still has time to do the right thing, but its proposals so far are not very reassuring.

LENGTH: 1125 words

HEADLINE: The Bus Stops Here (and, Often, at the Pump)

BYLINE: By LEONARD M. APCAR

DATELINE: SCARSDALE, N.Y. 

 BODY:
THE neighborhood association met recently to discuss the usual complexities of suburban life, like trash pickups and leaf collection, and inevitably the talk got around to dropoffs and pickups at the elementary school.
 The narrow old streets around the school have become crowded and potentially dangerous. It can be frightening to behold mothers one-handing their sport utilities while clutching their cellphones -- illegally, in New York State -- especially when you consider their less than ideal vision to the rear and sides of their rigs.
 This makes it all too easy to miss seeing a first-grader who has stepped off the curb, looking for a ride home. (Hardly any children walk to or from school these days, not when they can be chauffeured in fancy trucks with leather seats, DVD players and four-wheel drive.) 
 Big sport utilities have their place, but when a 2004 Nissan Armada test truck arrived in my narrow driveway, it seemed out of area. While the hulking Armada may be at home on lonely West Texas highways, it seems grossly oversized for car pooling in Westchester County.
 Derived from the Nissan Titan pickup, the Armada is longer than any sport utility save the Chevrolet Suburban (a foot longer) or the Ford Excursion (20 inches longer).
 That makes for a very big S.U.V., a first for Nissan. The Armada has more than 10 inches of ground clearance in four-wheel-drive trim, so a first-grader may have to pull himself up and over the running boards. And while a mom at the wheel has heaven-high visibility, there are still those blind spots. At least the Armada's more expensive relative, the Infiniti QX56, can be ordered with a video monitor that lets you know Johnny has dashed behind the truck.
 I took the Armada to a meeting at the high school, where I had to wrestle it into a parking space. (I succeeded on the third attempt). Around town, the truck's sheer scale and bulky design made me feel as if I were steering the Incredible Hulk.
 The Armada's Paul Bunyan looks, which are presumably a big part of the appeal of the $36,000-plus package, had me scratching my head. Nissan has, of late, had one of the hottest design studios in the business, with a fresh eye for making cars and crossover wagons look different and desirable. 
 A few Nissan family traits are stamped on the Armada: the swooping curve over the side windows; the large, intricate headlamps and taillights; and the thickly drawn sheet metal with pronounced curves and bulges. Like the Titan, the Armada has a bold front end that you won't soon forget. 
 Still, it gives you a jolt to see these strokes on a canvas so large. Had the artists behind the saucy Murano, the organic Altima or the fluid Maxima signed off on this? I never warmed to the Armada's styling, or that of the QX56 that I drove later around Southern California. [Review, Page 4.] 
 I much prefer the somewhat more compact -- though still large --Dodge Durango, which was restyled this year. But I encountered plenty of others who liked the Armada/Infiniti duo, especially the trucks' grandiose proportions and he-manliness.
 With record gasoline prices and sales of big S.U.V.'s declining, at least temporarily, this might not be the best time to introduce a pair of heavy, thirsty trucks that flaunt their bulk. Of course, development of the Armada and QX56 began several years ago, when the world was a different place and a lot of truck buyers were not at all concerned about an economy rating of 13 m.p.g. in town and 18 on the highway. (My actual mileage, in combined city-highway use, was 14.) Filling the 28-gallon tank -- regular grade will do -- can cost $60.
 So far, the Armada is not sailing out of showrooms, with dealer inventories at a 118-day supply, about twice the desirable level. Ron Pinelli, president of Autodata, a consulting firm in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., said that with Nissan's competitors, especially General Motors, offering huge sales incentives, it was difficult to squeeze into the market. ''I don't think the Armada brings all that much to the table that is all that unique,'' he said.
 Still, there is plenty to like. It seats seven or eight in three rows, depending on whether you get captain chairs or a bench in the middle row. The long wheelbase provides exceptional room, especially for legs in the second row. But it can be hard to reach into the waist-high cargo floor.
 On a wet dirt road in the Hamptons, the Armada easily rolled through sand, gravel and puddles without jostling the sightseers on board. On the highway, it was sure-footed and nicely composed even on long S-curves.
 Its 5.6-liter V-8 (305 horsepower) had plenty of power to haul its 5,300 pounds. Wide open on expressways, the Armada, whose five-speed automatic transmission is a rarity in this class, never showed a sign of strain. In a zero to 60 test, Car and Driver clocked the Armada at an impressive 7 seconds.
 Rear drive is standard, but Nissan offers four-wheel drive (albeit a system without the full-time, dry-pavement setting available on competitive Chevys, GMC's and Dodges). The braking and steering were sure and precise. 
 The Armada produced more wind noise than I expected. On stretches with roadway seams, vibration made its way through the suspension and into the passenger space.
 The Armada is not flashy inside, but plainly functional, though it has luxury touches like amber dash lighting, contrasting textures with minimalist lines and 10 cup holders (plus four bottle holders in the doors, including one that can handle a 64-ounce container). You can fold the front passenger seat to provide still more cup holders and a work surface. Storage spaces are plentiful and cleverly done.
 One miss: Three knobs adjust the cabin temperature, with red indicator lights for the setting. The tiny red slits are hard to see in daylight. 
 For rollover protection, Nissan says the long wheelbase -- seven inches longer than the Chevy Tahoe's -- enhances stability. All Armadas come with side curtain air bags that protect all three rows of seats; side bags in the front seats are optional. 
 Compared with the Durango and the Ford Expedition, the Armada is generally roomier and competitive even with the high-end optional engines of some other S.U.V.'s. Ford has greatly improved its Expedition and earned a top rating in safety crash tests. The more expensive Lincoln Navigator is more luxurious and more expensive. But I found the Durango easier to maneuver, quite comfortable and less imposing on city streets. The trade-off, of course, is that it is not as roomy.
 Would I take my kids to school in an Armada? Not a chance. Buses serve just fine, and at least their drivers aren't gabbing on cellphones.

INSIDE TRACK: With this Armada, the Spanish might have conquered the world.

HEADLINE: A Fireman Off Duty, Still Listening for Fires

BYLINE: Compiled by C.J. Satterwhite And Michael Molyneux

 BODY:

THE LAST MEN OUT:
Life on the Edgeat Rescue 2 Firehouse
By Tom Downey
Henry Holt
($25, hardcover)
 There's no ''Welcome to New York City'' sign, but Bob realizes he's crossed the border when the buildings get bigger, the air dirtier, the drivers crazier. Passing Exit 24 on the Grand Central Parkway and crossing into Queens, he reaches for the power switch on his Radio Shack scanner. The Fire Department bandwidth will tell him what he's missing. He's buffing: listening to the department radio when he's not working, just for kicks. 
 Some civilian buffs spend their weekends speeding around the city, scanners in hand, trying to catch a glimpse of the firemen at work. Each borough has a frequency of its own, except for the eternally fireless Staten Island, which shares one with the Bronx. Bob tunes in to Brooklyn, and the first static crackle tells him that Rescue 2 is heading out:
 ''Three-ten to Brooklyn, let's give a 10-75 to start with.'' Engine 310 is calling Brooklyn with a job.
 Nice and casual, Bob thinks, 10-75 to start with. As if there might be something bigger to come.

THE ART OF THE STEAL:
Inside the Sotheby's-Christie's Auction House Scandal
By Christopher Mason
Putnam
($26.95, hardcover)
 The room was packed, partly due to feverish interest in the 16 Havemeyer pictures and in the other first-rate works of art in the sale by Monet, Klee, Picasso, Leger and Renoir. News of the magnificent lineup of museum-quality paintings had prompted 25,000 visitors to file through the company's York Avenue galleries the weekend before the sale -- the largest number in the firm's history.
 Nevertheless, many of Sotheby's staffers were feeling jittery. The art market was still in the grip of a recession that had dragged on for two years, and some executives feared that the company's ongoing bitter struggle with Swid and Cogan might cast a pall over the proceedings.
 John Marion was feeling confident. Earlier that day he had received a call from his senior colleagues in London, wishing him the very best of luck.
 ''I have a feeling I'm not just going to sell the pictures tonight,'' Marion replied. ''I'm going to sell the company.''
 The excitement of the crowd was palpable from the moment Marion rose to the podium to take up his gavel at 7 o'clock. ''There was an electricity about the room,'' he marveled. ''The bids were absolutely crackling, like rifle shots coming: Bam! Bam! Bam! People started applauding the first time we hit a million. And I said, 'We're going to go there a lot of times tonight.''' 
 The wildly successful sale also sent a powerful message to collectors and dealers that New York had replaced London as the international center of the art market.

SHUT UP HE EXPLAINED:
The Memoir of a Blacklisted Kid
By Kate Lardner
Ballantine
($23.95, hardcover)
 When my father said good-bye to prison he was given an overcoat at government expense -- a navy officer's black winter coat with a detachable lining and some slight imperfection, and whenever he wore it he remembered leaving the place.
 Granny and Albert were waiting at the gate. They drove my father to Uncle John's apartment in New York City and after a while Granny, visibly happy that my dad was over the whole ordeal, indicated she wanted to return to New Milford.
 What a relief for her not to have the strain of those visits anymore, thought my father. They said good-bye not knowing how long it would be before seeing each other again. From Uncle John's on West 12th Street my father went to East 10th, where Dalton and Cleo Trumbo were occupying half of the house belonging to the writers Donald Ogden Stewart and Ella Winter. An old brownstone with large rooms, high ceilings, chandeliers and fireplaces, and a small garden out back, in the heart of Greenwich Village.
 Trumbo had been released from his institution the week before, and Cleo came from California to meet him. The three of them had midday drinks and talked about the uncertainties of the future. The whole situation had gotten much worse. Senator Joseph McCarthy had appeared on the scene.

WILLIAM SLOANE COFFIN JR.:
A Holy Impatience
By Warren Goldstein
Yale University Press
($30, hardcover)
 One day in early 1977 the phone rang in Strafford, Vt. From the New York City headquarters of the United Church of Christ, Valerie Russell was calling her old friend and mentor Bill Coffin. ''I've been asked by the Black Christian Caucus at Riverside Church to talk to you.'' 
 Coffin interrupted: ''So how many of you are there? All four of you talking in one voice?'' 
 Her reply -- ''No, we make up 39 percent of the congregation'' -- got him thinking. Unruffled, she continued: ''As you can imagine, our preference would have been for Andy Young, because he could have kept the whites. But seeing as Andy Young is at the U.N., we decided we'd like you to become minister, because you could keep the blacks.'' Suddenly Coffin had become a serious candidate for the pulpit of the flagship church of American mainline Protestantism.

CAN'T TAKE IT WITH YOU:
The Art of Making and Giving Money
By Lewis B. Cullman
John Wiley & Sons
($29.95, hardcover)
 The board was meeting in my office at 767 Third Avenue, discussing our new-found success when I made a radical proposal. The people I contacted hadn't bought the tables to support the American Chess Federation in general, I said. They'd bought the tables primarily to support the new chess program.
 The program had become our public face; it was what excited the outside world, especially those in a position to help fund us. Why didn't we put our name where our money was, and retitle the foundation Chess-in-the-Schools? (Maybe I was better at corporate branding than I realized.)
 ''Holy smoke! Oh, my heavens, no!'' came the response. By and large, the old guard was absolutely horrified. A few years later, though, I was elected chairman of the foundation, and in 1997 we officially changed the name. As I sit here, Chess-in-the-Schools is teaching the game and much more to some 38,000 elementary and junior-high students in all five boroughs of New York City.

HEADLINE: Tracking the Sale of a Kidney On a Path of Poverty and Hope

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: RECIFE, Brazil 

 BODY:
When Alberty Jose da Silva heard he could make money, lots of money, by selling his kidney, it seemed to him the opportunity of a lifetime. For a desperately ill 48-year-old woman in Brooklyn whose doctors had told her to get a kidney any way she could, it was.
 At 38, Mr. da Silva, one of 23 children of a prostitute, lives in a slum near the airport here, in a flimsy two-room shack he shares with a sister and nine other people. 
 ''As a child, I can remember seven of us sharing a single egg, or living for day after day on just a bit of manioc meal with salt,'' Mr. da Silva said in an interview. 
 He recalled his mother as a woman who ''sold her flesh'' to survive. Last year he decided that he would, too. Now, a long scar across his side marks the place where a kidney and a rib were removed in exchange for $6,000, paid by middlemen in an international organ trafficking ring. 
 Among poor men like Mr. da Silva and others who have migrated to slums here from Brazil's parched northeastern backlands, word of the market to sell their organs spread quickly. 
 Some who had done so were already buying houses, businesses, cars and refrigerators. 
 The sums being offered seemed a fortune. The minimum wage here is barely $80 a month, and work is hard to find. Many men struggle to exist on odd jobs that pay barely a dollar a day. Initially, the organ brokers paid as much as $10,000 for a kidney -- more than a decade's wages.
 Donors and recipients were not related, in contrast to the usual preference for legal and medical reasons. In fact, they did not even know each other. But they were linked by a trafficking ring that the authorities now say exploited two very different sets of needs -- for money and for life itself -- at opposite ends of a tangled chain thousands of miles long.
 Tracing the journey of Mr. da Silva's kidney through that chain, which spanned four continents and ended in a one-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn, reveals the inner workings of a network that human rights groups say is by no means unique. Rather, they say, it is representative of a global black market for organs, including livers, kidneys and lungs, that touches dozens of countries and generates many millions of dollars a year. 
 In Alberty da Silva's case, the authorities here say, the organ's odyssey began with two middlemen based in this gritty port city of 1.5 million people: Gedalya Tauber, a former Israeli police officer, and his partner, Ivan Bonifacio da Silva, a retired Brazilian military police officer. 
 The pair, since jailed on organ trafficking charges, not only handed out cash payments, the authorities say, but also arranged for the medical exams to weed out unqualified donors. They then obtained passports and airline tickets for the donors to travel to South Africa, where the transplants took place. Both countries have laws against commercial trade in organs.
 ''Six grand is a lot of money, especially when you don't have any,'' Mr. da Silva said when asked why he had given up his kidney. ''No one here warned us that what we were doing was illegal.''

Get a Kidney, or Expect to Die
 The American woman who received Mr. da Silva's kidney initially worried that what she was doing might be illegal. She described herself as deeply religious and concerned with the ethics of transplants.
 But during an interview in April she also recalled the long years of suffering that made her take the risk of seeking an organ on the international market. The decision to go abroad for a kidney, she said at her third-floor walk-up apartment in Brooklyn, was not an easy one, but necessary nonetheless.
 ''I had been on dialysis for 15 years and on two transplant lists for 7,'' said the woman, who asked not to be identified by name, for fear of losing support payments vital to maintaining the health of her transplanted organ. ''Nothing was happening, and my health was getting worse and worse.'' Finally, she said, ''my doctors told me to get a kidney any way I could,'' or expect to die.
 She took their warning seriously. The years of dialysis had left her with worsening heart and lung problems. She also suffered from severe osteoporosis. ''I had seen four other ladies that I knew pass away'' while they waited for kidney donors, she said.
 More than 3,300 Americans died last year awaiting kidney transplants, and the Brooklyn woman was among 85,000 people on waiting lists in the United States, 60,000 of them in need of kidneys. The average wait can be five years, says the United Network for Organ Sharing, a nonprofit transplant information clearinghouse in Richmond, Va.
 It is illegal in the United States to pay a donor for an organ. But Nancy Scheper-Hughes of Organs Watch, a human rights group in Berkeley, Calif., that has long tracked the illegal organ trade and denounced abuses, says irregularities still occur. 
 ''It is a common practice of many larger clinics to advertise on the Internet for transplant tourists, so we're up to our necks in it,'' Dr. Scheper-Hughes said. Transplant doctors, she says, have developed a ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy. 
 The World Health Organization issued guidelines in 1991 to avoid the coercion or exploitation of organ donors. They were endorsed by 192 countries, including the United States, Brazil and South Africa. But the guidelines are not binding, and the recommendations have been widely ignored. At least one country, Iran, has a legally regulated system to trade organs.
 As medical science advances and health care increasingly becomes a marketplace transaction, a fierce debate about commercializing transplants has emerged.
 On one side, said Alexander M. Capron, the director of the ethics department of the World Health Organization, are ''transplant surgeons who believe that a good way to remedy the shortage of organs would be to offer payments,'' and bioethicists and philosophers who see organ trade as an extension of the principle of autonomy.
 But an opposing group, Mr. Capron said, ''fears that the line between selling organs and actually selling people is a rather fine one'' and that, as in sex trafficking, the marketplace is one in which coercion and exploitation may be unavoidable. 
 In the case of the Brooklyn woman, her husband had relatives in Israel who had heard of a syndicate that brokered transplants, and reached out to them. The woman and her husband said that relatives and the brokers reassured them that an operation abroad would be perfectly legal.
 ''I felt helpless, because she was going to die,'' said the woman's husband, who is in such fragile health himself that he receives disability payments. ''Helping her get that kidney was the best thing that I have ever done for anyone in my entire life.''

'Mr. Big' or 'the Wrong Guy'?
 The syndicate that organized the American woman's transplant, the authorities say, also arranged kidney transfers for at least 100 Israelis. It was led, they say, by a 52-year-old organ broker in Israel, Ilan Peri.
 ''He's Mr. Big, the one who started the whole thing,'' Johan Wessels, a forensic investigator in South Africa who works for the Department of Health in KwaZulu-Natal Province and has had access to hospital records there, said in Durban.
 Mr. Peri works out of a Tel Aviv suburb through a company called TechCom. He faces charges of tax evasion in Israel, accused of improperly declaring nearly $4 million said to have been earned as an organ broker and is also under investigation in connection with inflating the invoices that he did submit to Israeli health care programs. 
 When reached by telephone in Tel Aviv and asked to comment on the charges, Mr. Peri said: ''I have never been involved in kidney transplants. You are talking to the wrong guy.'' He eventually hung up the telephone, but not before amending his statement. ''I'm not involved in that anymore, so I can't help you,'' he said.
 To those who monitor organ trafficking, it was no surprise that Israel should emerge as the focal point of a syndicate. Organ donation rates in Israel are among the lowest in the developed world, about one-third the rate in Western Europe, in large part because of what Health Ministry officials and doctors describe as a widespread impression that Jewish religious law prohibits transplants as a ''desecration of the body.''
 In reality, religious law is far more nuanced. But influential Orthodox rabbis have been reluctant to make public statements that would encourage either live donors or the harvesting of organs from the deceased.
 Israelis needing transplants have suffered as a result. More than 1,000 people in a nation of about 6 million are on Israel's waiting list for organs, more than half of them for kidneys. The list grows by more than 20 percent each year, health officials say. In an average year, more than 80 people die waiting, proportionally a slightly higher rate than in the United States. 
 To meet Israeli's growing demand for organs, middlemen calling themselves brokers, from prominent doctors to a former spokesman for a health maintenance organization, have rushed into the market to set prices for a scarce product that can reach $150,000 for a kidney. Some advertise openly in Israeli newspapers and on radio stations, soliciting recipients and donors.
 ''As of today, there is no law in Israel that forbids trafficking in human organs,'' Meir Broder, a legal adviser to the Health Ministry, explained in an interview in Jerusalem. ''There is no criminal aspect at all.''
 A bill drafted by the Health Ministry that would make trafficking illegal and forbid organ donations for money awaits action in the Parliament. But medical specialists say it faces strong opposition and may not pass.
 For now, allowing the brokers to operate with few restrictions in effect benefits the state by exporting Israel's organ shortage overseas. The patients who do go abroad ''save the country a lot of money,'' explained Dr. Michael Friedlaender, a kidney specialist at Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem, ''not only in terms of what doesn't have to be spent on dialysis, but also by opening places for other people who are on the list.''
 For operations in Israel, the Ministry of Health relies on elaborate procedures to ensure that donors and recipients act for ''altruistic'' motives and do not exchange money. But another ministry directive also allows Israelis who go abroad for transplants to be reimbursed as much as $80,000. 
 Much of the remaining costs can often be obtained from insurance plans, though Israeli health maintenance organizations are supposed to ask for proof when donors and recipients say they are related in ''voluntary'' operations. 
 Israeli doctors say those requirements are often ignored, and the government says it has no obligation to monitor operations done abroad. ''In the end, a country can only be responsible for what happens within its own borders,'' said Mr. Broder, the Ministry of Health lawyer.
 In the mid-1990's, many of the Israeli organ brokers took their patients to Turkey, flying in teams of Israeli surgeons and relying on donors from Moldova, Romania and Russia. But after some patients died and Dr. Scheper-Hughes of Organs Watch and the Turkish and European news media raised ethical questions, the brokers were forced to search for new locations.
 For both the medical expertise available and its low costs, South Africa emerged as a logical alternative.

The South African Connection
 It was there, in South Africa, the authorities say, that Mr. Peri's ring brought together Mr. da Silva and the woman who ultimately received his kidney.
 After long negotiations in Israel, which she said were conducted by relatives of her husband, the Brooklyn woman flew to South Africa for a transplant. Because of her unusual circumstances, it cost her just over $60,000, which other kidney recipients who dealt with Mr. Peri said was less than half the price the syndicate usually charged.
 Even so, that amount was 10 times the payment Mr. da Silva received, though organ recipients in Israel said Mr. Peri routinely told them that the Brazilian donors were being paid $25,000.
 While money initially motivated Mr. da Silva to sell his kidney, he said he also came to be moved by the chance to help a stranger. The change, he said, occurred after he, too, arrived in South Africa, his first trip out of Brazil, in what he saw as an adventure that would allow him to see lions, giraffes and elephants.
 Instead, after 10 hours of flying last August, Mr. da Silva found himself in Durban, a resort city of 1.4 million on the Indian Ocean, where he was shuttled to a safe house. Later, at St. Augustine's Hospital, he met the American woman and learned of her long ordeal.
 ''It's hard for me to imagine how a person might feel when a relative is about to die, so I don't blame anybody for trying anything to get a new kidney,'' Mr. da Silva said. 
 He said he also made friends with hospital orderlies and a nurse called Mama Tchuka. Mr. da Silva said hospital employees joked openly about the illegal nature of the transplants and the fact that he and the woman receiving his kidney were of different ethnic backgrounds and could not even speak each other's language. 
 ''It was only when I got to South Africa and was told to sign a document saying that the recipient of my kidney was my cousin that I realized that something was wrong,'' Mr. da Silva said. ''But by then it was too late to turn back.''
 In interviews, Mr. da Silva and several other of the Brazilian men who donated organs said they were treated well in South Africa. But investigators say the donors did not get the same quality of care as the Israelis who received their organs.
 The Israelis, for example, like the American woman, were lodged in beachfront hotels before the operation and, afterward, kept under intense observation and given detailed records to be handed over to their doctors back home. The donors, by contrast, were monitored ''for a maximum of three days,'' Mr. Wessels, the South African investigator, said. Some of that time, they were not even in the hospital, but at the safe house the syndicate rented.
 ''Then they were put on a plane without much further ado,'' he said. 
 Based on a detailed study of confiscated records, South African authorities say the kidney transfer between Mr. da Silva and the Brooklyn woman was one of more than 100 suspect transplants performed in less than two years at St. Augustine's.
 Today, the director of the kidney transplant unit there, Lindy Dickson, and another employee, Melanie Azor, are among seven people arrested and charged with acting on behalf of the illegal organ ring. Government officials say more indictments are on the way. ''Not all the invitation cards have been sent out yet,'' Barent Groen, the chief government prosecutor in the case, said in an interview in Durban.
 Also arrested was Shushan Meir, an Israeli-born South African who authorities said acted as a middleman for Mr. Peri, the Israeli broker.
 ''He visited transplant clinics in Durban, Johannesburg and Cape Town,'' Mr. Wessels said of Mr. Peri, ''and correspondence shows that he was in touch with the doctors and the transplant clinic staff here. The impression I get is that he was making sure his investment was running smoothly.''
 At a court hearing, Mr. Meir said that beyond the 100 or so transplants done in Durban, he had organized ''probably about 35'' more in Johannesburg. But South African investigators estimate that the actual number is probably closer to 200, divided among hospitals in Johannesburg and Cape Town.
 All the hospitals under investigation belong to the same private health care chain, Netcare, which on its Web site boasts of ''aiming to uphold South Africa's reputation as 'the transplant capital of the world.' '' Since the mid-1990's, the company has been buying up facilities like St. Augustine's, originally a Catholic missionary hospital, and demanding a strong bottom-line performance.
 Netcare's chief executive officer, Michael Sacks, declined a request for an interview. Through a press spokeswoman, Martina Nicholson, Netcare has denied conscious involvement in any wrongdoing.
 ''We do not know of anything untoward having taken place at all,'' Ms. Nicholson said. ''We still firmly believe that there has been no transgression at any of our hospitals or by any of our staff members.''
 With operatives of Mr. Peri's syndicate now jailed in Brazil and South Africa, and Mr. Peri under pressure in Israel, his ring has apparently been smashed. But the transplant waiting list in Israel continues to grow, and recent reports from kidney specialists say Israeli organ brokers have appeared in China, among other places.
 ''This is obviously a well-oiled syndicate that knows how to move from one country to another,' R. W. Green-Thompson, superintendent general of the KwaZulu-Natal provincial department of health, said in an interview in Durban. ''I'm sure that this problem will pop up again in another country soon. The only question is which one.''

Unexpected Consequences
 These days, Mr. da Silva works 44 hours a week as a security guard, but still earns less than $175 a month, money that is the sole support for the 10 other people he lives with. Even that income was jeopardized when he and other kidney donors were arrested and briefly jailed early this year on suspicion of violating Brazilian laws against trading in human organs. He and more than a score of other donors still faced criminal charges here.
 In the 18 months that ended last November, when the authorities shut down the ring, so many residents from the slums of Recife had volunteered that the middlemen had begun offering just $3,000 for a healthy kidney.
 All told, the police in Brazil estimate that about 100 men, nearly all poor or unemployed, ages 20 to 40, agreed to sell kidneys. Though some would eventually be rejected for having an unusual blood type, frail health or signs of drug use, more than 60 men are believed to have gone to South Africa.
 Recife and its slums had become so lucrative a source for organs, in fact, that Brazilian investigators believe that by late 2003, Israeli brokers, in an effort to swell their earnings further, were considering moving their operations to hospitals here and in other nearby cities.
 With poverty offering up an unquenchable pool of volunteers, the local authorities say the ring had also begun inquiring about buying other vital organs from poor residents, including lungs, livers and corneas.
 ''Even after all of this fuss, I'd do it again,'' said Orley de Santana, a 26-year-old laborer, who went to South Africa but was unable to sell his kidney for $6,000 before the police broke up the ring. ''In order not to have to steal or kill, I thought it better to sell my kidney.''
 Among the men who did give up a kidney, some say they have experienced health problems that no one warned them about. 
 ''For me, the complications began almost immediately,'' said Jose Carlos da Conceicao da Silva, 24, a day laborer who hauls produce. He said he required a second operation in South Africa on a lung three days after his kidney was removed. Since returning to Brazil his health has worsened, he said.
 ''I'm tired all the time and can't lift heavy weights, which I have to be able to do if people are going to hire me,'' he said. ''My blood pressure goes up and down, and I feel pain and numbness where the scar from the operation is.''
 Worse still, after his flight back to Brazil, Mr. da Silva, who is not related to Alberty da Silva, said he was robbed of nearly all of the $6,000 he was paid for his kidney when he went to Sao Paulo during a layover on his flight home. ''I begged and pleaded for them not to take the money, telling them that I had sold my kidney abroad and showing them the scar,'' he recalled, near tears.
 Another donor, Rogerio Bezerra da Silva, not related to the others, also lost his kidney and his cash, which South African authorities confiscated after the ring was exposed late last year, and is now the object of mockery in his slum neighborhood. 
 On occasion, Alberty da Silva says, he shows pictures of his trip to South Africa to the neighborhood children. During the interview, he showed them to a reporter, too, including some of him in Durban with the woman who received his kidney. He also displayed a letter she later wrote, thanking him for ''the gift of life.''
 The American woman continues to correspond with him and, though hardly wealthy herself, says she intends to send cash gifts each Christmas and on his birthday.
 ''They never want you to see the donor,'' she said of the traffickers. ''But I kept insisting that we meet because I know that he is now part of my being. I have a piece of him inside of me, so who wouldn't want that bond?''

HEADLINE: Give Her Your Tired CD's: Greta's Back in Business

BYLINE: By STEVEN KURUTZ

 BODY:
For years, Greta Perr worked as a clerk in a used-CD store called Sounds on St. Marks Place. While she wasn't as widely known as the bands whose albums she bought and sold, in time she developed a cult following. In the slightly covert world that deals in used CD's, the clued-in knew to go see Greta. 
 On Thursdays through Saturdays, loyal sellers lined up while Ms. Perr performed the mysterious calculations of record store economics.
 ''Thirty-five dollars cash or $50 in store credit,'' she'd say. ''I'll take the cash,'' nearly everyone answered. 
 Last year, a group of three employees that included Ms. Perr, 39, who had spent more than a decade there, were laid off, and she disappeared into the cityscape. 
 So it is with great relief that people have begun spotting Ms. Perr on the West Side, smoking cigarettes outside a new and used CD shop on Ninth Avenue near 52nd Street in Hell's Kitchen called Future Legend. It turned out that not long after leaving Sounds, she opened the shoebox-shaped store in partnership with Paul Ruggiero, 36, whom she befriended while they were students at the High School of Art and Design in Manhattan because they were both David Bowie fans. The store is named after a Bowie song.
 ''I'm working seven days a week,'' Ms. Perr said the other day, ''but it's for myself now. On the days I'm sick, I wonder what I'm missing. It's like an adventure.'' 
 Growing up, Ms. Perr was surrounded by music. Her father did publicity for Capitol Records and then Elektra Records, and she bounced between New York and California. She fondly recalls seeing the Stooges, the Flaming Groovies and Alice Cooper in concert when she was 6; Mr. Ruggiero says he is constantly amazed at her encyclopedic musical knowledge. 
 ''Sometimes I'll ask Greta questions I know the answer to, just to test her,'' he said. ''She always gets them.'' 
 Reflecting on her renown as a CD buyer, Ms. Perr attributes her popularity to the fact that she is, as she puts it, ''fast and fair.'' She said she didn't miss her East Village location, but she did miss some of the old customers. ''I never asked anyone who they were or what they did so I had no way of contacting them,'' Ms. Perr explained.
 Lately, though, people have begun to rediscover Ms. Perr, among them Clayton James, a physical trainer from the Upper West Side who searched up and down the West Side to find her.
 During his latest visit, they discussed the new Loretta Lynn album. ''Greta was hesitant to recommend that one,'' he said. ''She hadn't made up her mind yet.'' STEVEN KURUTZ


GRAPHIC: Photo: Got a question? Greta Perr at Future Legend probably has an answer. (Photo by Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Catholic Parishes in Jersey City Are Told to Consolidate, Again

BYLINE: By JASON GEORGE

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, May 21 

 BODY:
There was a time when a person could stand on Sixth Street and hear dueling organs swelling from back-to-back Catholic churches, and it all made sense.
 Faithful Italians would gather on one end of the block at Holy Rosary Church, which bills itself as New Jersey's first Italian parish. Devout Poles would fill the building abutting it, St. Anthony of Padua Church, which, as the oldest Polish Roman Catholic parish in the city, once boasted a congregation of more than 10,000.
 But now both churches stand on the hushed street like sentinels, quietly guarding a time that has long since left Jersey City. The buildings have remained there for more than a century, a steady and persistent presence, even as their congregants proved far less reliable, with many picking up their roots in the years soon after World War II and drifting away to the suburbs of Bergen County and beyond. 
 ''A lot of people simply moved away,'' said James Fisher, co-director of the Center for American Catholic Studies at Fordham University. ''An awful lot of people.''
 Because of that exodus, the demographic changes that followed, and other trends, the Archdiocese of Newark has proposed a plan that would have both churches meld into the nearby Parish of the Resurrection. But, reflecting just how severe the drain of Catholics has been from the city over all, Resurrection itself comprises five churches, merged in 1997 because of dwindling attendance and the meager contents of collection baskets. Where once more than half the city's population was reported to be Roman Catholic and seven parishes could thrive, the seven could become one, using just three houses of worship.
 Altogether, the archdiocese would like to realign or merge 48 churches in the 235-parish diocese, and more changes and closures could follow. The plan is a reflection of the dwindling forces of the Catholic Church in the region that includes Hudson, Bergen, Essex and Union Counties. But it is also a story that has played out in city after city, neighborhood after neighborhood, around the country as the church has tried to adjust to changing times.
 Last Tuesday, the Rev. Rino Lavaroni, pastor at Holy Rosary, spent the morning in the rain clearing brush from behind the church that had become his home only nine months earlier. When a small church was built here in 1885, Italians were still a small percentage of the immigrants who were arriving in waves to double Jersey City's population every decade from the 1830's. That would change, and by 1903 the little church was replaced by the imposing sandstone building that sits there today. 
 For Father Lavaroni there is little time to gaze in the rearview mirror, reflecting on a time when the pews were packed and the church's street fair was legendary in the neighborhood. ''The numbers are down,'' he admitted. ''They have gotten out of these neighborhoods.
 ''Thank God,'' he said, looking over the area that in recent years has been wounded by crime and too little reason to hope. Still, those same forces make his job tough. ''I'm trying to reach out to this area,'' he said.
 The area is called downtown Jersey City, although historians have argued that the city has not had a distinctive downtown since the Dutch rowed across the Hudson River to establish a colony here in 1630. Instead, Jersey City became a city of industry that defined its neighborhoods by railway yards, factories and shipping docks. 
 The immigrants who arrived at America's Golden Door, as the city was called, would shuffle off to tenements and work long hours at unskilled jobs. The first were the Irish. A survey in 1860 found 55 percent of Irish men worked unskilled jobs, while the Irish only accounted for 37 percent of the population then. But by 1917, when Frank Hague, an Irish Catholic mayor who would rule Jersey City with an iron fist and a greased palm for 30 years, took office, the Irish immigrants and their Catholic churches had emerged as the city's ruling class.
 ''The public employees would shovel the snow in front of the Catholic schools,'' Mr. Fisher said. ''All the aspirations of the Irish Catholics rose with Mayor Hague.''
 By the end of Mr. Hague's term, the Italians and Poles had replaced the Germans and Irish as the majority. In 1960, of the 610,000 people living in Jersey City, there were more than 83,000 people who considered themselves Italian, up from 187 a century before.
 Change would come again. Beginning in the late 1950's, the children and grandchildren of the immigrants who worked so hard to turn Jersey City into the second largest city in New Jersey began leaving, as the jobs did. 
 ''In the 50's and 60's, a tremendous number of the so-called white ethnics moved away to the neighboring counties,'' Mr. Fisher said. In their wake came African-Americans and Puerto Ricans, who together accounted for 25 percent of the city's population by 1970. 
 But during those years of disappearing jobs and limited opportunities came a new kind of poverty and street-level crime, and the first visible signs that the Catholic churches were falling on hard times, as well. 
 ''The falloff started in the 1950's and 60's, and the late 60's were probably the worst of times,'' said the Very Rev. Gregory Studerus, pastor of the Resurrection parish.
 The economic decay in the community was evident in the peeling paint of the area's Catholic churches. It continued until a public works project near the seven churches gutted, cleared and rebuilt more than 100 homes in the early 1980's, said Father Studerus. But the new houses were not filled by returning European families. Rather, the next wave was of immigrants from Southeast and South Asia. 
 The community soon came to consist of those new immigrants. Over all, there were far fewer Catholics than there had been before.
 Father Lavaroni said he was well aware that Italians no longer inhabited the apartments surrounding Holy Rosary in the numbers that they did before. But, he said, he still believes the church can turn the corner toward renewal. Attendance at Sunday Mass is about 300 now -- an increase, he said. And the church is adapting: besides English, Italian and Latin, one Mass is offered in Chinese. He has hopes that the church can survive and, while the archdiocese spends the next 18 months working out the ultimate fates of the churches on its list, he plans to push ahead with plans for Holy Rosary. 
 ''They are all CEO's,'' he said, referring to the task force of pastors, pastoral associates and parishioners that came up with the recommendations for the Archdiocese. ''I'm a sociologist, so I know you have to take a good picture of the situation, but they didn't look. These people never came to see the reality.''
 Next door, at St. Anthony's, the pastor, the Rev. Joseph Urban, has other plans on his mind. The church is trying to organize a celebration for its 120th anniversary next month. He, too, sees signs of hope. He said he has already seen attendance on Sunday grow to 300 people from about 40 in the last three years, though it is still nowhere near the 10,000 congregants of the past. Standing in the nave of his church last week he conceded that he should probably be doing more. ''We know we need to develop our activities and improve,'' he said. But, ''More people are coming.''
 The neighborhood has already tried to deal with its shrinking Catholic population by reorganizing some of its churches. In 1997, Resurrection parish was formed to consolidate parish activities, like social and educational services, and to save money for five churches within blocks of each other: St. Bridget's, St. Mary's, St. Michael's, St. Peter's and St. Boniface.
 St. Bridget's had dipped to a congregation of 650 just before the merger, down from 6,000 in 1910. St. Mary's, only seven blocks away, had slipped to 1,180 in 1997 from 7,500 members in 1910. Both churches offer religious services in up to four different languages, two for the growing Asian population in the area. Asians account for more than 17 percent of Jersey City's population, up from 4 percent in 1980, according to census data.
 The third church in the Resurrection parish, St. Michael's, has maintained attendance figures stronger than Holy Rosary's and St. Anthony's, largely because it has integrated these newer immigrants, said Father Studerus. Originally a church for Irish and German dockworkers, St. Michael's is now home to the Vietnamese Apostolate and offers Mass in English, Spanish, Vietnamese and Tagalog, a language mostly spoken in the Philippines. Last Tuesday night, members of the Apostolate gathered and sang prayers in Vietnamese to St. Jude, patron saint of hopeless causes, which echoed off the gilded cathedral ceiling. Later, the Rev. Joseph Minh said Mass in English for 14 congregants, half of whom were Vietnamese.
 Iris Perez, who has attended St. Michael's for more than 15 years, said that when Vietnamese parishioners began appearing at the church in large numbers about three years ago, there was talk then, too, of how it would affect the church. But not anymore, she said. ''Honestly, they are the ones keeping the church alive.''
 Should the consolidation plan go through, Holy Rosary and St. Anthony's would be absorbed into St. Michael's, three blocks north. But the details of how this would occur -- and what might happen to the buildings -- is unclear.
 ''There is ambiguity in the recommendation they gave us,'' Father Studerus said. ''They're saying there must be a much closer relationship than there is now. It does not necessarily include simply closing the church sites, even though that seems to be a starting-point recommendation.''
 Even as the seven churches are scheduled to be merged into one parish, possibly under three roofs, another church in downtown Jersey City seems to have survived the first round of recommendations. And in that there is either a tale of urban luck or a lesson for the church at large.
 That church, Our Lady of Czestochowa, once served the city's large Polish population. It ceased Polish language Mass in 2001, a year after it adopted the slogan ''Our Lady's Church on the Waterfront,'' to reach out to the new, wealthier residents who were settling nearby in developments along the Jersey City waterfront.
 Polish congregants protested, calling the plan a form of ethnic cleansing and a tasteless ploy. But James Goodness, spokesman for the Newark Archdiocese, said no offense had been meant. 
 ''What they did, however, to kind of encourage people to come, is they did some smart marketing of the parish, saying it was Our Lady's on the Waterfront,'' he said. Attendance there has been climbing. ''Something is working here,'' he said.

It was 276,101. (According to the United States Census, 610,000 was the population for Hudson County as a whole, not just Jersey City.)

ORGANIZATION: FORDHAM UNIVERSITY (55%) Roman Catholic Church; Roman Catholic Church
