SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 1451 words

HEADLINE: Dateless in Seattle

BYLINE: By Walter Kirn. 
Walter Kirn, whose most recent novel is ''Up in the Air,'' is a regular contributor to the Book Review.

 BODY:

TRANSMISSION
By Hari Kunzru.
276 pp. New York:
Dutton. $24.95.
 The problem with tearing a novel from the headlines is that headlines don't last much longer than old newspapers. It's an impossible project anyway, right up there with perfecting perpetual motion. Even if it took no time at all to write a few hundred pages of polished prose, it would still require a score of news cycles to typeset, bind and distribute the physical books. And then folks still have to get around to reading them. There's no way to avoid it: unless they find a wormhole, novelists will stand in relation to the headlines as the French and the Germans do to rock 'n' roll: doomed to play a tin-eared game of catch-up whenever they try to play at all. 
 The fact that all contemporary fiction is now, by definition, historical fiction is hard to deny, but it's much, much harder to face, of course -- particularly for talented young novelists, like Britain's Hari Kunzru, who don't want to cede the present entirely to cable news personalities and Internet posters. Kunzru -- who turned down a prize for his first novel because he felt the London newspaper that sponsored it, The Mail on Sunday, had ''pursued an editorial policy of vilifying and demonizing refugees and asylum-seekers,'' and who went on to win a spot on Granta magazine's prestigious list of the best young British novelists -- is as up-to-date as writers come, with interests in technology, pop culture and the economics of globalization. If anyone deserves a shot at breaching the literary space-time continuum and doing what logic says can't be done, it's Kunzru.
 ''Transmission'' is his brave attempt. Making this exercise in timeliness even tougher than it has to be, the novel revolves around computers, which become obsolete even faster than morning papers. Even when they're hooked up to the Web and continually fed with software updates, computers now go to seed within a year, but put them into the pages of a novel, away from their modems, and the things are stillborn. A plot formed around their latest capabilities and influenced by their current limitations is irrelevant by the time the pages are spell-checked. It's science fiction in reverse.
 Which is why, now more than ever, novels need characters. ''Transmission'' has one very good one, Arjun Mehta, a shy young programmer who grows up in stultifying middle-class India and dreams of emigrating to racy America. Anyone who watched the news last night will instantly understand the humor here and feel for poor Arjun from the beginning. To leave a booming country of high-tech outsourcing for the shrunken horizons of Silicon Valley is to tilt against the megatrends. As Arjun flies west, new visa in his pocket and visions of third-rate TV stars in his head, the jobs he wants are flying east. Sadly, he doesn't see them as they wing past; he only discovers their absence after he lands.
 Arjun's fate plays out from there with a ticktock determinism that points back to Dreiser, Upton Sinclair and the French naturalists. It's a curious attitude to strike these days, when Americans feel that the color of their parachutes is up to them and not the demigods. Kunzru is writing from England, though, remember, where long-view intellectuals still brood over history's chain-link dialectics and humanity's puny impotence. Punch-the-air Tony Robbins-style optimism has never cut it along the Thames, not with the diploma holders, and deluded characters like Arjun who fall for the gospel of wealth and self-improvement are ground up by these dark thinkers to make their bread (which is eaten with jam at Harold Pinter's house). Once Kunzru sets Arjun down on the West Coast and surrounds him with conniving corporate double talkers, soulless strip malls and all the other bad things that orthodox air-conditioned-nightmare satirists have been kicking around for half a century now, the little fellow doesn't have a chance. As a fundamentalist Euro-pessimist, Kunzru simply can't allow him one, lest Arjun find happiness even for a moment (while drinking a Coke at a strip mall, heaven forbid) and call into question the faith's core teaching: the pursuit of the good life equals death, especially when it occurs in California.
 While Arjun suffers his pummeling, drifting in and out of crummy jobs, boning up on lame American slang and finally winding up outside Seattle testing antivirus software for a paranoid numbskull of a boss, there are funny moments of real pathos that make one wish his creator would loosen his handcuffs and let him find his own odd path. To reassure his parents back in India, who believe he's on track for early millionaire-hood, he lies about meeting the likes of David Hasselhoff. After somehow managing to meet a woman, he takes her to a corny Indian movie and misses the fact that his girlfriend is bored to tears. As it happens, the woman isn't even his girlfriend; Arjun, a naive virgin, just thinks she is. The agony of finding out otherwise, and of losing his new job, pushes his story into headline territory, whereupon it begins to break down like an old hard drive.
 Arjun unleashes a killer computer virus -- one that features his favorite Bollywood actress, the seductive Leela Zahir -- in order to try to prevent his being fired. (He hopes to save the day by ultimately stopping it.) Kunzru lucidly, systematically details the virus's progress through the global nervous system, even though nothing crucial would be lost if he merely wrote ''It spread and spread.'' Tom Clancy fans love and require tricky fact sheets because Clancy's plotlines hinge on technicalities that one must puzzle out as they emerge. From this sort of novel, though, readers expect new metaphors, not credible blueprints for world destruction. They want imagery that compresses and synthesizes the dizzy razzle-dazzle of events. Who cares how computer viruses proliferate or how exactly they disrupt the power grid, cause collisions at congested intersections and screw up airport arrival schedules? What do these darned computer viruses mean -- or what can they be made to mean? Besides, that is, that we're all interconnected, for good or for evil, for better or for worse. We already knew that from ''The Matrix.'' 
 This is probably the novel's big message, too, because, really, what else could it be? It's in the title. It's also meant to be in the novel's structure, which tells two other stories besides Arjun's that the virus eventually brings together in much the same fashion that hovering flying saucers used to function in B movies. (Cut from African chieftain gazing skyward to shot of wide-eyed Little League right fielder spotting the Martians and missing easy pop-up.) The more diverting story of the pair, because it's somewhat unfamiliar, tracks the shooting of Leela Zahir's new movie -- a sloppy gob of overemotional soap that's set in bonny Scotland, of all places -- and includes an arresting little digression into the life of its tortured leading man, whose messy sex life has landed him in the clutches of a sadistic, manipulative mob boss. 
 The other sub-story doesn't need to be here but it fits, more or less, because any story would fit as long as it featured a computer susceptible to attack by Arjun's rogue code. The virus device is nothing if not adaptable, and the choices it offers could drive a writer bats. This may be why Kunzru picks a proven scenario: the frantic, drug-fueled, greed-addled unraveling of a smarmy young white-boy capitalist who realizes he's in above his head but thinks that if he just runs a little faster he can redeem himself with one last deal, after which he'll finally marry his mistress and settle down in the country with a good book. His name in this case, Guy Swift, is so spot on that it's surprising it hasn't been used before, and his plunge from the cocaine high life to the gutter shares the same quality of deja vu. Yes, the tale is cleverly told, and yes, Kunzru's shots at the pseudoscience of ''branding'' are as stinging as Don DeLillo's recent slaps at the voodoo cult of currency trading, Tom Wolfe's blasts at the 1980's bond market, and so on and so on, but when will this rant stop? 
 Talk about falling victim to a virus. Those pesky bugs also dwell in novelists' brains.
 Like an unsaved file on a computer, ''Transmission'' dissolves back into random electrons the moment one turns it off. The reader may still be grinning over its good bits, may still feel impressed by Kunzru's verbal agility, but then he'll pick up his remote, switch on the news, and out will billow the great gray cloud of war footage, food safety warnings and terrorist threats. Novelists just can't compete.
 And can't not try.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Column 4; Long Island Weekly Desk; SUMMER ON LONG ISLAND; Pg. 14

LENGTH: 1037 words

HEADLINE: The Long Beach Rite of Spring

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

DATELINE: LONG BEACH 

 BODY:
IT'S countdown time to Memorial Day weekend, the unofficial beginning of summer, and Long Beach, a summer destination for thousands, is good to go -- well, almost.
 ''Just like any deadline, we are scrambling at the last minute,'' said John Skudin, newly appointed chief of Long Beach's 90 lifeguards, who will patrol the city's five-mile stretch of sand. Beginning Saturday, the beaches will be officially open, and lifeguards will be on duty each weekend; on June 26, they will be open daily. 
 The Long Beach oceanfront attracts more than a million people every summer, Mr. Skudin said, and ''on a busy summer weekend, we have about 50,000 people a day.'' 
 That crowd is roughly equal to the total number of summer residents of Long Beach, whose population the other nine months is about 35,000. 
 This swell in population requires serious preparation. 
 The advance work began in earnest in April, when many returning lifeguards and new candidates began training at the Long Beach High School pool. Returning lifeguards have to requalify every year, and rookies have to pass a more stringent test that was given May 15. 
 Last month, a 10-member maintenance crew started its preseason beach cleaning: scraping and painting lifeguard chairs; cleaning the beaches; grading the sand; getting the four-wheel-drive beach vehicles ready; and restocking first aid and medical equipment.
 ''I know summer is coming when I hear the trucks out cleaning the beaches at 6:30 every morning,'' said Glen Spiritis, the city manager, who spent 10 summers as a lifeguard in the 1960's and 70's. ''It tells me that we made it through the winter, and summer is finally here.''
 Then there is the problem of actually getting people onto the beaches. More than 200,000 daily and seasonal beach passes have been ordered, delivered, counted and taken to designated locations for sale. A daily is $6, most conveniently available at stands along the beach. The city's beach park manager, Joe Brand, reached an agreement with the Long Island Rail Road several weeks ago for a discounted $15 combination voucher, good for rail transportation from and to Manhattan and a beach pass. 
 ''It's the quickest, easiest and most economical way to get from the city to our beaches,'' Mr. Brand said.
 Once in Long Beach, if local officials and merchants have their way, visitors will be bombarded with opportunities to have fun and spend money. The calendar is already filled with concerts, volleyball and soccer tournaments on the beach, races along the 2.2-mile boardwalk, and several arts and crafts fairs. 
 The real estate market is booming with summer rentals. ''We start getting calls as early as January from people looking to rent something for the summer with an ocean view,'' said Marina Hirshhorn, an agent at Century 21 Kaye. ''Our customers come mostly from New York City because Long Beach is convenient, quiet, clean and more low-key than the East End.'' 
 Restaurateurs, too, are counting on crowds. For the holiday weekend, Sam Marelli, who leases the Turquoise Food Court on the boardwalk, has ordered 2,000 hot dogs, 1,000 hamburgers, 4,000 sodas and 300 pounds of calamari. A giant Post-it on the wall in Mr. Marelli's office reminds him of what he still has to buy: light bulbs for the bar, blades for a ceiling fan, cups for Italian ices.
 ''Our list goes on forever,'' he said. ''Because we're seasonal, it takes a lot to open this place every year. But this is my fifth year here, and it's my life. I love it.''
 Rob Richards, the owner and manager of Sutton Place, which opened a year and a half ago, shares those sentiments. ''I hate winter,'' said Mr. Richards, a lifelong Long Beach resident. ''I can't wait for summer, when our food business picks up by 20 percent, and we're always busy.''
 Of course, the success of the entire venture is predicated on the sun. Business people here remember only too well what happened last summer, when the sun went into hiding. 
 ''All I need is for the weather to cooperate,'' said Mr. Marelli, who owns five adjacent operations offering everything from clams, pizza and burritos to ice cream and frozen drinks. ''Last year, the weather was a disaster. Out of 13 weeks, we only had five good ones, and the blackout in August killed us because people lost two days and then had things to take care of over the weekend. It will take us two or three years to make up for last summer.''
 To handle the anticipated crowds, the city's 72 full-time police officers are being reinforced by 26 ''summer specials.'' Thomas Sofield, the Long Beach police commissioner, described them as ''college students who must be at least 20 years old and who are majoring in criminal justice.''
 ''They dress in uniform,'' he said, ''and are mostly responsible for beach and boardwalk patrol -- enforcing code violations like animals on the beach, alcohol use and beach pass infractions.''
 Then there are the traffic and criminal operations. ''We have several tag and tow officers who work on summer weekends to enforce traffic, 32 volunteers in our auxiliary police who help with traffic control, and a street criminal unit of two plainclothes officers with a supervisor to target problem areas,'' the commissioner said. ''There will also be extra beach patrol officers for every summer event. It's all in place, and we're ready.''
 Mr. Skudin, the lifeguards' chief, also expressed readiness -- though with a certain reserve. ''More and more, people are coming to our beaches from out of town, and they are not used to the ocean,'' he said. ''That presents more of a challenge to our lifeguards, and we try to put some of our most experienced guards at the most crowded beaches.
 ''At this time of year, I'm very excited -- but also nervous. I can train the lifeguards and get them all ready, but I can't be on every chair.''
 But if Mr. Skudin voiced a note of concern, James Hennessy, the president of the City Council, expressed nothing but anticipation. And he should know: he was a Long Beach lifeguard for 18 years. 
 ''Long Beach is summer,'' Mr. Hennessy said. ''Every year at this time, I miss being a lifeguard. When Memorial Day arrives, it's as if someone flicks a switch. Everyone comes outside, and summer is here.''

HEADLINE: 'Poor Man's Paradises': Not Just for Summer

BYLINE: By PATRICK HEALY

DATELINE: OAKWOOD ON THE SOUND 

 BODY:
IT'S an eerily calm Saturday afternoon, so still that onshore breezes barely stir the parasols of oaks and maples towering above the bungalows. Around this onetime summer haunt, driveways are empty. Clapboard shacks remain shuttered. Lights are off.
 But there is one exception. In a rust-orange house at the base of a hill, Jerry and Diane Waters have jumped the gun on summer. Life here may still be bookended by Memorial Day and Labor Day, but the Waterses, who live in Levittown most of the year, said they couldn't resist returning to their summer home a little early, to open the windows and shake out the rugs.
 ''Come on up,'' Mr. Waters said one brisk mid-May afternoon. ''We're just cutting up a lot of wood for the fire.'' 
 On Long Island, the traditional summer spots are as tapped as a college keg. Fire Island? Montauk? The Hamptons? Been there, done that, spent four hours in traffic and paid $1,000 to share a bedroom.
 But in northeastern Suffolk County, snug against Long Island Sound, lie some of the last untrampled bastions of summer life -- tiny communities that were built for farmers and middle-class residents and still called ''poor man's paradises'' by locals. 
 They are Sound Beach, Rocky Point, Baiting Hollow, Wading River, Oakwood on the Sound, Herod Point and Fresh Pond Landing. These hamlets (and hamlets within hamlets) are nestled in obscurity behind steep hills and sod farms. They are separated by name and local history, but they still have a lot in common: pebbled beaches, breathtaking views of Long Island Sound and a palpable dread that development will trample the hamlets' languid summertime spirit.
 Season by season, life in this stretch of northern Suffolk County and in summer havens across the New York metropolitan region is changing from part time into full time. Property values are rising, subdivisions are sprouting on old potato farms and residents are grudgingly taking on longer and longer commutes. 
 Twenty years ago in northern Suffolk, residents say, it was news to see another car on Sound Avenue, the east-west main road that loosely connects these communities. Today weekend traffic can be fierce, and federal census data show that in 2000, only 11 percent of houses were seasonal or vacation homes. 
 Throughout Suffolk County, 8 percent of homes are used seasonally. Western towns like Brookhaven and Huntington have the slimmest proportions, with 1 percent to 3 percent of homes classified as seasonal.
 But in towns like East Hampton and Southampton, 40 percent to 55 percent of homes remain seasonal, the data show.
 On this northern ledge of the Island, residents exult as homes become more valuable and posh restaurants and golf courses move in down the way. They also complain about trash on the beach, traffic and the possibility their neighborhoods may be too quaint and alluring for their own good.
 ''This year was the first year that I felt like I had to share a snowstorm,'' said Valerie Goode, who owns a real-estate agency in the area. ''I was very upset about it.''

Seasonal or Permanent?
 As the old summer towns circling New York extend their year-round roots, more and more Americans are looking for seasonal idylls, according to the federal housing data. 
 The number of people who own seasonal recreational homes has grown by nearly 200,000 in the past 16 years, reaching 1,974,ooo in 2001, from an estimated 1,775,000 in 1985.
 In the New York metropolitan area, the limited housing supply and climbing prices have pushed many bargain-hunting buyers to act. Whether primary homes are in upper Manhattan, the outer boroughs or the remote exurbs, vacation homes must be sought even farther afield.
 So while some are scouring upstate Woodstock or the back roads of Putnam County for a vacation cottage, others with less disposable income are putting down permanent roots in towns like North Salem, or Milford, Conn., or Long Island's eastern North Shore hamlets. These former summer towns, one or two hours from the city, are littered with tiny, often flimsy homes, but they also offer comparatively cheap prices and nature at the back door.
 ''Land values in waterfront communities have escalated dramatically, particularly in the last couple of decades,'' said Pearl Kamer, chief economist of the Long Island Association, the Island's largest business group. ''It just became economically reasonable to winterize those houses and live there year-round.''
 Real-estate agents from across the region say most of the new residents are young families buying their first homes or senior citizens buying their last. Thomas Cooke, an associate professor of geography at the University of Connecticut, says the pattern is for many part-timers to become full-timers as they age.
 ''Some of that is just people choosing to retire,'' Professor Cooke said. ''Housing prices are up and they're taking their equity, fixing their summer cottages and choosing to live there.''
 A handful of iconic getaways have resisted the trend. Fire Island, for instance, is rugged and inaccessible enough to have retained its summertime flavor, and though the Hamptons now hum all year, many of the millionaires' estates are still shuttered for the winter. 
 But Ms. Kamer said the solidly middle-class summer communities, like Wading River or Baiting Hollow, are now too expensive and too accessible to retain their May-to-September character.
 ''I think it's kind of sad,'' Ms. Kamer said. ''These part-time summertime locations will probably disappear in the next 5 to 10 years.''
 Oozing ever farther from New York, such communities are like rings on a pond, said Susan Fainstein, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University, remembering places like Coney Island, the Rockaways, Yonkers, Hoboken or Asbury Park as once-distant havens.
 ''It's a very old story in fact,'' she said. ''It's happening all over the country, actually.''

Snapshot of a Haven
 Today, the strip of hamlets along the North Shore is a picture of change. 
 In Rocky Point, modest one-story Cape Cods line the roads while contractors hammer away at more ambitious homes overlooking the Sound. In Oakwood on the Sound, after one thin-walled bungalow burned down, its owners replaced it with a grand faux-Victorian. In Wading River, McMansions sit across the street from sod farms.
 But for years after these acres were first parceled out into lots during the late 1600's, change happened at a much slower pace, according to local histories and longtime residents. Early residents here made their living shellfishing and shipping cordwood to Connecticut.
 The wide, rich fields were used to grow potatoes, and the waterfront evolved as a summer community for local farmers.
 ''The old way was, farm families would have a beach house and would move up to the water for the summer months,'' said Ms. Goode, the real-estate agent. ''The husband would continue farming and come home at the end of the day and take a swim.''
 Other communities grew less organically.
 In the 1920's, The New York Daily Mirror bought swaths of land in Rocky Point and sold cheap lots to its readers. Over the years, many of the homes closest to the water have stayed in the families of the original purchasers, passed down like heirlooms or rent-controlled apartments, real-estate agents said.
 At least three communities in the area, including Oakwood on the Sound, developed in the early 20th century as summer camping spots, said Jerry Waters, the resident who was airing out his home one May afternoon. 
 Mr. Waters, whose grandparents owned a home in Oakwood on the Sound, said the homes here evolved from camp tents to porous shacks to small bungalows. Irish, German and Italian immigrants living in Brooklyn would trek out to Suffolk for the summer, shelling out $20 or $30 to spend the season on the Sound.
 ''It was all O'Flaherty and Puccio,'' Mr. Waters said, describing people who lit their homes with kerosene lamps and walked into town to fetch blocks of ice for the iceboxes. 
 Each area boasts some small claim to fame, either historic or modern, according to Long Island histories. 
 Wading River residents talk about the night in 1756 that George Washington, then 24, was supposed to have bedded down at the Horn Tavern. Rocky Point was the site of the Radio Corporation of America station, which once broadcast a message delivered by President Warren G. Harding. Baiting Hollow was the setting of a short story by Theodore Dreiser.
 These days, though, longtime residents up and down the beaches divide their lives here into B.S. and A.S. -- before Shoreham and after Shoreham. It rankles many, but in recent years, the failed Shoreham nuclear plant has become the area's most prominent landmark.

Affordable Sound Views
 Good restaurants are scarce in Ashley McLean's new neighborhood. Winter winds off the Sound sting the skin. The roads can be treacherous and the winter months desolate. If the weather or traffic is bad, getting into Manhattan can take two hours or more.
 So why would Ms. McLean and her fiance move from their home in bustling Westhampton to the bottom of Edwards Avenue in Baiting Hollow?
 Simple, Ms. McLean said: a view of the Sound for $800 per month.
 Though northern Suffolk lacks the cachet and name recognition of the Hamptons, real-estate agents here say comparatively low prices are drawing residents eager to convert old summer havens into year-round houses. Lots facing the Sound sell for $300,000, and there are still houses with full water views going for less than $1 million, real-estate agents said.
 ''Property values are skyrocketing,'' said Roger Marks, a Wading River real-estate agent. ''People have discovered our town, and we have a tremendous influx of people coming out from the west.''
 Between 1990 and 2000, property values crept up in Rocky Point, Sound Beach and Wading River, rising by 3 percent, 5 percent and 10 percent respectively, according to census data. The average home value in the area in 2000 was $160,833 -- a modest sum by Long Island standards.
 Today, Mr. Marks said, nothing sells for less than $200,000. Recently, an old seasonal Cape Cod a block from the Sound sold for $269,000. Some summer bungalows and cottages sell for around $450,000.
 Mr. Marks said that in recent years, he could recall selling only one home whose new owner planned to live there part time.
 Most buyers today are retirees or young families looking for a bargain, who work in New York City, Nassau County, or closer towns like Hauppauge or Patchogue, real-estate agents said. 
 Drawn by the area's quaintness, good schools and proximity to Long Island Sound, they are persuaded to shoulder two-hour commutes.
 ''It's kind of evolved,'' Mr. Marks said of Wading River. ''It's not a summer town anymore. People are going into New York now every day. It's crazy, but they do it.''
 Growing up, Dan Holohan said, he spent his summers running up and down the pebbled beaches of Sound Beach and Wading River. Now a born-again pastor, Mr. Holohan sat on the beach one spring afternoon, staring into the Sound and recalling his boyhood.
 His extended family all came together during the summer, living in a small cottage in Sound Beach. Each morning they would run down the long stairways from the bluffs to the beaches and spend the day paddling around the Sound. 
 Since then, Mr. Holohan has lived in Bermuda, Alaska, Oklahoma and California. But when he was considering where to live permanently, he couldn't help returning to the beach communities of his childhood.
 ''I've been all over Long Island, and there's no other point like this,'' he said, feet kneading the sand. ''You want a quiet, simple life? This is the place.''

Still a Special Getaway
 Despite the growing number of year-rounders, life here still changes after Memorial Day. 
 Traffic thickens on Route 25A. Antique shops selling Jadeite tea saucers extend their hours. Retirees back from Florida pull the shutters off their houses. Produce stands open. The waterfront restaurant La Plage stays open on Mondays and Tuesdays -- its ''closed'' days during the off-season.
 In ways both intentional and haphazard, much of the area has retained the feel of a drowsy beach community. Outside people's homes, fishbowls are filled with smooth sea glass. Seahorse lawn ornaments abound. Rusting sailboats sit in front yards and driveways. And the gossip often revolves around which farm has the best strawberries or apricots, residents said.
 In Oakwood on the Sound and other small communities on the North Shore, summertime life is written into the bylaws, the Waterses said. Oakwood on the Sound and similar areas operate like New York City co-ops and are governed by boards of directors who lay out house rules.
 Such bylaws often prohibit families from using the area as a full-time home. And in Oakwood on the Sound, after a number of large new homes sprang up -- including one behemoth now called ''the church of disappointment'' -- the community passed a rule limiting home sizes, Ms. Waters said.
 ''This is our getaway,'' she said. ''We don't want it to be anything else.''
 Ms. Waters described summers that sound like being at a grown-up camp. Residents hold Christmas-in-July parties and offer arts and crafts classes. They go fishing for bluefish, set up umbrellas on the beach and have wine and cheese parties at dusk.
 But if the pastimes endure, some faces on the shores have changed.
 Mr. Holohan says he sees more and more Colombian and Mexican residents driving out to the beaches to swim and cast lines into the surf. Ms. Waters says Vietnamese and Asian residents camp at Wildwood State Park and spend the summers swimming and fishing.
 Renea Zeh, who lives in a beachfront house first owned by her grandfather, said crowds were becoming more of a problem each year. Teenagers celebrating the end of school have beach parties and leave behind trails of trash. Packs of Jet Skis roar across the water.
 Yet despite the growing crowds, Ms. Zeh says, the area is still tightknit. She can point at each house up and down her sandy street and say who lives there, who owned it years ago and whether the owners have other family in the area.
 ''When spring and summer come, I don't want to ever leave,'' Ms. Zeh said. ''People start taking the shutters down, cleaning up their little yards. By Fourth of July, everyone's having drinks. I am going to live there, and die in that house. I love it.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: Beach cottages in Wading River, close to the old Shoreham nuclear plant, are still mostly unwinterized and shuttered from Labor Day to Memorial Day. (Photo by Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Refining the Plan for a Former Psychiatric Center

BYLINE: By CAROLE PAQUETTE

DATELINE: KINGS PARK 

 BODY:
AFTER a weeklong series of public meetings, a master plan for the 368-acre site of the former Kings Park Psychiatric Center has been created that envisions the development of only 92 acres of a possible 200.
 The amount of land to be developed, significantly less than earlier proposals, was reduced in response to strong concerns expressed by residents over the possibility that a more sprawling development would result in a substantial loss of public land, cause traffic problems and diminish the community's small existing downtown.
 At the final meeting on May 11, attended by more than 1,000 residents, Andres Duany, a principal in the Miami-based planning firm of Duany Plater-Zyberk & Company, which was hired by the site's developers to create the master plan, characterized the revised 92-acre approach as ''politic, and the only feasible one.''
 As revised, the multiuse project would consist of a variety of 2,053 residential units, retail and office buildings, parkland and many sidewalks, to encourage residents to travel on foot or on bicycles instead of in cars. Much of the remaining 276 acres would be left as woods or open for public use, including ball fields and other recreational areas. 
 Dense development at the property is needed to help to pay for the $40 million asbestos cleanup and demolition of more than 40 existing buildings at the 120-year-old hospital site, Mr. Duany said. The cleanup will also deal with the remainders of many buried buildings, which also had asbestos and lead, that were demolished years ago by being ''tumbled into their basements and grassed over.'' 
 If the plan is ultimately approved by the town of Smithtown, the project is expected to take many years to complete at a cost of more than $1 billion, according to James Buslik, an owner of LAMB Acquisitions, a consortium of primarily local real estate investors, which won the right to buy the property for $7.5 million from the state in an auction last May. The purchase came with the condition that LAMB would pay the remediation costs.
 Construction is to begin once the plan has been approved and the site has been entirely cleaned up. The owners hope to begin work on new buildings on the site in about five years and expect the whole project to take 10 to 20 years to build out. The owners said that they had no guarantee they would get grants toward the cleanup but that they were confident they could get financing. 
 The plan estimates that the development will ultimately add $12.5 million annually to the local tax base, with $9 million going directly to the school district. Estimates are that it would bring in 4,416 new residents and 381 students. 
 Among the residential units would be 84 ''affordable'' starter condominium apartments, averaging 700 square feet each and projected to sell for about $200,000, and 1,596 market-rate units averaging 1,200 square feet for ''empty nesters'' and people 55 and over. The apartments would be in 16 buildings, one a tower of 11 stories and the others two to five stories tall. 
 There would be a two-story 23,800-square-foot building holding small shops and four 72,000-square-foot office buildings.
 The Kings Park Psychiatric Center officially closed in 1996 after the state began phasing out large psychiatric complexes. The property originally consisted of 562 acres; 158 have been dedicated to the Nissequogue River State Park and another 36 acres have been retained by the state, where some of the health facilities are still in use.
 On the 368 acres that are being purchased, there are numerous brick buildings, with a total of 2.5 million square feet of space, including the main 11-story, 350,000-square-foot Building 93 that has served as a landmark for the site. It is possible that three buildings may be saved.
 The Long Island principals of LAMB, whose initials form the acronym, are Charles Lefkowitz of Port Jefferson, Charles Alter of Lido Beach, Todd Mendik of Locust Valley and James Buslik of East Hills, who is also a principal in Adams & Company, a Manhattan real estate firm. Another partner is the Manhattan-based Durst Organization. 
 THE public planning forums, called a ''charrette,'' were held on eight consecutive days from May 4 to May 11, and individual afternoon workshops featuring specific subjects like transportation and housing drew up to 200 residents.
 The sessions were run by Duany Plater-Zyberk, which set up a studio at a former elementary school where the workshop meetings were held. 
 Throughout the week the planners, who Mr. Duany said ''came in with an empty slate,'' brainstormed with residents as they continuously revised designs for project options based on the public input.
 In the end residents' concerns helped to mold the final plan, reducing the development size and eliminating plans for a supermarket. Suggestions that have now been incorporated into the plan include public recreational areas, a public swimming pool and an amphitheater.
 As a result of worries that the development would take business away from the hamlet's downtown, the proposed new retail and office area and the entrance to the development were shifted to a spot along Route 25A, near where it intersects with Kings Park's main street. In effect, that makes the stores at the project an extension of the existing downtown; if the businesses had been placed deeper inside the development, they might have been seen as an alternative to the downtown. Space has been set aside for 32 live-work units in addition to the shops. 
 In addressing concerns about retaining a sense of the history of the hospital, where many Kings Park residents once worked, the planners designed the 11-story apartment building with 264 units for those 55 and over. It would be similar in size and style to the widely recognized Building 93, which has been deemed structurally unsound and will most likely be demolished.
 Although Mr. Duany said connector roads within the development would lead to other existing roads that would do a lot to bypass Route 25A, concern over the impact of traffic on the heavily traveled two-lane state road continues to worry Long Island's major planners like Lee Koppelman, the executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board since 1965, and a former Suffolk County planning director.
 ''My first concern is that access is limited,'' Dr. Koppelman said. ''There is only one way into the site, which is off Route 25A, and any increase in traffic generated is uncomfortable for residents of the area.''
 Frank DeRubeis, the Smithtown planning commissioner, said he was also concerned about traffic and the ''sheer size of the development.'' There are already 7,500 homes in Kings Park and the project would increase that total by 30 percent, he said. ''In a small area, that is a substantial increase,'' he added. ''The increased density would be the economic way to justify the remediation costs. It raises the question though, should the town through zoning bear the cost of remediation?''
 The guiding principle of the Kings Park planners is ''smart growth,'' a community-planning movement that seeks to design development in such a way that sprawl is minimized and open space is retained. The result is a multiuse village with residential, commercial and open spaces within walking distance.
 An important element in achieving smart growth in Long Island is the use of a ''charrette,'' a sort of brainstorming public forum that brings together many groups, including residents, politicians, merchants, environmentalists and developers, in a collaborative effort.
 The Kings Park charrette was coordinated by the Northport-based Vision Long Island, a nonprofit regional proponent of smart growth. ''This was the biggest charrette ever held on Long Island,'' said Eric Alexander, the director. ''The owners are searching for a big idea; this builds a consensus from the community.''
 Previous Long Island charrettes had been held in commercial corridors in the communities of Mastic-Shirley, Middle Island-Coram, Yaphank and Huntington.

HEADLINE: What Goes Up and Pulls Down the Dow?

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
HOW is it that the third-best-performing stock in the Dow Jones industrial average is also one of the main reasons the Dow is down 4.7 percent for the year -- almost three times the decline of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index?
 The stock is American International Group, the world's largest insurance company. A.I.G. is up 5.8 percent for the year and has bolstered the performance of the S.&P. 500. But it has been a drag on the Dow because of the timing of its entry into that index. A.I.G. joined the Dow on April 8. Since then, the stock is down 8 percent, almost double the fall in the Dow. 
 Some of the decline in A.I.G. is attributable to the overreaction of investors to the announcement on April 1 that it would become a Dow member, along with Verizon and Pfizer. Investors, evidently expecting that inclusion in the Dow would help these companies' stocks, promptly bid up their prices. From April 1 to April 7, A.I.G. jumped 6.9 percent, while Pfizer rose 1.8 percent and Verizon climbed 2.1 percent. A.I.G.'s price peaked on April 12 and has since fallen, along with other insurers', in part because premium growth is slowing and interest rates are rising.
 The A.I.G. decline accounts for 43.3 of the 487.18 points, or 8.9 percent, of the Dow's drop for the year through Friday, according to Bloomberg. Four other stocks -- United Technologies, Caterpillar, General Motors and Alcoa -- each contributed more points to the Dow's decline. But because A.I.G. had been in the Dow for just 44 days, it was the biggest negative influence on a per-day basis, dragging down the index by an average of almost one point a day. (The closest competitor was United Technologies, which dragged down the average by 0.67 points each day this year.) 
 A.I.G.'s effect on the S.&P. 500 is another matter. Because of the stock's rise since Jan. 1, it was the fifth-biggest positive influence on that index through Friday.

THRESHOLDS -- By some measures, inflation this year is already at levels that, in the past, would have prompted the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
 Through the first four months of 2004, the core Consumer Price Index, which excludes food and energy prices, has risen 1 percent -- compared with a 1.1 percent increase for all of 2003.
 If the consumer index rises 0.2 percent for May, the same as it did last month, the index will be up 1.2 percent in the first five months this year, more than in all of 2003.
 The current annual rate of core price increases through April is even higher, at 3 percent. 
 The annual rate of core inflation over four months has not been higher than 3 percent since the period ended June 1995, when it reached 3.2 percent.
 When the Fed began raising its benchmark interest rate in February 1994, the four-month rate was 2.8 percent. And when policy makers began their last tightening, in June 1999, core consumer prices were rising at an annual rate of just 1.7 percent over the previous four months.

NEW NUMBERS -- Among the economic data due this week are durable-goods orders for April, a revision of the first-quarter gross domestic product data -- which include an important inflation barometer -- and two measures of consumer confidence. Analysts expect the G.D.P. inflation measure to rise 2.5 percent, confirming the figure initially reported in April, according to Bloomberg.

HEADLINE: Where the Dust Motes Glow

BYLINE: By Jonathan Miles. 
Jonathan Miles is a writer who lives in New York.

 BODY:

EVENTIDE
By Kent Haruf.
300 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.
 I can't support this with demographic particulars, but here goes: many of the same readers who were drawn to Kent Haruf's best-selling novel, ''Plainsong,'' are equally drawn to Pottery Barn furniture. 
 What endeared them to Haruf's plainspoken, muslin-textured novel, a 1999 National Book Award finalist that chronicled a year in the life of a small Colorado town, was its ''rustic lines,'' its ''traditional sensibility'' and ''enduring style,'' its ''aged patina'' and ''sense of being at the center of family life,'' not to mention its quiet resemblance ''to authentic Shaker furniture.'' Save for that last line (which came from a USA Today review), I'm not quoting from ''Plainsong'' raves; these come from descriptions in Pottery Barn's early summer 2004 catalog. Both Haruf and the items in that catalog draw inspiration from visions of a more durable, hand-hewn past, and both willfully emit the horsey, old-leather scent of an America that may or may not be apocryphal. If readers found the novel's moral clarity refreshing, they warmed even more to its aesthetic clarity. Like antique reproductions, ''alternative'' country music and the Slow Food movement, ''Plainsong'' was a life raft for people who felt they were drowning in the sour froth of pop cynicism.
 Haruf's new novel, ''Eventide,'' is a sequel to ''Plainsong,'' and it will come as a familiar gift to those legions of readers -- maybe an overly familiar gift. I'm reminded of a friend who was once so smitten with a three-course restaurant dinner that after dessert he ordered all three courses again. ''Eventide'' is that kind of multi-course repeat performance. Here again are the convergent narratives, the seasons-come, seasons-go pacing and the same wide-angle, windswept ending. 
 The crotchety but lovable McPheron brothers take another star turn here, and Maggie Jones, the saintly schoolteacher and emotional-repair person of tiny Holt, Colo., makes a cameo appearance to pop the hood on people's lives and take a wrench to what's broken. The role of the Guthrie boys, the innocent and poorly mothered children of ''Plainsong,'' is played here by a motherless boy named DJ Kephart, an 11-year-old with ''brown hair that hung over his forehead'' that's not so unlike the dark hair of the Guthrie boys that fell ''identically over their unmarked foreheads.'' Russell Beckman, the bully of ''Plainsong,'' has been replaced by Hoyt Raines; Hoyt, like Russell, abuses children and is dealt no authorial justice for that abuse. ''Mama, do you have to smoke in here now?'' asked a daughter in ''Plainsong''; ''Mom, do you have to smoke?'' a different daughter asks a different mother in ''Eventide.'' In ''Plainsong,'' the reader saw ''dust motes swimming in the dimly lighted air like tiny creatures underwater,'' while in ''Eventide,'' the ''dust motes danced in the air like tiny creatures in dim water.'' Haruf has not, as a publicist might say, outdone himself. He's just done himself.
 There's no crime in this, of course. As Alfred Hitchcock once put it, ''Self-plagiarism is style.'' It should follow, nonetheless, that what was good about ''Plainsong'' should be equally good about its chip-off-the-block sequel, and for the most part this is true. As a stylist, Haruf melds the hoof-clop cadences of Cormac McCarthy (''They came down the plank steps out of the trailer into the bright sun in the middle of morning and rounded the corner in the packed dirt and arrived at the rusted shopping cart that waited like something patient and abiding among the dry cheatgrass and pigweed'') with the pinched economy of Hemingway. He is sensitive, as V. S. Pritchett wrote of Chekhov, ''to the musicality of simple language,'' and is rarely victim to the purple fevers that can infect describers of the Western landscape. His prose has the balming effect of a grandfather clock ticking in a quiet, pine-floored house, and, like that clock, seems to exist solely to record the passing of time. 
 For all their mirrored affinities, however, there are real differences between the two novels. Despite its didactic undertones -- its esteem for an honest day's work, its tenderhearted adherence to innocence as a virtue (as seen in the bachelor McPherons, aghast at the townsfolk murmuring about them living with a pregnant high schooler) -- ''Plainsong'' was pitted with dark crevices. Witness the short fuse of the hero, Tom Guthrie, or Haruf's dead-on rendering of the bumper-car carnality of small towns, or the epidemic disintegration of traditional families in Holt County. If Haruf took Sherwood Anderson's ''Winesburg, Ohio'' as his inspiration for a cross-sectional depiction of small-town life, then he was intermittently true, with ''Plainsong,'' to the skewed vision that prompted Anderson to title his manuscript, originally, ''The Book of the Grotesque.'' ''Eventide,'' alas, is almost devoid of shadowed crannies; dark meets light, and light meets dark, but little gray sits between them.
 An accidental death gives the novel one of its primary plot hinges, but accidental deaths are neither dark nor light; they just are. Haruf peeks into the trailer parks of Holt to introduce us to Luther and Betty June Wallace, but as even their names attest, these are archetypes of poor white poverty, exhumed from the archives of socialist fiction, and Haruf loses his balance when he tries to pump life into them, resulting in such moments as when Betty, ''her eyes rolling unfocused,'' wails ''into the rank and odiferous air'' of her trailer. Haruf also flirts with the archetypal in his portrayal of Hoyt, a hard-drinking, womanizing, child-abusing lout, ''smelling of . . . cheap bar whiskey,'' who seems unfairly deprived of a puppy to kick as he wreaks predictable havoc. 
 The sometimes twisted sexuality of ''Plainsong'' -- the multipartner couplings in abandoned houses and Denver bathrooms, the frenzy of back-seat sex with the night wind drifting into open car windows ''smelling of sage and summer grass'' -- is absent in ''Eventide,'' tokenly represented by a scene in which one of the McPherons finally loses his virginity to a woman whose naked body is ''so smooth and warm and full-fleshed, and she herself so goodhearted.''
 For all its admirable craftsmanship, ''Eventide'' is too goodhearted. Pottery Barn's success lies in its ability to convince consumers that it's possible to market authenticity in a shopping mall, and that its furnishings recreate a bygone warmth and simplicity, not cynically invent it. Kent Haruf's achievement lies in his ability to depict the frangible values of rural communities, not advocate them. Dusting the West with sugar isn't necessary; what dust there is is sweet enough.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: Where the Twain Meet

BYLINE: By PATRICK HEALY

DATELINE: Long Beach Island 

 BODY:
FROM behind the counter of his custard stand, Jim Brennan can practically smell the summer hordes approaching.
 Most won't arrive in full force until Memorial Day, he knows. But already, a few are crossing the bay and broaching the shores of Long Beach Island like reconnaissance soldiers before battle. They come to clean up the cottage, greet old friends and reacquaint themselves with the salt air -- their numbers a meager hint of what's to come.
 The year-round population of this skinny, sandy summertime destination is a mere 8,000 people, but by midsummer, that number will have swelled to 100,000, perhaps 150,000, say Mr. Brennan and others who work on the island. Roads clog. Beaches overflow. And money flows. 
 ''It's getting better now,'' said Mr. Brennan, 22, as he served up mango custard shakes and wiped down the counters one afternoon. ''By the Fourth of July, it's just packed all the time. It's just mobbed.''
 Long Beach Island is one of the few communities nearby that live a grasshopper's life. Bit by bit, more people have retired here or are settling on the island and commuting to Philadelphia. But for the most part, life still begins in late spring and ends in September. 
 Other old summer towns like Asbury Park, Spring Lake and Hoboken long ago put down their roots and developed into year-round habitats, said Susan Fainstein, a professor of urban planning at Columbia University. Old lakefront getaways in Westchester County and Connecticut are now bedroom communities for New York City, and even the East End of Long Island is becoming full-time residential.
 Rising home prices and property taxes, a dwindling housing supply and a growing willingness to take on mammoth commutes have all transformed those areas from part-time towns into full-time ones.
 But on the 18-mile thread of land known as Long Beach Island, federal data show, there's a trend in the opposite direction: the portion of seasonal or vacation homes climbed to 65 percent in 2000, compared with 62 percent 10 years earlier.
 Though property values in the region have shot up over the past five years, residents and real estate agents here say the island is too cold and windy in the winter and too remote from New York City (two hours, if you're lucky) to become a bedroom community.
 It's true that the houses here are getting bigger, and that vacationers' hometowns and ethnicities are constantly changing. But there are still sailboats carved onto navy shutters, sand on the main roads and 25-mile-per-hour speed limit signs that urge, ''For Pete's sake, slow down!''
 ''It's still a summer, family island,'' said Joanne Quinlan, who owns the Bywater Shop, a knickknack trove on Long Beach Boulevard. ''Always has been, always will be.''
 One of the reasons Long Beach Island has become so hot in recent years is that communities like it are disappearing.
 As the old summer towns circling New York extend their year-round roots, more and more Americans are looking for seasonal idylls, according to federal housing data. The number of people who own a seasonal recreational home has grown by nearly 200,000 in the past 16 years, reaching 1,974,000 in 2001, from an estimated 1,775,000 in 1985.
 In the New York metropolitan area, the limited housing supply and climbing prices have already pushed many bargain-hunting buyers to act. Whether primary homes are in upper Manhattan, the outer boroughs or the remote exurbs, vacation homes must be sought even farther afield.
 So while some are scouring Woodstock, N.Y., and the back roads of Putnam County for a vacation cottage, others with less disposable income are putting down permanent roots in towns like North Salem, or Milford, Conn., or in Long Island's eastern North Shore hamlets. These former summer towns, one or two hours from the city, are littered with tiny, often flimsy homes, but they also offer comparatively cheap prices and nature at the back door.
 ''Land values in waterfront communities have escalated dramatically, particularly in the last couple of decades,'' said Pearl Kamer, chief economist of the Long Island Association. ''It just became economically reasonable to winterize those houses and live there year-round.''
 Real estate agents from across the region say most of the new residents are young families buying their first homes or older people buying their last. Thomas Cooke, an associate professor of geography at the University of Connecticut, says the pattern is for many part-timers to become full-timers as they age.

Retirees and Summer Sojourners
 On Long Beach Island, the growing ranks of retirees are split evenly between year-round residents and summer sojourners who keep a condo in Florida, real estate agents said. 
 ''Some of that is just people choosing to retire,'' Professor Cooke said. ''Housing prices are up and they're taking their equity, fixing their summer cottages and choosing to live there.''
 A handful of iconic getaways besides Long Beach Island have resisted the trend. Fire Island, for instance, is rugged and inaccessible enough to have retained its summertime flavor, and though the Hamptons now hum all year, many of the millionaires' estates are still shuttered for the winter. 
 But Ms. Kamer said the solidly middle-class summer communities are now too expensive and too accessible to retain their May-to-September character.
 ''I think it's kind of sad,'' Ms. Kamer said. ''These part-time summertime locations will probably disappear in the next 5 to 10 years.''
 Oozing ever farther from New York, such communities are like rings on a pond, Dr. Fainstein said, remembering places like Coney Island, the Rockaways, Yonkers, Hoboken or Asbury Park as once-distant havens.
 ''It's a very old story in fact,'' she said. ''It's happening all over the country, actually.''

Evolution of a Haven
 Long Beach Island floats like a twig in the ocean on the eastern ridge of New Jersey, 20 miles from Atlantic City. It is so skinny -- about a quarter-mile wide -- that you can stand just off its west coast, feet in Manahawkin Bay, and still have a great view of the Atlantic on the other side of the island.
 In less than five minutes, a visitor can walk from the commercial streets in the middle of the island to the shoreline and glimpse the endless white beaches that caught the eye of the earliest Colonial settlers. 
 Sighted in 1614 by a Dutch captain, Cornelius Jacobsen May, the island first served as an outpost for whalers and fishermen, and later as a hunting ground for affluent Philadelphians, who reached it by train and ferry and whiled away the summer among the beach plums and bayberry.
 ''I think they got to like the island,'' said Mary Gruber, who volunteers with the local Historical Society. ''They got their friends to come down, and it just blossomed.''
 The island communities of Beach Haven, to the south, and Barnegat Light, to the north, were developed as elegant resort destinations. Other parts of the island got built up with creaky hotels and rows of wooden bungalows, many of which had the unfortunate habit of blowing over whenever major Nor'easters rolled in.
 As the fledgling tourist economy grew, full-time residents improvised. Steven Parker's Norwegian ancestors, for instance, settled on the island to fish and scallop, but after the stock began to vanish, Mr. Parker said, his father's family earned their living bootlegging liquor
 Transportation soon started to define the character and residents of the island, and what divided them. After the Garden State Parkway and Verrazano-Narrows Bridge opened in the 1950's and 60's, more and more New Yorkers and North Jerseyans began settling on the island. This change brought more money to the island but did not win the newcomers good relations with the other inhabitants. 
 Historians and authors tell stories going as far back as the 1920's, when two families, the Engles and the Baldwins, built competing hotels catering to region-specific crowds. The Engleside became the destination for the more Victorian crowds from Philadelphia, while New Yorkers flocked to the New Baldwin Hotel, to drink German beer and shoot at porpoises from the beach.
 These tales are hardly West Side Story, and though Philadelphians, New Jerseyans and New Yorkers have coexisted on the island for decades, locals seem to have made a pastime of A) insisting that more New Yorkers are arriving on the island and B) describing how to tell the different groups apart.
 Some point to the expensive restaurants with prix-fixe menus; others say the Empire State license plates are multiplying with each season. Real estate agents say more of their clients list primary addresses in New York City, and bar patrons say they see clear evidence of the rift: When the Yankees or the Mets are playing at the same time as the Phillies, you don't want to be the bartender who has to choose the channel.

The New Allure of Buying
 Here's a sign of the times. Or perhaps a dozen of them.
 Drive down Long Beach Boulevard, the island's main north-south drag, and you'll spot more real estate offices than traffic lights. The market for summer homes and rentals is, well, rabid these days, residents and realtors say, and there are few signs it is abating.
 Average home values rose by 23 percent in a decade, to $298,016 in 2000 from $242,233 in 1990, according to federal census data. In one of the island's six boroughs, Harvey Cedars, prices shot up by 44 percent. Rentals range from $1,500 per week, for a shack in modest south island, to $9,500 per week for a beachfront mansion in tony north island, said Paul Gow, a local real estate agent. 
 ''This would have been unheard of a couple of years ago,'' Mr. Gow said.
 The soaring prices have transformed the market, experts say, making rentals less attractive. ''There's actually a surplus of rentals out there,'' Mr. Gow said, as he tapped at the computer in his office, and pulled up a list of still-vacant summer rentals.
 While some of the new flock of buyers are year-round residents, most are part-timers who spend their summers on Long Beach Island, or live on the island for part of the summer and rent out the house for the remainder, to make enough to pay the property taxes or mortgage.
 Ann and Anthony Merlino had been renting and staying with family in Beach Haven for years until three years ago, when they decided to buy a two-bedroom condo overlooking the bay. They bought their second-floor unit for $270,000, and today, similar places are selling for $490,000, according to the Jersey Shore Multiple Listing Service.
 ''We bought at the right time,'' said Ms. Merlino, 57, who is retired and splits her time between the Jersey Shore and Titusville. ''Oh God, I love it.''
 It was quiet up and down the residential streets one recent weekday afternoon, except for the constant clatter of construction work. Contractors were adding porches and second floors, pounding banana-cream vinyl siding onto homes and tar-papering anything that didn't move. The construction workers outnumbered the residents.
 As property values rise here, people seeking to resell their houses or convert them to luxury rentals are tearing down the old bungalows and Cape Cods and erecting boxy mansions with porticos, rooftop decks and pebbled yards raked as smooth as Zen gardens.
 At the same time, more and more residents are inverting the layouts of their homes, putting living rooms and kitchens on second floors for the best possible light and views. 
 From 1990 to 2000, the number of homes with nine or more rooms doubled in three of the island's boroughs, according to census data. ''No part of the island is escaping it,'' Mr. Gow said.
 As the pace of change quickens, residents like Mr. Parker, of the bootlegging lineage, have watched with a mixture of awe and befuddlement.
 ''Everything's being knocked down,'' he said over happy hour drinks at Nardi's, a bar on Long Beach Boulevard. ''We just sit there and say, 'I would've bought that house just the way it was.'''

A PG-Rated Summer
 As the sun slipped behind the piers, Ali Chance parked her BMW with the ''I'd Rather Be Deer Hunting'' sticker on the back and walked into Nardi's. She has been coming here for years. So have most of her friends. And to them, even in the midst of this rapid-fire development, the island's scrappy summertime identity seems unshakable.
 While other summer haunts have lost their iconic shops and attractions to time or urban redevelopment, businesses like the Fantasy Island Amusement Park chug along, and chain stores have been kept at bay. Even surfers who come to the island each summer say they are charmed by the PG-rated quality of the island, where drunken shuffleboard games make for a wild evening.
 ''It's a different kind of world out here,'' Ms. Chance said. ''We don't have fast food. We don't have drive-throughs.''
 When the summer sun is out here, thousands make the trek to the beaches and complain about the mandatory beach passes. They take day cruises, go fishing in the bay and buy trinkets. They go to the bars in Beach Haven and knock back $2.50 glasses of wine. 
 Though Long Beach Island's full-time population has held almost flat over the past decade and remains 98 percent white, Hispanic workers drawn by construction work and seasonal jobs have become more and more of a presence, Ms. Chance said.
 And every season brings new nationalities of seasonal help, from the Australians who come to work as lifeguards, to the Russians and the Czech and Irish students who get jobs at convenience stores and restaurants.
 As the summer wears on, Ms. Chance added, the full-time residents' ambivalence toward the summer masses begins to show through. But while the visitors cause traffic jams and bump elbows with year-rounders at the bars, they spend enough in three or four months to sustain many here through the winter.
 These days, as increasing numbers of people buy homes, full-time part-timers like Ms. Merlino have announced that they, too, find it necessary to dodge the tourists.
 ''Summer is so different -- too crowded,'' she said. ''It just becomes much more fun to stay in your own backyard.''

HEADLINE: Farmers Reaping New Buyers

BYLINE: By JILL P. CAPUZZO

DATELINE: Riverton 

 BODY:
IN early May, signs began appearing in shop windows and on telephone poles throughout town that a farmers' market was coming soon. For this small Victorian village on the banks of the Delaware River, this was welcome news -- far more welcome than earlier reports of the new high-speed rail line, or the bike trail, both also being routed through town. 
 After all, who doesn't like farmers?
 In the last few years, a growing number of towns and cities throughout New Jersey have opened their arms to farmers interested in peddling fresh produce on a given Saturdays, Wednesdays or Thursdays throughout the summer. Originally created to give the state's struggling farmers access to new sources of income, community farmers' markets have become economic engines for some of their host municipalities, bringing life back to declining downtowns and giving people a reason to linger in neighborhoods they might not otherwise visit. 
 Standing in the shadow of the overhead train trestle, Stephanie Viereck unloaded more boxes of produce off of her green pick-up truck last Saturday morning. By 9:30, she had sold out all 30 flats of strawberries she brought to the market here and was down to her last tender shoots of fresh asparagus. At the next stand, farmers from Buena offered $1 heads of fresh lettuce and newly plucked herbs, while across the way, customers sniffed the aromatic Sungate Soaps. 
 Every Saturday from May through November, downtown Collingswood begins a mini-festival as thousands of shoppers fill the two-block stretch adjacent to the high-speed line. Many people credit the farmers' market with playing a major role in the renaissance in Collingswood, an inner-ring suburb of Camden. Now in its fifth season, the farmers' market has gotten bigger and more popular every summer, bringing more shoppers not only to the market, but also to nearby shops and restaurants. .
 This season, the market manager, Pam Ciervo, has arranged for about 20 vendors to sell their wares there. In addition to the dozen or so farmers, who come from counties in South Jersey, the market has four bakers, a Bridgeton woman who makes jams from berries she grows, a creperie, and two registered nurses who sell herbal soaps. Vendors pay a registration fee of $50 for the season, and a weekly lease of $35 to $50. 
 ''We want food and produce either sold by the grower or the person who cooked it,'' Ms. Ciervo said. ''If it's food related, it's great.''
 Colin Egan is a bit more of a purist when it comes to running the Journal Square Farmers' Market in Jersey City, which opens on July 7. In the decade the market has been operating, he has limited it to a few farmers and one baker. ''I don't want it to become like a flea market,'' he said.
 In addition to tapping into the thousands of commuters who pass through the square on their way to catch a PATH train or bus, Mr. Egan said the market had become a destination for many city residents who normally don't venture downtown.
 ''I had a senior citizen tell me 'I haven't come to the square for years, and now I'm coming for this,''' said Mr. Egan, who the rest of the week runs the landmark Loews Jersey Theater in Journal Square. ''It's something people really look forward to, the sense and smell of fresh produce, and getting to know the farmers from year to year.''
 Limited to selling only produce grown in New Jersey, most of the markets run from mid-June or early July into October, when the finest blueberries, tomatoes and corn are in season. Each market sets its own rules, some of which can be fairly stringent. At the Friday afternoon market in Forked River, for example, farmers can only sell produce that was picked that morning, which must be aesthetically displayed, in baskets and on tablecloth-covered surfaces. 
 The concept of farmers selling their goods in the middle of town can be traced back to Europe in the 1600's. The practice fell out of favor in modern times, however, with the advent of the supermarket. The current interest in freshly grown and organic foods has spurred a revival of community farm markets. A United States Department of Agriculture survey found close to 3,200 such markets around the country in 2003. With 8 to 10 new markets expected to open this summer, New Jersey will be home to about 75 community farmers' markets, according to Ronald Good, markets bureau chief in the New Jersey Department of Agriculture.
 Through the 1980's and early 1990's, Mr. Good said, New Jersey had a steady count of 10 or 15 community farmers' markets, but in the last four years he has gotten applications for 5 to 10 markets each year. The problem now has become finding enough farmers to fill the demand. 
 ''Farmers can get help picking in the field and in the packing house, but to deal face to face with the public, that takes a special personality,'' said Mr. Good, who tries to persuade farmers to at least try a market for one season.
 Last summer, the owners of William Schober Sons Orchards in Monroeville decided to sell produce at a farmers' market for the first time, after being invited to take part in the Woodbury market. While doing research at the Collingswood market on how to set up their stand and what to bring, the farmers were asked by Ms. Ciervo, the manager, to join her market also. This summer they plan to add three more farmers' markets to their roster. 
 Darlene Hurff of Schober Orchards said the markets were a whole new business opportunity for the farm, which was started by her grandfather in the early 1900's.
 ''It was more profitable than our wholesale business, because we were able to market things in smaller quantities, and we became very friendly with the customers,'' Ms. Hurff said. ''It almost became like family with some of the purchasers.''
 Bringing communities together has turned out to be another byproduct of the farmers' markets. While Riverton residents were divided over the arrival of the new RiverLine high-speed line, one resident, Eric Goldstein, saw its recent opening as an opportunity to bring a farmers' market to the borough. Mr. Goldstein said he met with nothing but positive reactions from town officials and business owners when he proposed a Saturday farmers' market. 
 Still, starting a market is not always smooth sailing. The organizers of both the Forked River and Collingswood markets said it took them a full year of planning before they were up and running. After running into some insurance problems, Mr. Goldstein had to race around town the night before the market was to open last weekend, replacing promotional flyers with new ones that announced the new June 5 start date. Still, he said he was determined to open the market this summer.
 ''My concern is with helping out the businesses in town,'' said Mr. Goldstein, who runs a nonprofit business improvement program in Philadelphia. ''Our businesses are struggling, and if we don't come up with something to bring more pedestrian traffic into downtown, those businesses are going to fail. The farmers' market is a vehicle to do that.''


GRAPHIC: Photos: Many in Collingswood say their farmers' market, above, has led to a renaissance. Thousands of shoppers, right, visit the market, now in its fifth year. (Photographs by David Hunsinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cure for Sticker Shock at the Pump: The Shore

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS

 BODY:
GASOLINE prices have been going up so quickly that the signs at the local service station seem to change like slot machine readouts, surging ever higher. Terrorism -- now touching such tourist destinations as Madrid -- does not seem to be abating. And as the value of the dollar continues on its own trip south, it is prohibitively expensive for many to travel abroad. 
 ''While it does seem that Americans will tolerate the increase in gas prices, they may well be re-thinking long car trips this summer,'' said Pam Maiolo, the manager for public affairs for AAA Mid-Atlantic in Hamilton. ''If that's so, the Shore, with its traditional base so close, might be primed for a boom.'' 
 For the first time ever, the price of gasoline soared to more than $2 a gallon this month, a rise of more than 20 percent in one year, or about six times the rate of inflation. 
 Still, New Jersey is a bargain. In fact, it is second only to South Carolina in having the lowest average gasoline price, mostly because of its low gasoline taxes and proximity to refineries. California has the highest average price ($2.24), with neighboring states like New York and Connecticut far higher.
 ''It doesn't seem like it is going to change soon,'' Ms. Maiolo said. ''In fact, it seems like it will go high as the summer comes. Demand is high. Supply is not.''
 That suggests that for now, people have not cut down significantly on their driving. Ms. Maiolo said that AAA had found that air travel was up slightly this year, though not at the levels it was in 2000. But travel to Europe might be down slightly because of the weakness of the dollar. All of that, she said, bodes well for business at the Shore this summer.
 ''It's a good destination,'' she said. ''It is popular from Canada to Pittsburgh to Washington. Unemployment is down. Wages are up. It should be a good time for the Shore.''
 While housing prices at the Shore have continued to rise, rental prices have apparently stabilized. The Monmouth-Ocean County metropolitan area, for instance, is sixth in the nation in housing appreciation over the last five years, up 77.6 percent; the Atlantic-Cape May metro area is 15th, up 66.9 percent.
 ''And it would be much more if you just take the beachfront areas of those counties,'' said Mark Grimes of Ocean City Realty in Ocean City in Cape May County. ''The sales market is incredible. That said, there seems to be an oversupply of rentals right now. The beach block, for a standard three- or four-bedroom place would be $3,000 to $4,000 a week, which is what it has been for a couple of years. Back four blocks, you can get it for $1,500 to $1,700, even though sales prices are way up.''
 Atlantic City expects such a good summer that its Convention and Visitors Authority has already turned its attention to fall.
 ''We have to be careful running any promotions of things like golf in the area, because rooms are already taken for the summer,'' said Jeff Vasser, the executive director of the authority. ''Our mission is to make sure Atlantic City hotel rooms are booked, so we are already out looking for conventions for later in the year and next year.''
 Mr. Vasser said that new, non-casino attractions are helping draw tourists in the summer. Bally's Hotel-Casino is opening up a bar on the beach in front of its hotel, joining three others (Caesars, Hilton and Trump Plaza) that opened last summer. The new Borgata Hotel and Casino is opening an outdoor amphitheater, which will have events like shows and beach volleyball, on the bay side of its property. The Walk, a multi-level upscale shopping center adjacent to the Tropicana near the Boardwalk. is mostly completed. 
 Mr. Vasser said, too, that the beach replenishment program, which will be completed by the start of the summer season, should help make beaches in Atlantic City and nearby Ventnor more attractive.
 ''We've always said that casino visitors want to be near the beach. Now that will be even more so,'' Mr. Vasser said.
 Farther along the Shore, especially from Bay Head and north, where the commuter trains start, the boom is being fueled by a growing number of year-round residents.
 ''People in their 50's, the leading edge of the Baby Boom, now have kids out of the house and are cashing in their big houses in Short Hills and Westfield and moving to the beach, especially in places where they can commute to Newark or New York,'' said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University.
 And with them, he said, more year-round businesses are coming to the beach areas in Monmouth County especially. That, in turn, makes it more attractive to summer visitors. It's a win-win for the Shore, he said. 
 The typical summer Shore amusement areas are also looking for a good season. Even in the more middle-class towns, there is a move to refurbish. In Ocean City, the old Moorlyn Theater has been gutted and restored to its 20th century days of glory, its mock-Moorish architecture complementing that of the Music Pier nearby on the Boardwalk.
 The Morey Organization, which operates the three amusement piers in the Wildwoods, is replacing an old ride, the Dark River, with Pirates of the Wildwoods, a take-off on the movie, ''Pirates of the Caribbean,'' with live actors. Instead of the ubiquitous T-shirt and cheap memorabilia shops, the Moreys are putting two new stores underneath the Sea Serpent roller coaster. One is a Create-a-Bear teddy-bear-making center. The other is the Doo-Wop Boardwalk Museum Shop, with items remembering the resort's previous heyday in the 1950's and 1960's -- everything from stylized pink flamingos to full-scale $1000 jukeboxes. The store will be operated by Cape May's Mid-Atlantic Center for the Arts.
 ''Who would have thought we'd see the day when Victorian Cape May and Doo-Wop Wildwood would get together?'' said Joanna Galloway of the Morey Organization. ''But this is the new Shore. The visitors everywhere are just more sophisticated, and we have to keep up.''
