HEADLINE: OPEC Rejects a Saudi Proposal to Increase Production Quotas

BYLINE: By HEATHER TIMMONS

DATELINE: AMSTERDAM, May 22 

 BODY:
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will make no immediate adjustments to its current production levels, despite Saudi Arabia's offer on Friday to increase the amount of oil it pumps to ease high prices. 
 Members of OPEC, the oil cartel that controls over a third of the world's production, met Saturday in Amsterdam to discuss various proposals, but no changes will be made until a June 3 meeting in Beirut, the organization's president, Purnomo Yusgiantoro of Indonesia, told reporters. ''We are deeply concerned'' about high prices, he said, but OPEC's production levels are not the main cause. 
 OPEC's position contrasts with that of Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil producer. On Friday, its oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, told other energy ministers gathered at a conference here that he was willing to increase Saudi production by half a million barrels a day in June. Saudi Arabia is one of the few countries that is not already pumping oil as quickly as it can. 
 On Friday, Mr. Naimi also said recent revisions in demand and supply projections indicated that OPEC should increase production by more than 2 million barrels a day. OPEC nations are already producing more than 2 million barrels a day over their 23.5 million quota.
 Oil prices fell on Thursday and Friday in hopes that OPEC would agree to one of the Saudi proposals on Saturday as an emergency relief measure. Oil prices rose above $40 a barrel on May 11 for the first time since Iraq invaded Kuwait in 1990, and stayed above $40 until Friday. 
 Saturday's meeting was not a place to set policy, but ''was an opportunity to meet and formally exchange views,'' Mr. Purnomo said. Many factors are contributing to the climb, including varying specifications for emissions in the United States that prevent states from sharing gas supplies, speculation in the futures markets and tension in some oil-producing regions. OPEC is ''deliberating on the proposition to increase production'' in line with the cartel's commitment to stabilize oil prices, Mr. Purnomo said. 
 OPEC is under pressure to increase production as nations feel the pinch from rising energy prices. The price of oil has become an important issue for the Bush administration, and officials on Saturday called for changes from OPEC. ''We need strong action now in the immediate period ahead to address today's challenge, these high prices,'' the United States secretary of energy, Spencer Abraham, said during a news conference in Amsterdam, Bloomberg News reported.
 Any changes in OPEC production levels must be made by unanimous decision. The numbers that it sets in some instances have more effect on oil trading, though, then on the actual amount its members produce. Saudi Arabia pumped 8.3 million barrels a day in April, above its OPEC quota of 7.64 million, for example. 
 Dr. Ibraham Bahr Al-Uloum, the oil minister of Iraq, backed OPEC's official line in a statement on Saturday, saying that high prices were caused by many factors besides production levels, including accelerated economic growth and speculation in the trading markets. Iraq plans to revive its national oil company, Mr. Uloum said. In recent months, Iraq has pumped 2.5 million barrels a day, and hopes to reach 3 million by the end of the year, he said. 
 OPEC members met during the International Energy Forum, which brings together oil ministers and company representatives from around the world.

HEADLINE: The Family Trees

BYLINE: By Anthony Quinn. 
Anthony Quinn is the film critic for The Independent in London.

 BODY:

TRUE NORTH
By Jim Harrison.
388 pp. New York:
Grove Press. $24.
 EARLY on in Jim Harrison's new novel, ''True North,'' the narrator, David Burkett, reflects that ''lovemaking and fishing don't manage to dominate your life like you wished they could,'' though on most people's reckoning he gets to do his fair share of both. Particularly the lovemaking. From the moment he loses his virginity as a neurotic teenager in the 1960's to the more mature and considered years of his mid-30's, David never seems to be short of a woman eager to console his yearning loins. That he remains nonetheless cagey on the matter is due to his troubled relationship with his father, an egregious drunkard and ne'er-do-well whose sexual incontinence leads to the ''grotesque and unprosecuted crime'' that lies at the dark heart of the novel.
 David's life has been haunted not just by the sins of his father but by those of his forefathers. The scion of a wealthy logging dynasty, he has become obsessed with finding out ''what went wrong'' with his family, or ''if it was ever right in the first place beginning with those big-eyed, jut-jawed portraits in my father's den.'' He begins to research the history of the Burketts and how they despoiled the virgin forests of Michigan's Upper Peninsula during the late 19th century, a project that will, over the following decades, topple him into a morass of anxiety, guilt and self-loathing. In a word: timber! What his ancestors did to the landscape is still a sore spot for David: his very surname has become a byword for economic rapacity.
 Divided into three parts -- the 60's, the 70's, the 80's -- the novel is rather elusive in its tenor. It is hard to decide whether Harrison is offering us a coming-of-age story, a familial saga of estrangement or a slow-burning revenge tragedy; the knottier it becomes, the more likely it seems that we are actually reading all three. David, when first we meet him, is 16, lonely, slightly priggish and susceptible to influence. Having defected from his parents' Episcopal Church to the Baptists, he eventually feels the countervailing tug of young women and blues records, and broods guiltily about it. He has a will to self-improvement, reading widely, looking after his alcoholic uncle Fred and teaching underprivileged kids in the hope that he will, like his feisty younger sister, Cynthia, shake off the ghost of his DNA.
 Unlike Cynthia, he hasn't been able to make a clean break from his father, whose rape of a friend's 12-year-old daughter reverberates mightily to the very end of the novel. His father, it transpires, is a ''nympholeptic'' -- ''which at least seemed a step up from a pedophile.'' Cold comfort indeed. He is also a crook, selling property he doesn't own and bilking the trust money that their mother, a long-suffering woman pickled in booze, had set aside for David and Cynthia. The book becomes a tragicomic struggle between David's better self and an Oedipal fantasy of killing his father, a mortifying compulsion that prompts his girlfriend to set him straight: ''You can't spend your life writing a family history when there's no one who will want to read it. You can't spend your life in reaction to your family, mostly your father, because that means you're still his wounded little boy.'' Unfortunately for him, David can spend his life this way, and his marriage collapses while he persists with his history of the Upper Peninsula, compiling material as doggedly as Casaubon with his ''Key to All Mythologies'' in ''Middlemarch.''
 There is no denying the urgency of Harrison's storytelling, or his passionate involvement in the fate of his embattled hero. One comes to like David's slightly wistful tone and ''that curiously destructive bravery of the Midwesterner who never quite knows when to cut and run.'' But the novel is not without its problems. For one thing, there is something slovenly about the prose, be it Harrison's unreliable punctuation (he has an aversion to the comma), his insistence on the pronoun ''I'' instead of ''me'' (as in a lecture that ''left Fred and I in tears'') or his simple misuse of a word. For example, he seems to think ''enervated'' means ''unnerved,'' as in ''she was enervated by the feral cat.'' These solecisms are obviously not fatal, but they do throw off the reader's concentration.
 ONE can't help noticing, also, a tendency to jump the narrative gun. Both the 1970's and 1980's sections of the novel begin with the report of a significant character's death, before the story switches back to a time when that person was still alive. It is hard to know why Harrison is so offhand with his timing; the deaths of those characters, which affect the narrator deeply, are less moving for us because they are prematurely revealed. There must be a rationale here, because the novel's prologue also opens with a death that is answered by an echo at the conclusion.
 ''True North'' finishes strongly, as David tries to effect a reconciliation with his father; dried out at last, the old man admits that he too had a hateful father whom he wanted to kill: ''The ultimate bully. . . . After being raised by him World War II was a relief.'' In this disclosure resides the book's mournful take on patrimony, and one is irresistibly reminded of Philip Larkin's lines: ''Man hands on misery to man. / It deepens like a coastal shelf. / Get out as early as you can, / And don't have any kids yourself.'' This sprawling, rackety novel will not do a great deal for Jim Harrison's reputation as a stylist, but in his portrait of a father and a son he has made an indelible addition to the gallery of literature's ''bad dads.''

 his narrator loves sex and fishing. (Photograph by Mathieu Bourgois)

HEADLINE: In Step With Marching Bands

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER REARDON. 
Christopher Reardon, an Ohio native, is an arts writer who lives in New York.

 BODY:
NOTHING draws a crowd in Columbus, Ohio, like college football, a civic ritual that combines choreographed steps with seat-of-the-pants improvisation. Concert dance is a much harder sell, but faced with a tight economy, BalletMet, the local ballet company, is rewriting its playbook in a bid to win bigger, younger audiences.
 Last year this 28-member troupe performed onstage with Ohio State University's marching band. This spring it began dancing to music by Moby, whose pulsating beats are more commonly heard at nightclubs and frat parties than at the ballet. 
 Gerard Charles, BalletMet's artistic director, agreed that such moves might have raised a few eyebrows back at the Royal Ballet School in London, where he trained as a dancer in the 1970's. But he insisted that the company, which will make its Manhattan debut on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, was not selling its soul. 
 ''Our constant source of frustration is the inertia of getting people out of their homes and into the theater,'' Mr. Charles, 48, said in a recent telephone interview. ''Once they're in their seats they can't understand why they haven't been before.''
 New Yorkers might also find something to like. This week's program at the Joyce features commissioned works by two highly regarded choreographers, James Kudelka and Stanton Welch, and one emerging talent, Deanna Carter.
 ''BalletMet is a very strong regional ballet company with a unique voice,'' said Mr. Welch, 34, an Australian dynamo who is artistic director at the Houston Ballet and moonlights as artistic associate at BalletMet. ''I've been impressed by its dramatic flair as well as its dancing ability.''
 Columbus, after all, is not exactly a cultural backwater. This rapidly growing city is home to the Wexner Center for the Arts, a lively playground for experimental artists who come -- often from New York -- for more creative time and space.
 BalletMet, with an annual budget of $5.2 million, ranks among the country's 15 largest professional dance companies. Its affiliated school is also one of the nation's biggest, with about 1,000 students each week. 
 Now in its 26th season, the troupe has never run a deficit, said Cheri Mitchell, its executive director. But in recent years it has seen a decline in corporate and government support. Ticket sales also slumped before rebounding in January. Luckily, individual donors have picked up much of the slack. But even so, Ms. Mitchell said, BalletMet must raise an additional $100,000 by June 30 to stay in the black this fiscal year.
 At home the company performs large-scale story ballets at the 2,800-seat Ohio Theater; it presents mixed bills of shorter dances at the 800-seat Capitol Theater. Still, BalletMet sells fewer tickets each year (about 75,000) than the university's football team does for a single home game (more than 100,000). 
 One way to bring in more money down the road might be to focus on story ballets, which cost more to produce but fill more seats. But Mr. Charles cautioned that there are only so many worth staging. ''We don't want to end up doing 'The Three Musketeers' and 'Peter Pan,' '' he said. ''That could kill you artistically.''
 Instead he reaffirmed his intention to commission shorter works and to reach out to new audiences. In a novel endeavor, the troupe performed on campus last year with the marching band in ''Ballet in Scarlet and Gray,'' whose title refers to the school colors. The piece coincided with BalletMet's 25th anniversary, as well as the school's recent national championship in football, but it was no mere pat on the back. 
 With the United States then on the brink of war with Iraq, the choreographer Susan Hadley, a veteran of the Mark Morris Dance Group, was wary of striking a righteous or triumphal tone. 
 ''The question was: how could I make a work that I could stand behind artistically?'' said Ms. Hadley, a Columbus native who now teaches in the university's dance department. ''Ultimately, I chose to celebrate qualities I admire in my community and in my country. We are a culture that is still trying to be religiously tolerant, for example, and we are still working on our experiment in pluralism.'' 
 To convey such values onstage, she enlisted a cantor from a local synagogue and a pair of dancers familiar with Islamic and Christian prayer. Together they performed a trio that suggested, through stylized movements, these different spiritual traditions. In another section, as the musicians marched in formation to spell the name Ohio, she brought on a diverse group of local residents to dot the ''i'', a role usually reserved for a sousaphone player.
 Mr. Kudelka, the artistic director at the National Ballet of Canada, also created a piece for the program, which was presented at the Wexner Center. Called ''Gazebo Dances,'' it was set to music written by John Corigliano, the Pulitzer Prize-winning composer, and performed by the university's acclaimed Wind Symphony. (BalletMet will reprise it, with recorded music, during its run at the Joyce.) 
 The program drew 5,500 people over two nights. ''They came for the marching band,'' Mr. Charles said. ''But they ended up seeing a world premiere by Kudelka and hearing a live rendition of Corigliano.'' 
 Since then, he said, more students are buying tickets to see BalletMet perform downtown. The company is also making plans to return to campus next year. 
 Also on the bill this week is an excerpt from Mr. Welch's newest dance, ''Evolution,'' which had its premiere a few weeks ago at the Capitol Theater. In New York the troupe will perform the first section, ''Play,'' a flurry of pedestrian movement that evokes contemporary urban life. The dancing is accompanied by songs from Moby's album of the same name, which was released in 1999 and went double platinum.
 The third piece on the program, ''Colores de Alma,'' was first staged in Columbus in February. Choreographed by Ms. Carter, a Seattle native who works chiefly in Germany, it casts Spanish flamenco dancing in a modern light.
 Mr. Charles hoped that, both in New York and back home, such dances might spark new interest in his chosen field. ''There will always be some people who don't like ballet,'' he said. ''I don't get that. But then I don't attend a lot of football games either.''

BalletMet
Joyce Theater, Tuesday-next Sunday

HEADLINE: Four Designs Compete For Les Halles Makeover

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING

DATELINE: PARIS 

 BODY:
TEARS were shed when the 19th-century iron-and-glass market known as Les Halles was torn down in the early 1970's, and before long weeping resumed, first over the giant hole that scarred the heart of Paris for a decade, then over the grim multifloor shopping mall and transportation hub that eventually filled it. In this city, at least, the ugliness of Les Halles today is matched only by that of the Tour Montparnasse, the single skyscraper in central Paris. Many here would love to see both demolished.
 Not much can be done about the Tour Montparnasse, but Bertrand Delanoe, the first Socialist mayor of Paris, has now pledged to transform the district of Les Halles. And he has invited Parisians to study and debate four competing designs, all immensely ambitious, all calling for a radical reorganization of the area's buildings and gardens. No price tag has been set, but the city government has said it will make its choice this summer, perhaps combining elements from different proposals, with the first phase of work due for completion in 2007. 
 Major building projects are no novelty for Paris. In the 1980's, the courtyard of the Louvre was excavated to make room for I.M. Pei's glass pyramid, while the Place de la Bastille was disrupted to accommodate the Bastille Opera. Then, in the early 1990's, President Francois Mitterrand ordered up a new National Library of France on the Left Bank of the Seine. Today, things are quieter, with only President Jacques Chirac's pet project, the Musee du Quai Branly for primitive art, rising beside the Eiffel Tower. It is expected to open in 2006. 
 So Mr. Delanoe has decided the time is ripe to polish Paris anew. And he has found a good excuse for doing so. Along with London, New York, Rio de Janeiro, Moscow and a half-dozen other cities, Paris is bidding to play host to the 2012 Summer Olympic Games. Many experts consider Paris a favorite because it already boasts good sports facilities. Wherever they are held, however, Olympic games always offer the occasion for urban renewal. And, in Mr. Delanoe's view, Les Halles is a prime candidate for a makeover.
 The main reason is that today, Les Halles is frankly sleazy. Although barely 300 yards west of the Georges Pompidou Center, its fast-food cafes and tourist shops draw not only young people but also drug traffickers and petty criminals. Its Forum, the main glass and aluminum building, which includes shops, movie theaters and even a museum, looks run-down and uninviting. Below the Forum, some 800,000 commuters crowd through its Metro and suburban R.E.R. stations daily. It has become, the mayor concluded, ''a soulless architecturally bombastic concrete jungle.''
 Last month, he unveiled designs by two French and two Dutch firms. Jean Nouvel, the French architect who designed the Musee du Quai Branly, proposes a vast roof garden over the commercial area as well as a wooden music conservatory in adjacent gardens. Rem Koolhaas, the renowned Dutch architect, is more radical, filling the area with multicolored glass structures resembling perfume bottles. The Dutch M.V.R.D.V. firm headed by Winy Maas suggests covering most of the area with glass, transparent in places, with vegetation in others. Finally, David Mangin, another French architect, opts for a minimalist approach, placing a copper and glass roof over the Forum, with an avenue like the Ramblas in Barcelona cutting through the gardens.
 But what happens if Parisians, notably the vocal 7,000 residents of the quarter, dislike all four proposals? Photographs and models of the designs are on display in the Forum, while the local daily, Le Parisien, has invited visitors to its Web site, www.leparisien.fr, to study computer images and express their preference (Mr. Nouvel's design is the most popular to date among these voters). At the same time, older residents, who bitterly recall the endless squabbling and delays of the 1970's, are already alarmed at the prospect of a new upheaval.
 ''This is such a symbol of the heart of Paris that we cannot afford to make a mistake,'' Mr. Delanoe has conceded. ''We should never forget that Les Halles forms part of our history.'' Yet, he added, in reorganizing a neighborhood that was already populated in the 12th century, the city will have to take risks. 
 Mr. Delanoe too will be taking risks. Today, he enjoys considerable popularity -- his gamble in 2002 and 2003 to turn the banks of the Seine into a city beach paid off handsomely -- but he also aspires to higher office. Like Mr. Chirac before him, he would like to go from City Hall to the Elysee Palace. With presidential elections due in 2007, what happens to Les Halles may well determine if he has a chance.

HEADLINE: Mix of Idealism and Resume-Building Motivates Americans Seeking Jobs in Iraq

BYLINE: By GLEN JUSTICE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 22 

 BODY:
Ty Cobb Jr. was fresh from law school and eager to add to a resume that already included answering mail in the Virginia governor's office when he heard through contacts that the Bush administration was looking to fill civilian jobs in Iraq.
 So despite having little foreign experience beyond touring Europe and studying there for a summer, Mr. Cobb headed to Baghdad. He has since traveled the country -- often packing a 9-millimeter pistol or an AK-47 -- to help educate Iraqis about democracy. He says he is committed to the United States' mission there, but he is not shy about saying that there are career calculations behind his adventure: he hopes it will lead to a government job.
 ''If they look at a resume and see that someone picked up and moved to Iraq for seven months, they will put their faith in you to handle the rigors of any position,'' Mr. Cobb said. 
 Hundreds of Americans have converged on Iraq for all kinds of reasons. Some consider it rewarding to try to bring democracy to the Iraqis. Some are in it for the adventure. For some, it is a combination of the experience, the fervor for supporting the administration's goals and the sense that it is more exciting than work back home.
 Many of these recruits have top-notch skills. But the downside, foreign policy experts say, is that some lack the proper experience for such difficult and often unsafe assignments.
 ''A vast number of people are being recruited who have no qualifications, no background, and who have never done anything serious in the U.S.,'' said Anthony Cordesman, a Middle East expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington.
 Daniel Benjamin, who is also at the center working on the postconflict reconstruction project, said some who go to Iraq were altruistic, some were opportunistic and others were just doing a job.
 ''For better or worse, this is the biggest show in town and it's a place to get your ticket punched,'' Mr. Benjamin said.
 The jobs are filled by the Coalition Provisional Authority, the United States civilian administration that is running Iraq. Created just over a year ago, the authority has about 1,160 employees, including more than 325 members of the military and about 150 workers from other countries, according to authority officials. Some are on loan from government agencies in Washington, while others have been hired from the outside. Most recruiting is done through a Defense Department Web page called Sofia (Support Our Friends in Iraq and Afghanistan), which seeks people interested in ''assisting the fledgling governments in their quest to become full-fledged democracies.''
 ''People who submit a resume need to understand that conditions may be harsh, primitive and hazardous,'' the Web page says. ''Conversely, there may be few opportunities in life to make such a lasting contribution to world peace.''
 The authority has received more than 11,000 resumes, and though officials say political affiliation carries no standing, Republican connections seem to help some of them stand out. 
 Mike Hardiman, 43, a former aide to a Republican congressman, was self-employed as a Washington lobbyist and public relations specialist when a Pentagon official he would not identify asked him to go to Iraq. As a lobbyist Mr. Hardiman has handled clients like the American Land Rights Association, which represents property owners opposed to government land regulation. 
 In Iraq, he is a spokesman for the occupation authority, working with a portion of the Iraqi government that, among other things, works on land and infrastructure issues. ''Things like traffic circles, sewers and zoning codes are interesting to me,'' Mr. Hardiman said.
 Mr. Hardiman tells of having to explain to Iraqi reporters that a $10 million beautification effort will not be used to erect statues of President Bush. The truth in Iraq, he says, is sometimes stranger than fiction. But he says he believes in what the United States is doing.
 ''Free speech, an open economy and democracy are the genies that have been let out of the bottle, and they will not be put back in,'' he wrote in an e-mail message. ''There will be successes and setbacks, but freedom will win, I see it firsthand every day.''
 Rich Galen, 57, is a former press aide to Dan Quayle and Newt Gingrich with extensive international experience who runs an online Republican newsletter called Mullings. He worked in the authority's press office, helping broadcast reporters from smaller markets. 
 Mr. Galen, who is now back in the United States, said he got his invitation from the White House, but he too declined to say who called. ''When they ask you to go, the only answer is 'When can I leave?' '' he said.
 Job descriptions originate on the ground in Iraq, and candidates are found through the database of applicants that Sofia provides. Occupation officials say that all candidates are selected to fill specific jobs according to their credentials, and that many have specific skills that are in demand, like fluency in Arabic or a deep knowledge of health care, financial markets and other policy areas.
 ''Those who are here believe in the mission,'' said Dan Senor, a spokesman for the occupation authority. ''They want a hand in building democracy in Iraq.''
 Most stay from six months to a year, sometimes less, working six-day weeks and often living in the secure part of Baghdad known as the green zone. Those who work outside the zone, where many of the ministries are based, travel heavily guarded. Body armor is common, and many also carry guns. 
 Mr. Cobb, 28, was searching for a job in Washington last year when he heard about the positions in Iraq while at a meeting at the Pentagon to get job advice. His father had served on the National Security Council staff in the Reagan White House, which helped open doors like this.
 The idea immediately appealed to Mr. Cobb, who became interested in a career in counterterrorism or national security after losing a friend in the Sept. 11 attacks. Like many who now serve in Iraq, he said he believed strongly in the war and the efforts that followed. Those who support the war, he said, have a duty to do what they can.
 ''The whole reason I'm here is that I believe it is part of an effort to make America a more secure place,'' Mr. Cobb said. ''That seems to be the general feeling people have.''
 Though conditions in the green zone may be safer than those outside it, many of those interviewed said their routine in Iraq was a radical departure from the lives they had left back home as students, political consultants or employees of government agencies.
 Many spend their days in or around Saddam Hussein's massive palace, which now serves as headquarters for the occupation authority. Meals are eaten in a cafeteria there. Quarters for those who arrive are often large, communal rooms packed with dozens of workers .
 On their first night in Baghdad many have bunked in what is known as the chapel, which several workers described as a religious chamber known for its mural of missiles being launched. Later, they move to four-person trailers that are placed all over the green zone, each surrounded by a wall of sandbags. 
 War stories are common. Many workers interviewed told of being awakened by explosions, and of rocket and mortar attacks that missed them by only a few hundred feet. Even when there is a break in the violence, workers think about the friends who have been killed or wounded. Though only two Americans on the occupation staff have been killed, according to the Pentagon, many workers in Iraq know contractors, locals and workers from other countries who have been victims of the violence. Then there are stories like the decapitation of Nicholas Berg, a contractor, which present the danger in the starkest terms.
 ''Sometimes I feel like this is an evil place, because people are doing terrible things to each other,'' said Elizabeth Cote, 27, a medical student on leave from Harvard University to work on health care policy and volunteer in a combat hospital. ''But it may be the most positive experience in my life. There are examples of kindness and people putting their life on the line to do things.''
 Still, tough conditions have not stopped people from taking these jobs. Iraq offers opportunities to some that they cannot get elsewhere. 
 Jacques Myers, 48, was a civilian firefighter at a military base in Wisconsin who came to train Iraqis. Two weeks after his arrival, his boss left and Mr. Myers was placed in charge of advising the country's 8,400 firefighters, a force comparable to the fire department of a major American city.
 ''It's something I'd never be able to do stateside,'' he said. ''I control $200 million worth of equipment.''
 Van Smith, 23, was at lunch one day when he ran into a college friend and the friend's father, Steve Casteel, a senior American adviser to Iraq's Interior Ministry. They started talking about Iraq.
 Mr. Smith was working at his first job after college, as director of public outreach at the College of William and Mary in Virginia, his alma mater. He happened to be reading a biography of Winston Churchill at the time.
 ''I was at the chapter where we were the same age and he was having life adventure after life adventure,'' he said. ''I was saying I wish I had a chance to be involved in something international and in war, I wish I had a chance to make a difference in a foreign place.''
 He had a resume to Mr. Casteel before the day ended.

LENGTH: 1228 words

HEADLINE: Four 30's Apartment Buildings on 4 Chelsea Corners

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
THE freshly pointed brick, crisp new windows and construction scaffolding at 201 West 16th Street reflect only repair work, but they make the orange brick apartment house look as if it is just nearing completion.
 The early 1930's building is one of four similar structures on 15th and 16th Streets along Seventh Avenue that were the opening wedge in Henry Mandel's unfinished campaign to rebuild Seventh Avenue below 23rd Street with a group of tall apartment buildings. What he called Chelsea Corners was a visionary plan -- it's a pity Mandel began the project just before the Depression.
 In 1927, Chelsea property owners noticed that an unknown buyer was accumulating big corners on Seventh Avenue north of 14th Street. Although the IRT subway expansion had come down that route in the 1910's, this section of Seventh was still just a stretch of miscellaneous old structures. It soon came out that the buyer was Mandel, 43, who had begun his real estate career building tenements and other modest buildings with his father, Samuel, who brought the family to the United States from the Ukraine in the late 1880's. 
 Mandel predicted that the 17 buildings he envisioned would cost $50 million. He filed plans for the first one, 200 West 16th Street, in July 1929, three months before the stock market crash. Plans for three other buildings -- 200 West 15th, 161 West 16th and 201 West 16th -- followed quickly, and the buildings were completed in 1930 and 1931. Another, at 200 West 22nd, was never built. 
 Mandel was part of a new housing movement in New York City that built smaller, efficient dwellings in large complexes for white-collar employees who wanted to live close to work and would trade a prestige neighborhood for transit convenience. He also sought to remake the neighborhood by dominating one stretch of real estate with complementary structures, and he planned a separate building with meeting rooms and sports facilities. 
 The first element of Chelsea Corners was completed in late 1930, the 18-story-high 200 West 16th. With nine apartments per floor, it was heavily marketed to singles and working couples. Early ads listed prices for one-room apartments as $76 to $145 per month, and four-room apartments as $160 to $270 per month. 
 Like other such buildings, 200 West 16th had space-saving Murphy beds, but with a twist: instead of folding down from a false doorway, they pivoted around on a track from an oversized clothes closet and then unfolded to the floor. 
 A 1931 article in the magazine Buildings and Building Management said that the steel casement windows used in all four buildings of Chelsea Corners were ''given prominent attention in renting and advertising,'' suggesting that such windows were considered a modern improvement over the old wooden double-hung installations.
 Almost simultaneously, Mandel had other projects under way or just finished: his giant London Terrace development, with 1,761 apartments, on the full block of 23rd to 24th Street and Ninth to Tenth Avenue, and his more expensive Parc Vendome, with 600 apartments, just east of Ninth Avenue on a through-block site from 56th to 57th Street. He also built other more conventional buildings, like the Lombardy apartment hotel at 111 East 56th Street, where he lived, and the Pershing Square Building, at 42nd and Park Avenue. 
 Mandel set up an ''Apartment Shop'' at 36th and Fifth Avenue, where he presented five full-size apartments, completely furnished. The two-level store even had sections of the exterior walls laid up so that ''Mrs. Prospect Can Select Her Apartment Just as She Would Select Her Car,'' as a 1931 article in Buildings and Building Management put it.
 In 1930 and 1931 Mandel gamely continued with Chelsea Corners in the face of the Depression. In a 1931 article, ''Build During a Depression? There Are Advantages,'' in the magazine Building Investment and Maintenance, he predicted that economic troubles in the United States would be over in a relatively short period. ''In the broad scheme of things, even six years is not a vast amount of time,'' he said. 
 But Mandel was never able to continue with the rest of his project, and in 1932 he filed for bankruptcy, listing assets of $380,000 and liabilities of $14 million. The four completed apartment houses of Chelsea Corners went into separate ownership.
 The developer went to jail for two months in 1933 because he owed $19,000 in alimony to his former wife, Bertha. One of his final projects was a two-story theater and nightclub at 79th and Madison; he died in 1942. 
 No successor took on Mandel's expansive vision for Seventh Avenue, but construction did continue on the street, which has buildings from the 40's, 50's and 60's occupying some of Mandel's potential corners, and even a few built in the last couple of years. 
 SO the ordered symmetry conceived as Chelsea Corners has emerged with a ragged aspect, and the four corners where Mandel actually did build do offer a spot of harmony. All were designed by Farrar & Watmough; the Chelsea Corners buildings share with London Terrace -- also by Farrar & Watmough -- a variegated orange brick. 
 The building at 200 West 15th Street has some chunky, Assyrian-style ornament with Romanesque-style details. But the buildings at 161 West 16th and 201 West 16th are really the gatekeepers of Chelsea Corners. They have the pointed arches, label moldings, crockets and other details characteristic of the Gothic style, but in the varied brickwork there is also something of the Romanesque.
 The Chelsea Corners lobbies make an interesting study. Those at 200 West 15th and 200 West 16th have nice vaulted ceilings and polychromed tile decoration, but the one at 161 West 16th got what was probably thought to be an ''Art Deco'' makeover perhaps 15 years ago. 
 Three of the four buildings have replaced their steel casement windows with common one-over-one aluminum windows, which serve to deaden the liveliness that Farrar & Watmough sought to impart. But the co-op at 201 West 16th has bucked the trend of the lowest common denominator and has just finished installing near-replicas of the original steel casement windows. 
 ''This co-op is very, very much into the architecture of the building -- from day one they were going to do it this way, and they're really happy with it,'' says Mary Frances Shaughnessy, an owner of Tudor Realty Services, the managing agent. The co-op is also midway through a program of facade repairs. (The building at 161 West 16th is also a co-op; the other two are rentals.)
 The replicas are not perfect -- the frames are thicker than the original steel, and the co-op has specified a black finish -- while the original windows were more likely buff, orange or some color complementary to the masonry. But the obvious desire to do something more appropriate -- as well as the design itself -- gives the building life, while the standard replacement windows in the other buildings are just black eyes.
 In the unlikely event that some future owner wants to find the exact profiles of Mandel's original casement windows, there are a few dozen left. In the 1980's, the clothing store Barney's took over the first four floors on the Seventh Avenue side of 161 West 16th; the space is now occupied by Loehmann's. Barney's blocked up the window openings, but left the original steel casement windows in place.

HEADLINE: Different Fight, Same Battleground

BYLINE: By AVI SALZMAN

 BODY:
LONG ISLAND SOUND has become a repository for all the dregs and dredgings of humankind. People sweep the leaves from their yards into a wormy pile, and the rain washes the piles of leaves, along with pesticides and dirt and dust from construction sites and the oily grime of highways, into drains and rivers, which carry the muck south.
 When the rivers empty into the Sound, civilization's waste builds in channels, which are squeezed so narrow that boaters maneuvering through the channels are caught in traffic jams on busy Sundays in summer or even get stuck. Last summer a sailboat ran aground in the channel in Milford and the owner broke his leg. Commercial boats have less and less room to move. At low tide, some sailboats can't leave or return to their harbors. 
 No one likes the muck and everyone seems to agree that it needs to be scooped out and hauled away. But where to put it? That question has caused the latest rift between Connecticut and Long Island. After a five-year process to figure out how to dispose of the mud in Connecticut's harbors, the federal government picked two spots, both in the Sound. One is two nautical miles north of Lloyd Point on Long Island and 2.5 miles south of Long Neck Point in Noroton. The other is more than 10 nautical miles north of Shoreham, N.Y., and 5.6 miles south of South End Point in East Haven.
 Long Island and Connecticut have argued relentlessly over the last few years about numerous issues involving the Sound, including the placement and use of an underwater natural gas line and the Cross Sound Cable connecting New England's power grid to Long Island. ''The Cross Sound Cable, the natural gas pipeline -- the timing of this sort of feud on these couple of issues certainly is unfortunate,'' said Mel Cote, the manager of the federal Environmental Protection Agency's water quality unit in New England. ''There just seems to be some bad blood.''
 Although the dredging issue would appear to be a largely political battle, with high-level officials on both sides laying claim to the waterway, residents have gotten involved. Meetings about the proposal to dump 20 million cubic yards of dredged material primarily from Connecticut harbors and marinas over the next 20 years have attracted dozens of people. The federal Environmental Protection Agency has created a massive appendix to an environmental impact statement about the dredging full of comments from the public and answers to these comments. The public has until June 1 to respond to the impact statement. If the process moves forward as planned, dumping wouldn't likely begin until early fall.
 At a recent meeting in Stamford, Long Islanders and other opponents of the plan questioned and sometimes berated scientists working for Connecticut and the federal government. An environmental group opposing the plan had gathered more than 4,000 signatures from residents in both New York and Connecticut who oppose the plan.
 Dumping dredged material in the Sound is nothing new: It has been going on for more than 100 years, according to Mr. Cote of the E.P.A. The two proposed dumping spots have already been used to dump dredged material for at least 20 years without significant impact, he added.
 Material has been dumped ''in the Long Island Sound for a really long time,'' he said.
 The material is tested extensively before any of it is dumped, Mr. Cote said. The Sound is the only inland waterway protected by the federal Ocean Dumping Act, which has high standards for disposing dredged material, he said. Material deemed ''unsuitable'' is removed from the rest of the muck and treated or buried deep underground.
 So why all the fuss?
 For many Long Island residents, the prospect of billions of pounds of dredged material being dumped nearby for the next 20 years is frightening. People who stood up at the meeting in Stamford expressed their fears of the unknown: will children become sick; will the shellfish begin to die off again, will beaches be closed because the dirty sediment has drifted?
 Suzanne Keefe of Stony Point, N.Y., with relatives in Long Island, attended the meeting after reading a flier about the issue. She goes to reunions every year near Merrick in Long Island and watches her young cousins swim and catch fish in the Sound. The prospect of mud from Connecticut's harbors floating into their swimming areas inspired her to speak out.
 ''I've seen a harbor. I've seen a marina,'' she said. ''I know what that water looks like and I don't like the idea of my family members swimming in it.''
 Although scientists with state and federal agencies have said the material that will be dumped is tested thoroughly and no ''unsuitable'' material will be dumped, many Long Islanders were doubtful. Previous federal policies that were supposed to be safe have proven disastrous, said Steve Levy, the Suffolk County executive. Dredged material from places like Bridgeport will inevitably be contaminated, he said.
 ''This isn't just some benign sandy beach they're dredging,'' Mr. Levy said.
 The state has invested millions in cleaning up the Sound, which is just recovering from years of pollution, he said.
 ''Why spend millions on one hand to clean up the Sound and then allow for an ill-advised decision to dump these spoils in the same venue you're trying to improve,'' Mr. Levy said.
 After the E.P.A. published its draft Environmental Impact Statement in September 2003, the agency received more than 400 letters, e-mail messages and faxes and listened to 47 people speak at public hearings.
 Among those comments were suggestions for alternative ways to dispose of dredged materials, including depositing the material farther into the ocean or finding an inland use for it.
 Adrienne Esposito, the executive director of Citizens Campaign for the Environment, an environmental organization based in White Plains, N.Y., said other states have found beneficial ways to reuse dredged spoils. In Elizabeth, N.J., for instance, the city capped a landfill with dredged material and has now placed a mall on the site of the former dump, she said.
 Those alternative methods, state and federal officials said, would cost much more than dumping the material in the two designated areas. The Army Corps of Engineers is required to use the least expensive way to dispose of the material, as long as it's safe for the environment.
 ''If we have a range of alternatives that are environmentally acceptable we have to pick the least costly,'' said Mark L. Habel, the project manager for the corps.
 Dumping the material in the two sites will generally cost around $10 or less per cubic yard, while dumping it on land would cost closer to $35 to more than $100 a yard, Mr. Habel said. The material will be dredged from harbors in New York and Connecticut west of Guilford, with a small percentage of the material likely coming from Long Island harbors.
 The plan's opponents argued that choosing a more expensive option now could save the government money in the long-term.
 ''What will cost more will be to pollute the Sound and spend 10 times that amount to clean it up,'' Mr. Levy said.
 Cost isn't only an issue for the government. Cities and private marinas use the same dump sites. In Milford, one of the smaller harbors in Connecticut, the city has to pay to dredge its marina every few years. The last time the city dredged, it cost about $60,000, said Richard S. Hosking, the operations director for Milford's Harbor Management Commission. Without a long-term cost-effective dumping site, the silt and sediment will overrun the city's harbor and channel, Mr. Hosking said, as he accompanied visitors on a tour of the harbor earlier this month.
 Three buoys that had been placed in a line had begun to shift as they were pushed by sediment from a nearby stream. The depth of water in the channel leading boaters out of the harbor has fallen from 10 to six-and-a-half feet at low tide, Mr. Hosking said. The dredging proposal wouldn't necessarily alleviate the short-term concerns of harbor owners, but it will give them a long-term dumping spot so problems like this won't persist.
 ''I'm sorry to say we have mud and we've got to put it somewhere,'' he said. ''We're not asking to expand anything. We just want to maintain what we have. It would be a financial disaster if Milford or all the Milfords in Long Island Sound would be unable to maintain what they have at a cost that's affordable.''
 Marina operators have been vocal at meetings, arguing that the plan needs to be passed soon to secure their economic interests and the safety of boaters. The mud is safer if it's out in deep water rather than collecting in a marina where people work and play every day, they argued.
 Operators of lobster boats are split on the effects of dredging on their business. At public meetings in Long Island, some argued that their business, which they said has just begun to rejuvenate after a prolonged decrease in the lobster population, could suffer setbacks because of increased dumping at the sites.
 But others disagree about the long-term effects.
 ''Any effect would be short-lived,'' said Bill Damicis, who caught lobsters for 23 years before going to work for Milford Boat Works. ''I don't believe it would be long-lasting.''
 Mr. Damicis said he has set traps around an active disposal site in New Haven Harbor and said the dredging did not create long-term problems with his catch.
 Caught up in the arguments about dredging is the feud between Connecticut and Long Island over the use of the Sound. The Cross-Sound Cable, a 330-megawatt electric line that stretches from New Haven to Shoreham, N.Y., was switched off earlier this month on orders from Spencer Abraham, the federal energy secretary. The line had been operating on emergency orders since the August 2003 blackout. Connecticut officials argued it was environmentally unsound because it was not buried deep enough under the water. Attorney General Richard Blumenthal had even filed a lawsuit to turn the power line off. Now that the line is off, Long Island officials have threatened legal action to get it turned back on. A Congressional subcommittee heard testimony from both sides last week on the issue.
 Connecticut's position on the cable is hypocritical given the state's position on dredging, Mr. Levy said. If the state is so concerned about the environmental impacts of the cable, officials should also be opposing the dumping.
 ''It's just a lot of contradictions here,'' he said.
 In a letter obtained by Mr. Levy's office, the commissioner of the Connecticut D.E.P., Arthur J. Rocque Jr., wrote in June 2002 that he was ''disappointed'' with Mr. Blumenthal's characterization of the cable's negative impact on the environment.
 ''From an environmental perspective, this cable project pales in comparison to even maintenance dredging of the federal navigational channel in New Haven Harbor,'' he wrote. Mr. Rocque added later in the letter that he wasn't trying to ''express concern'' over the dredging, but wanted to put the cable project in perspective.
 Mr. Rocque said in a recent interview that he was simply reacting to Mr. Blumenthal's ''overheated rhetoric'' on the cable, adding that he supports the E.P.A.'s proposal on dredging.
 George Wisker, senior environmental analyst for the D.E.P, said the agency has studied the effects of dumping and is confident that it can be done safely.
 ''We've gone on record as saying that dredging is absolutely necessary to maintain the safety and the ability to use our ports on both the Connecticut and Long Island sides,'' he said. ''This proposal to designate the sites is not a new issue. Disposal has been going on for many, many years. It has not caused environmental problems.''
 But Long Islanders and other opponents aren't taking his word and the turf war continues.
 ''People who live near the water come to think of it as their own,'' Ms. Keefe said. ''That's my Sound.''

HEADLINE: Stadium Opponents Criticize City for Adopting Jets' Economic Study

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI

 BODY:
When Bank of America asked the city last year for more than $1 billion in tax-free bonds and other incentives to build a skyscraper on 42nd Street, the city took nothing for granted and had its own economists analyze the potential economic impact of the project. 
 When the Yankees and Mets revived discussions last year about each of them building an $800 million stadium, the city hired a consultant to assess the value of the professional sports teams to the city's economy and a possible municipal investment.
 Yet, when it came to the New York Jets' proposal to build a $1.4 billion stadium on the West Side of Manhattan, the city simply reviewed and adopted an economic impact study commissioned by the football team. An independent analysis either by economists at the city's Economic Development Corporation, or by a consultant, might have produced the same results. But the unusual break with a routine practice has made some officials at City Hall nervous and outraged opponents of the Jets stadium. 
 The Jets contend that the proposed 75,000-seat stadium, which requires $600 million in cash from the city and the state, would generate $27.5 million more in annual tax revenue than it would cost government in bond payments. 
 ''This is the problem we've had with them from the beginning: there's no independent analysis,'' said Walter Mankoff, chairman of Community Board 4 on the West Side and an opponent of the stadium. ''City money is at risk here. They're blind to all the alternatives.''
 The stadium, which would be built over the railyards bounded by 30th and 34th Streets, between 11th and 12th Avenues, would also serve as an Olympic stadium if the city is successful in its bid for the 2012 Summer Games. On Tuesday, the International Olympic Committee selected New York as one of five finalists for the games.
 ''The city is relying on the Jets for these revenue estimates,'' said Ronnie Lowenstein, director of the Independent Budget Office, a nonpartisan city agency, which is doing its own economic impact analysis of the stadium. ''It suggests how badly they want the project to proceed.''
 The Jets say they will put up $800 million for the stadium, more than any professional sports team has ever invested in a new facility. The state and the city are providing $600 million for a retractable roof and the platform over the railyards on which the stadium would be built.
 According to a study done by Ernst & Young for the Jets, the stadium would generate $72.5 million a year in new tax revenues for the city and the state from football and other sporting events, trade shows and circuses. City and state officials estimate that annual debt service payments would cost them about $45 million, leaving a surplus of $27.5 million.
 Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff said the city was ''comfortable'' with the results of the Jets' Ernst & Young study.
 ''The key conclusion is that there's a substantial net gain for the city and the state,'' said Mr. Doctoroff, who founded the city's NYC2012 Olympic bid committee before joining the Bloomberg administration.
 He said that the city had not yet found the need to do an independent analysis, ''given the fact that a reputable firm did a thorough analysis, and we had an opportunity to review it in great detail. That's not to say we won't eventually do our own.''
 According to current and former city officials, the city generally does its own economic analysis of so-called retention deals, in which a corporation threatens to leave the city unless it gets tax breaks and other incentives for a new building. Last year, Bank of America and the developer Douglas Durst asked for $1 billion in tax-free bonds and $80 million in sales tax breaks to build a 51-story tower at 42nd Street and Avenue of the Americas, according to one person involved in the negotiations.
 Economists at the Economic Development Corporation did an analysis and pared the numbers sharply, with the city ultimately agreeing to provide $650 million in bonds and about $50 million in tax breaks, although critics thought even that was too much.
 For larger deals involving cash investments, the city frequently hires a consultant, as it did last year when it asked the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche to do an analysis of revised stadium proposals from the Yankees and the Mets. Neither team was happy with the results and they have since hired their own consultants, according to a team official.
 There is no guarantee, however, that a consultant will come up with a different or more accurate result.
 ''There's a fair amount of uncertainty in any of these studies,'' said Robert Berne, a senior vice president at New York University and an expert in municipal finance. ''It's very hard to parse out the economic impact of any subject. The developer will always have one set of assumptions, and the city would probably cut it down using a different set of assumptions.''
 The Jets have gotten plenty of service from the Ernst & Young report. On March 15, Councilman David I. Weprin became one of the first members of the City Council to endorse the stadium, citing the economic benefits. Mr. Weprin, chairman of the Council's finance committee, acknowledged that he had based his evaluation on the Ernst & Young report.
 Mr. Weprin was back on the steps of City Hall with the Jets and members of Mr. Doctoroff's staff last Sunday when he promoted a report by Tishman Construction indicating that the Manhattan site was better than an alternative in Queens favored by many critics. Tishman, which may bid to be the construction manager for the project, said it had used the Ernst & Young report.
 ''This is not an ordinary, arms-length transaction,'' said Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, a Manhattan Democrat. ''This is driven by Deputy Mayor Doctoroff's personal vision of bringing the Olympics to New York. He married his idea to the Jets, a ready partner. I don't think the evidence, or the merits, play much of a role here.''


CORRECTION-DATE: May 28, 2004

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about the proposed Jets stadium in Manhattan misstated the number of City Hall staff members at a May 16 news conference in support of a West Side location for it. There was just one -- Jennifer Falk, the City Hall spokeswoman on duty that weekend, who also serves as spokeswoman to Deputy Mayor Daniel L. Doctoroff, a supporter of the stadium. It was not several members of his staff.

HEADLINE: Easy-Going, but Hands-On, at Trinity

BYLINE: By JANE GORDON

 BODY:
JIMMY JONES, aka Dr. James F. Jones, the new president of Trinity College, was telling one of his newest stories: an employee of Trinity College attended a reception in early April for scholarship recipients and their donors. She surveyed the scene, then said to the stranger standing next to her, ''You must have to give a lot of money to get invited to this.'' 
 ''Never enough,'' the stranger said to the woman. ''Never enough.'' 
 The stranger was Dr. Jones.
 He laughed as he told the story, partly because the woman was horrified when she discovered whom her aside was directed to, partly because the brief discourse was as telling of Dr. Jones's past as it may be of his future. Building endowments is one of Dr. Jones's strengths, a skill he has mastered. He has an intellect and savvy at enticing alumni, parents, friends and employees given to musing aloud at receptions to part with their dollars for the good of the school.
 Dr. Jones will be stepping into an academic leadership arena that has had its share of controversy in the last few years, from the recent retirement of Richard Judd from Central Connecticut State University after he was accused of plagiarism, to the resignation in 2003 of John Shumaker, a former president of Central Connecticut State, from the University of Tennessee after questions arose about his spending. University of Massachusetts President William M. Bulger also gave in to pressure to resign last year after news reports surfaced about his brother, a fugitive who was indicted for racketeering and 21 murders. Presidential hopscotch has been played often lately at private schools, too, particularly at Trinity, where four presidents, including the popular Evan Dobelle, have left office within the last five years. That beats the national average (5.3 years) for the length of time a private school president typically serves.
 One student leader said the constant changes had not helped the campus.
 ''Needless to say, it's been an erratic three-year stay at Trinity with a changeover between four different presidents and acting presidents,'' said Patricia Allen, a junior at Trinity. ''Students could have established a strong rapport and contributed enormously to improve existing programs. Instead, the administration was too wrapped up in resolving its own internal instability problems.''
 While at Trinity, the charismatic Mr. Dobelle pushed the State Legislature for $175 million and the state's power brokers for several million to create Hartford's Learning Corridor, grand new buildings that include an elementary, middle and high school, a job-training center, a Boys and Girls club and a social service agency. On campus, he rehabilitated dormitories and expanded and renovated the library and the performing arts center. He also pushed for increased student involvement; by the time he left Trinity, more than half its students were performing volunteer work in the community.
 Dr. Jones is known for taking a gentle approach, unlike his predecessor, Richard Hersh, an outspoken reformer who Trinity hired to fix its perceived reputation as a party school and who was pressured to leave after one year.
 The new president is a connoisseur of 18th-century culture who speaks French, Italian and Latin and who holds degrees from Columbia, the Sorbonne, Emory and the University of Virginia. He is an affable professor of humanities who said he would as much spend his days dissecting Rousseau as he would leading an academic institution. Dr. Jones has, in fact, spent many days dissecting Rousseau, writing numerous published articles and papers bearing such ominous titles as ''On Names as Masks: Rousseau as Renou,'' and ''Rousseau and the Failure of Autobiography.'' But he is not without his fun, as evidenced by a lecture he gave at a teachers' conference, ''Bending Ears and Changing Horses: Cliches We Do Not Need in Class.''
 Even though Connecticut has been straggling behind some states in its economic recovery, Dr. Jones said he is optimistic about increasing Trinity's $340 million endowment. By comparison, Yale University's endowment is $11 billion.
 ''We need to raise a lot of endowment money,'' Dr. Jones said. ''I would never have thought it possible to double the endowment at Kalamazoo, but we did. It occurred within three years of the country being in a deep recession. People were not very fortunate in their campaigns. We were.''
 At Kalamazoo College in Kalamazoo in Michigan, where Dr. Jones was president from 1996 until his official departure this summer, he used the money to champion building initiatives and support faculty causes.
 ''He tends to go above and beyond the minimum necessary and he does it with great style and ease,'' said Barry Ross, a professor of music at Kalamazoo who is familiar with Trinity from time spent in Connecticut earning degrees from Yale University and the Hartt School of Music at the University of Hartford. ''I'm very proud of him for moving to a larger school where his career will take leaps above what it was here.''
 Talk to Dr. Jones, though, and leaps and bounds are far from his mind. If Trinity is happy with him, he said, he will stay put.
 ''I don't play the hopscotch game,'' he said. ''They've had a rough go of it here. I'm trying to learn the poetry of Trinity and I'll just keep doing it until I succeed.''
 For Trinity, Dr. Jones is an unknown quantity. For one longtime mentor, though, he is anything but. Dr. John Wesley Chandler, a former president of Williams College, discovered Dr. Jones when he was chairman of the department of Romance Languages at Washington University in St. Louis. Dr. Chandler recommended that Dr. Jones take a vice provost position at Southern Methodist University, then the president's job at Kalamazoo College.
 ''The people at Trinity knew me,'' Dr. Chandler said. ''Jimmy's record at Kalamazoo was crucial. The fund-raising that he did there, the way he related to students; he knows a huge number of them, and the respect accorded him by students and by other constituencies as well.''
 Dr. Chandler paused a moment, then chuckled.
 ''After people hear his name, they have often asked me if he's a football coach or a southern evangelist,'' he said. ''Yes, I call him Jimmy. And I think he has the qualities one looks for in chief academic officers and presidents.''
 Trinity is anticipating his arrival, Ms. Allen said.
 ''I'm hoping that Jones will continue a more Dobell-ian reign.''
 Kalamazoo is lamenting his departure.
 ''He's a real hands-on person,'' Professor Ross said. ''He really took charge of everything, from the food service to the fund-raising. He will be very missed here.''

HEADLINE: The View From the End of Life's Assembly Line

BYLINE: By MAREK FUCHS

DATELINE: YONKERS 

 BODY:
IT was no journey of personal discovery that brought any of the three men to where they are in the here and now: living out their lives amid 2,000 coffins. Victor Ruggieri's job as a coffin salesman was going to be a quick stopover.
 That was nearly 50 years ago. 
 He started as a salesman, driving from funeral home to funeral home with brochures of boxes in his hand and a smile always on his face, even when he had to pitch his wares to a funeral director who was busily embalming a body. 
 ''I was going to do it until something better came along,'' said Mr. Ruggieri, 76, ''but I guess nothing did.'' 
 Twenty years into his career, he was working in a coffin distribution center when he got company, in the form of Theodore Anderson. Like Mr. Ruggieri, Mr. Anderson, now 45, was not overfearful about working in an industry suffused with death, but then again he wasn't so keen. The plan was to make a little money and then flee. But the paychecks, which he needed, kept coming, so he stayed on -- a young black man with a middle-aged white man -- as his relationship with Mr. Ruggieri ripened into one that both men describe as father-son. 
 The two men were recently joined by another in their office at the Brooklyn-based Milos Industries, which has the names of two long-ago coffin companies on the front of its 45 Morris Street location: South Brooklyn Casket and R. Conte Casket. 
 John Gonzalez, 23, recently took a job managing the coffin inventory because it paid well. Looking forward, he is not sure how long he is going to stay.
 Death may have its vagaries, but the sales of coffins are tangible and, in the end, quite reliable. The Casket and Funeral Supply Association of America in Lake Bluff, Ill., said that out of 2.4 million deaths in America in 2003, 1.8 million were considered ''casketed deaths.'' That number includes as many as 75,000 cremation containers, for a grand total of $1.4 billion. 
 From its Yonkers distribution center, Milos Industries sends coffins out to funeral homes as close as Westchester and as far away as West Africa. On a recent afternoon, Mr. Ruggieri, who lives in Bayside, Queens, was poring over an order form for four coffins, soon to be sent by cargo ship, to a doctor in West Africa who also sells coffins. 
 In its cavernous warehouse, the company stores coffins of every quality, from basic to plush. There is the entire range, from what Mr. Anderson, who lives in Teaneck, N.J., refers to as the ''Jewish'' line of plain wooden coffins (observant Jews are buried in either that or a shroud), to low-end coffins made of stiffened cloth, to coffins with a minimal amount of metal, to the S.U.V.'s of coffins, complete with water resistance, some with solid bronze or copper casings. (The company refused to give a price range.) 
 The economy, Mr. Anderson noted, has little impact on which coffins sell. ''Sometimes expensive white ones will be selling,'' he said, ''and then all of a sudden for a week, we'll get orders for five pinks. Maybe it's the moon.'' 
 The need to get so many coffins out to so many different places does not leave much time for reflection or repose. And though that has meant that Mr. Ruggieri has not done much in the way of long-term thinking about death, Mr. Anderson says he has.
 Not that he has come up with any answers about the great beyond. No. There, he has come up decidedly short. 
 ''Most people can keep the inevitable removed from their every-day and every-moment thoughts,'' he said, waving a hand at the stacks of coffins to explain why he cannot. ''It's not that they are comforted, but they sort of have an invincible feeling until a loved one passes away, and then they are hit with a dose of reality.''
 But even though living with 2,000 doses of reality staring him in the face, Mr. Anderson says, he is no more insightful than those who work in plastics factories or those, like Mr. Ruggieri, who can keep their minds solely on their work, as if they were shipping widgets. 
 Mr. Anderson said: ''There is no figuring death out, and there's no such thing as a preparation book. When a person has been sick and passes away, it's a bad thing. And when a person dies suddenly, it's a bad thing.''
 After two decades of thinking about it, Mr. Anderson throws up his hands. ''I just don't know,'' he said. ''After all of it, I just have more insight and knowledge about caskets than the common person.'' 
 That is not to say, he quickly adds, that his life's work does not give him a greater foreshadowing of his ultimate fate. 
 ''I did get life insurance,'' he said. ''And when my daughter was born, I added to it.'' 
 For Mr. Ruggieri, avoidance is accomplished naturally -- because he and his co-workers do not directly deal with the dead; only the products that the dead will be placed in.
 The two worlds -- that of the dead and that of the products the dead will be placed in -- only collide the day before Halloween, when live people enter the warehouse asking to rent coffins for the night. They are accommodated, and appear satisfied, with damaged coffins that cannot be sold.
 Mr. Ruggieri plans to retire some year soon, and Mr. Anderson cannot fathom work without him. He learned from Mr. Ruggieri, he said, everything he knows about the business -- repeating the word ''everything'' twice for emphasis. Mr. Ruggieri taught him a knowledge of each coffin's particulars, the importance of learning the idiosyncrasies of every funeral director's tastes and a fealty to the ideal of getting the coffins out on time. 
 Mr. Gonzalez, who started in the business just this year, is learning, too. For the time being, he refuses to tell women what he does for a living. 
 ''I can't use it as a line,'' he said. ''It might scare them away.'' 
 Asked where he wants to be 5, 10 or 20 years from now, Mr. Gonzalez says, his ambitions are fixed low (or maybe not so low).
 ''Just happy and alive,'' he said.
 Two decades into the business, Mr. Anderson still has a trouble explaining his occupation, at least to his daughter. ''I just always tell her the same thing,'' Mr. Anderson said. ''Daddy sells furniture.''

HEADLINE: Outsourcing Is Another Threat to Jobs

 BODY:
To The Editor:
 Continued funding of major military programs isn't the only fear of thousands of residents employed in the aerospace industry (''Defending Connecticut's Defense Industry,'' April 25). The other fear is outsourcing. As defense contractors push for greater efficiencies, many believe it's only a matter of time before their job is moved to low-cost labor markets overseas. 
 It doesn't have to be that way. Connecticut already has implemented a program that's helping dozens of small aerospace manufacturing companies compete internationally.
 Aerospace Components Manufacturers (A.C.M.), an association of 43 smaller companies with combined employment of about 3,500, recently was awarded $212,500 in grants to help members transition to 'lean' manufacturing, the new international standard for efficiency and employee empowerment. Half of the money comes from the United States Department of Commerce and the other half from the state through the Governor's Council on Economic Competitiveness and Technology, under a program administered by the Department of Economic and Community Development and the Connecticut Economic Resource Center. Grants are matched by A.C.M. participants.
 Under these grants, companies can streamline internal procedures and help aerospace purchasing managers create greater savings by looking beyond a simple comparison of labor costs.
 Clearly, if labor pricing were the only factor determining where to purchase goods, Connecticut companies couldn't be as competitive. However, by including consideration of quality, reliability, turn-around time, the vagaries of long distance shipping, and the cost of dispatching agents across the globe to oversee production, the equation changes.
 Overseas competition is a fact of life. Connecticut's programs can help purchasing managers shift from a simple comparison of manufactured costs to a new realization of true total procurement costs. Continued state and federal support for programs like those run by A.C.M. is one way keep Connecticut's competitive edge and its jobs.

Clifford Lawton
West Granby

The writer is president of CBS Manufacturing, a manufacturing of parts to the aerospace industry, in Windsor.

HEADLINE: Mohegan Tribe Seeking To Expand Reservation

BYLINE: By JEFF HOLTZ

 BODY:
Montville officials received notification last week from the Bureau of Indian Affairs that the Mohegan Tribe of Connecticut had applied to expand its reservation in the town by about 49 acres.
 The mayor of Montville, Joseph W. Jaskiewicz, said the expansion called for the tribe to put an additional 18 of its properties into trust, which mostly include private homes, a church and a cemetery.
 Mark Brown, the tribe's chairman, said the expansion was part of the 700 uncontested acres the tribe was allotted in the compact with the state that established the reservation in 1994. Mr. Brown said the expansion would bring the size of the reservation to about 350 acres. 
 He said any additional land would not be used for casino purposes.
 ''Every year and a half we go back and assess the properties we've acquired and determine whether or not we want to put those lands into trust,'' Mr. Brown said. ''We can't understand why this has even become a topic. This is something we agreed to in 1994, and we're just doing due diligence to make sure we meet all of the requirements of that standard.''
 Mr. Jaskiewicz said the loss of the land would cost the town $268,000 a year in taxes. He said he would look to increase economic development in the town to make up the revenue, but hoped the tribe could help. Mr. Brown said he would be willing to talk with the town.
 Both Mr. Jaskiewicz and Mr. Brown said the town and the tribe have an excellent working relationship.
 Mr. Jaskiewicz said the town receives $500,000 each year from the tribe under the compact. He said the tribe has also donated a new bus to the town and paid for an upgrade to the sewer system. JEFF HOLTZ
